verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who has not followed the counsel of the impious, and has not remained in the way of sinners, and has not sat in the chair of pestilence.
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, qui non abiit in consilio impiorum, et in via peccatorum non stetit, et in cathedra pestilentiæ non sedit:
verses.notes: Or, more loosely translated: “Blessed is the man who has not followed the advice of the impious, and has not stood in the street among sinners, and has not sat in the company of complainers.” The Douay-Rheims notes are particularly insightful on this verse: “Blessed [Note: [a] He is in the right way to eternal happiness. ] is the man, that hath [Note: [b] not consented to evil suggestions. ] not gone in the counsel of the impious, & hath [Note: [c] not continued in sin. ] not stood in the way of sinners, and hath [Note: [d] not finally persisted in wicked life. ] not sit in the chair of pestilence:” Note that, in translating the Psalms, I have decided to choose accuracy and a more literal rendering, over a looser and more poetic phrasing of the text. The reason is that a looser translation, obscures some of the meaning.

verses.textEn: But his will is with the law of the Lord, and he will meditate on his law, day and night.
verses.textLa: Sed in lege Domini voluntas eius, et in lege eius meditabitur die ac nocte.

verses.textEn: And he will be like a tree that has been planted beside running waters, which will provide its fruit in its time, and its leaf will not fall away, and all things whatsoever that he does will prosper.
verses.textLa: Et erit tamquam lignum, quod plantatum est secus decursus aquarum, quod fructum suum dabit in tempore suo: Et folium eius non defluet: et omnia quæcumque faciet, prosperabuntur.

verses.textEn: Not so the impious, not so. For they are like the dust that the wind casts along the face of the earth.
verses.textLa: Non sic impii, non sic: sed tamquam pulvis, quem proiicit ventus a facie terræ.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the impious will not prevail again in judgment, nor sinners in the council of the just.
verses.textLa: Ideo non resurgent impii in iudicio: neque peccatores in concilio iustorum.
verses.notes: The verb ‘resurgent’ could be translated as ‘prevail again’ or as ‘rise up again.’ The translation ‘the impious will not rise up again in the judgment’ is avoided because both the just and the unjust will rise again at the general resurrection on the day of judgment.

verses.textEn: For the Lord knows the way of the just. And the path of the impious will pass away.
verses.textLa: Quoniam novit Dominus viam iustorum: et iter impiorum peribit.

verses.textEn: Why have the Gentiles been seething, and why have the people been pondering nonsense?
verses.textLa: Quare fremuerunt Gentes, et populi meditati sunt inania?
verses.notes: The word ‘gentes’ can be translated as ‘Gentiles,’ or as ‘nations,’ or as ‘peoples.’ When translated as ‘Gentiles,’ and when viewed from a present-day Catholic perspective, it refers not to non-Jews, but to non-believers.

verses.textEn: The kings of the earth have stood up, and the leaders have joined together as one, against the Lord and against his Christ:
verses.textLa: Astiterunt reges terræ, et principes convenerunt in unum adversus Dominum, et adversus Christum eius.

verses.textEn: “Let us shatter their chains and cast their yoke away from us.”
verses.textLa: Dirumpamus vincula eorum: et proiiciamus a nobis iugum ipsorum.

verses.textEn: He who dwells in heaven will ridicule them, and the Lord will mock them.
verses.textLa: Qui habitat in cælis irridebit eos: et Dominus subsannabit eos.

verses.textEn: Then will he speak to them in his anger and trouble them with his fury.
verses.textLa: Tunc loquetur ad eos in ira sua, et in furore suo conturbabit eos.

verses.textEn: Yet I have been appointed king by him over Zion, his holy mountain, preaching his precepts.
verses.textLa: Ego autem constitutus sum rex ab eo super Sion montem sanctum eius, prædicans præceptum eius.

verses.textEn: The Lord has said to me: You are my son, this day have I begotten you.
verses.textLa: Dominus dixit ad me: Filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘Filius meus es tu’ is a good example of how word order in Latin differs from word order in English. The word order in English is exactly the reverse of the word order in Latin. To translate, one must read the entire phrase before giving the first word of the translation.

verses.textEn: Ask of me and I will give to you: the Gentiles for your inheritance, and the ends of the earth for your possession.
verses.textLa: Postula a me, et dabo tibi Gentes hereditatem tuam, et possessionem tuam terminos terræ.

verses.textEn: You will rule them with an iron rod, and you will shatter them like a potter’s vessel.
verses.textLa: Reges eos in virga ferrea, et tamquam vas figuli confringes eos.

verses.textEn: And now, O kings, understand. Receive instruction, you who judge the earth.
verses.textLa: Et nunc reges intelligite: erudimini qui iudicatis terram.
verses.notes: More literally: ‘Be taught, you who judge the land.’

verses.textEn: Serve the Lord in fear, and exult in him with trembling.
verses.textLa: Servite Domino in timore: et exultate ei cum tremore.

verses.textEn: Embrace discipline, lest at any time the Lord might become angry, and you would perish from the way of the just.
verses.textLa: Apprehendite disciplinam nequando irascatur Dominus, et pereatis de via iusta.
verses.notes: Notice the use of the subjunctive tense here, and its translation. God may become angry, and then you would perish from the just way.

verses.textEn: Though his wrath can flare up in a short time, blessed are all those who trust in him.
verses.textLa: Cum exarserit in brevi ira eius, beati omnes, qui confidunt in eo.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. When he fled from the face of his son, Absalom.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, Cum fugeret a facie Absalom filii sui.

verses.textEn: Lord, why have those who trouble me been multiplied? Many rise up against me.
verses.textLa: Domine quid multiplicati sunt qui tribulant me? multi insurgunt adversum me.

verses.textEn: Many say to my soul, “There is no salvation for him in his God.”
verses.textLa: Multi dicunt animæ meæ: Non est salus ipsi in Deo eius.
verses.notes: The word ‘salus’ can mean ‘salvation,’ or ‘safety,’ or ‘health.’

verses.textEn: But you, Lord, are my supporter, my glory, and the one who raises up my head.
verses.textLa: Tu autem Domine susceptor meus es, gloria mea, et exaltans caput meum.

verses.textEn: I have cried out to the Lord with my voice, and he has heard me from his holy mountain.
verses.textLa: Voce mea ad Dominum clamavi: et exaudivit me de monte sancto suo.

verses.textEn: I have slept, and I have been stupefied. But I awakened because the Lord has taken me up.
verses.textLa: Ego dormivi, et soporatus sum: et exurrexi, quia Dominus suscepit me.
verses.notes: The verb ‘soporatus sum’ does not refer to normal sleep. It refers to being knocked unconscious or being put to sleep by something (extreme weariness, medication, etc.). It can also mean, more loosely, to be stupefied or dumbstruck. The reference to sleep in this verse is metaphorical, so ‘stupefied’ works better than ‘unconscious.’

verses.textEn: I will not fear the thousands of people surrounding me. Rise up, Lord. Save me, my God.
verses.textLa: Non timebo millia populi circumdantis me: exurge Domine: salvum me fac Deus meus.
verses.notes: Or, ‘Accomplish my salvation, my God.’

verses.textEn: For you have struck all those who oppose me without cause. You have broken the teeth of sinners.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu percussisti omnes adversantes mihi sine causa: dentes peccatorum contrivisti.

verses.textEn: Salvation is of the Lord, and your blessing is upon your people.
verses.textLa: Domini est salus: et super populum tuum benedictio tua.

verses.textEn: In parts according to verses. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem in carminibus, Psalmus David.
verses.notes:
Usually, ‘finem’ refers to the end or limit of something, but the root of the word is related to ‘findo,’ which means to divide into parts. Thus the word ‘finem’ typically means ‘the last part.’ But, in the context of the Psalms, which were in ancient times, as they are still today, sung or chanted, the phrase ‘in finem’ can mean ‘in parts.’ This expression refers to a song that is divided into different singing parts (e.g. a duet, or a song with parts for a chorus and parts for individuals), or to a poem that is divided into different speaking parts.
 However, there is a more meaningful translation of ‘in finem.’ The notes of the Douay-Rheims version interpret ‘in finem’ (‘unto the end’) to refer to the New Testament: ‘pertaining unto the new Testament.’ And the Wycliffe version translates ‘in finem’ as ‘for victories,’ i.e. pertaining to a successful end. Thus, ‘in finem’ in this translation is usually rendered as ‘unto the end,’ since this translation makes the most fulfilling meanings most accessible.
 The word ‘carminibus’ refers to a card for working with wool or flax. It is a card with many divisions or parts. In this context, ‘carminibus’ refers to the division of the psalm into verses. In ancient times, the Bible was not divided into verses. Perhaps the first application of this concept to the Bible was in the psalms, which had to be divided into verses, because it is poetry and because it is sung.

verses.textEn: When I called upon him, the God of my justice heeded me. In tribulation, you have enlarged me. Have mercy on me, and heed my prayer.
verses.textLa: Cum invocarem exaudivit me Deus iustitiæ meæ: in tribulatione dilatasti mihi. Miserere mei, et exaudi orationem meam.

verses.textEn: Sons of men, how long will you be dull in heart, so that whatever you love is in vain, and whatever you seek is false?
verses.textLa: Filii hominum usquequo gravi corde? ut quid diligitis vanitatem, et quæritis mendacium?

verses.textEn: And know this: the Lord has made wondrous his holy one. The Lord will heed me when I cry out to him.
verses.textLa: Et scitote quoniam mirificavit Dominus sanctum suum: Dominus exaudiet me cum clamavero ad eum.

verses.textEn: Be angry, and do not be willing to sin. The things that you say in your hearts: be sorry for them on your beds.
verses.textLa: Irascimini, et nolite peccare: quæ dicitis in cordibus vestris, in cubilibus vestris compungimini.

verses.textEn: Offer the sacrifice of justice, and hope in the Lord. Many say, “Who reveals to us what is good?”
verses.textLa: Sacrificate sacrificium iustitiæ, et sperate in Domino. Multi dicunt: Quis ostendit nobis bona?

verses.textEn: The light of your countenance, Lord, has been sealed upon us. You have given joy to my heart.
verses.textLa: Signatum est super nos lumen vultus tui Domine: dedisti lætitiam in corde meo.

verses.textEn: By the fruit of their grain, wine, and oil, they have been multiplied.
verses.textLa: A fructu frumenti, vini, et olei sui multiplicati sunt.

verses.textEn: In peace itself, I will sleep and I will rest.
verses.textLa: In pace in idipsum dormiam, et requiescam;
verses.notes: Or, ‘In peace, in the very same, I will sleep and I will rest.’

verses.textEn: For you, O Lord, have established me singularly in hope.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu Domine singulariter in spe constituisti me.
verses.notes: The term ‘singulariter’ could refer to God who alone establishes me in hope, or it could refer to being established in hope alone or in hope in a singular manner.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For her who pursues the inheritance. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem pro ea, quæ hereditatem consequitur, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: O Lord, listen closely to my words. Understand my outcry.
verses.textLa: Verba mea auribus percipe Domine, intellige clamorem meum.

verses.textEn: Attend to the voice of my prayer, my King and my God.
verses.textLa: Intende voci orationis meæ, Rex meus et Deus meus.

verses.textEn: For to you, I will pray. In the morning, Lord, you will hear my voice.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ad te orabo: Domine mane exaudies vocem meam.

verses.textEn: In the morning, I will stand before you, and I will see. For you are not a God who wills iniquity.
verses.textLa: Mane astabo tibi et videbo: quoniam non Deus volens iniquitatem tu es.

verses.textEn: And the malicious will not dwell close to you, nor will the unjust endure before your eyes.
verses.textLa: Neque habitabit iuxta te malignus: neque permanebunt iniusti ante oculos tuos.

verses.textEn: You hate all who work iniquity. You will destroy all who speak a lie. The bloody and deceitful man, the Lord will abominate.
verses.textLa: Odisti omnes, qui operantur iniquitatem: perdes omnes, qui loquuntur mendacium. Virum sanguinum et dolosum abominabitur Dominus:

verses.textEn: But I am in the multitude of your mercy. I will enter your house. I will show adoration toward your holy temple, in your fear.
verses.textLa: ego autem in multitudine misericordiæ tuæ. Introibo in domum tuam: adorabo ad templum sanctum tuum in timore tuo.
verses.notes: The humanity of Christ is a Temple united to His Divinity.

verses.textEn: Lord, lead me in your justice. Because of my enemies, direct my way in your sight.
verses.textLa: Domine deduc me in iustitia tua: propter inimicos meos dirige in conspectu tuo viam meam.

verses.textEn: For there is no truth in their mouth: their heart is vain.
verses.textLa: Quoniam non est in ore eorum veritas: cor eorum vanum est.

verses.textEn: Their throat is an open sepulcher. They have acted deceitfully with their tongues. Judge them, O God. Let them fall by their own intentions: according to the multitude of their impiety, expel them. For they have provoked you, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Sepulchrum patens est guttur eorum, linguis suis dolose agebant, iudica illos Deus. Decidant a cogitationibus suis, secundum multitudinem impietatum eorum expelle eos, quoniam irritaverunt te Domine.

verses.textEn: But let all those who hope in you rejoice. They will exult in eternity, and you will dwell in them. And all those who love your name will glory in you.
verses.textLa: Et lætentur omnes, qui sperant in te, in æternum exultabunt: et habitabis in eis. Et gloriabuntur in te omnes, qui diligunt nomen tuum,

verses.textEn: For you will bless the just. You have crowned us, O Lord, as if with a shield of your good will.
verses.textLa: quoniam tu benedices iusto. Domine, ut scuto bonæ voluntatis tuæ coronasti nos.

verses.textEn: In parts according to verses. A Psalm of David. For the octave.
verses.textLa: In finem in carminibus, Psalmus David, pro octava.

verses.textEn: O Lord, do not rebuke me in your fury, nor chastise me in your anger.
verses.textLa: Domine, ne in furore tuo arguas me, neque in ira tua corripias me.

verses.textEn: Have mercy on me, Lord, for I am weak. Heal me, Lord, for my bones have become disturbed,
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Domine quoniam infirmus sum: sana me Domine quoniam conturbata sunt ossa mea,

verses.textEn: and my soul has been very troubled. But as for you, Lord, when?
verses.textLa: et anima mea turbata est valde: sed tu Domine usquequo?

verses.textEn: Turn to me, Lord, and rescue my soul. Save me because of your mercy.
verses.textLa: Convertere Domine, et eripe animam meam: salvum me fac propter misericordiam tuam.

verses.textEn: For there is no one in death who would be mindful of you. And who will confess to you in Hell?
verses.textLa: Quoniam non est in morte qui memor sit tui: in inferno autem quis confitebitur tibi?

verses.textEn: I have labored in my groaning. Every night, with my tears, I will wash my bed and drench my blanket.
verses.textLa: Laboravi in gemitu meo, lavabo per singulas noctes lectum meum: lacrymis meis stratum meum rigabo.

verses.textEn: My eye has been troubled by rage. I have grown old among all my enemies.
verses.textLa: Turbatus est a furore oculus meus: inveteravi inter omnes inimicos meos.

verses.textEn: Scatter before me, all you who work iniquity, for the Lord has heard the voice of my weeping.
verses.textLa: Discedite a me omnes qui operamini iniquitatem: quoniam exaudivit Dominus vocem fletus mei.

verses.textEn: The Lord has heard my supplication. The Lord has accepted my prayer.
verses.textLa: Exaudivit Dominus deprecationem meam, Dominus orationem meam suscepit.

verses.textEn: Let all my enemies be ashamed and together be greatly troubled. May they be converted and become ashamed very quickly.
verses.textLa: Erubescant, et conturbentur vehementer omnes inimici mei: convertantur et erubescant valde velociter.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David, which he sang to the Lord because of the words of Cush, the son of Jemini.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, quem cantavit Domino pro verbis Chusi filii Iemini.

verses.textEn: O Lord, my God, in you I have hoped. Save me from all those who persecute me, and free me:
verses.textLa: Domine Deus meus in te speravi: salvum me fac ex omnibus persequentibus me, et libera me.

verses.textEn: lest at any time, like a lion, he might seize my soul, while there is no one to redeem me, nor any who can save.
verses.textLa: Nequando rapiat ut leo animam meam, dum non est qui redimat, neque qui salvum faciat.

verses.textEn: O Lord, my God, if there is iniquity in my hands, if I have done this:
verses.textLa: Domine Deus meus si feci istud, si est iniquitas in manibus meis:

verses.textEn: if I have repaid those who rendered evils to me, may I deservedly fall away empty before my enemies:
verses.textLa: Si reddidi retribuentibus mihi mala, decidam merito ab inimicis meis inanis.

verses.textEn: let the enemy pursue my soul, and take hold of it, and trample my life into the earth, and drag down my glory into the dust.
verses.textLa: Persequatur inimicus animam meam, et comprehendat, et conculcet in terra vitam meam, et gloriam meam in pulverem deducat.

verses.textEn: Rise up, Lord, in your anger. And be exalted to the borders of my enemies. And rise up, O Lord my God, according to the precept that you commanded,
verses.textLa: Exurge Domine in ira tua: et exaltare in finibus inimicorum meorum. Et exurge Domine Deus meus in præcepto quod mandasti:

verses.textEn: and a congregation of people will surround you. And, because of this, return on high.
verses.textLa: et synagoga populorum circumdabit te. Et propter hanc in altum regredere:

verses.textEn: The Lord judges the people. Judge me, O Lord, according to my justice and according to my innocence within me.
verses.textLa: Dominus iudicat populos. Iudica me Domine secundum iustitiam meam, et secundum innocentiam meam super me.

verses.textEn: The wickedness of sinners will be consumed, and you will direct the just: the examiner of hearts and temperaments is God.
verses.textLa: Consumetur nequitia peccatorum, et diriges iustum, scrutans corda et renes Deus.
verses.notes: The word ‘renes’ literally means ‘kidneys,’ but it is used metaphorically to refer to one’s temperament.

verses.textEn: Just is my help from the Lord, who saves the upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Iustum adiutorium meum a Domino, qui salvos facit rectos corde.

verses.textEn: God is a just judge, strong and patient. How could he be angry throughout every day?
verses.textLa: Deus iudex iustus, fortis, et patiens: numquid irascitur per singulos dies?

verses.textEn: Unless you will be converted, he will brandish his sword. He has extended his bow and made it ready.
verses.textLa: Nisi conversi fueritis, gladium suum vibrabit: arcum suum tetendit, et paravit illum.

verses.textEn: And with it, he has prepared instruments of death. He has produced his arrows for those on fire.
verses.textLa: Et in eo paravit vasa mortis, sagittas suas ardentibus effecit.

verses.textEn: Behold him who has given birth to injustice: he has conceived sorrow and has begotten iniquity.
verses.textLa: Ecce parturiit iniustitiam: concepit dolorem, et peperit iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: He has opened a pit and enlarged it. And he has fallen into the hole that he made.
verses.textLa: Lacum aperuit, et effodit eum: et incidit in foveam, quam fecit.

verses.textEn: His sorrow will be turned upon his own head, and his iniquity will descend upon his highest point.
verses.textLa: Convertetur dolor eius in caput eius: et in verticem ipsius iniquitas eius descendet.

verses.textEn: I will confess to the Lord according to his justice, and I will sing a psalm to the name of the Lord Most High.
verses.textLa: Confitebor Domino secundum iustitiam eius: et psallam nomini Domini altissimi.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the oil and wine presses. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem pro torcularibus, Psalmus David.
verses.notes: The word ‘torcularibus’ refers to oil and wine presses. This psalm is a prayer praising God’s magnificence as displayed in the abundance that comes to us from nature.

verses.textEn: O Lord, our Lord, how admirable is your name throughout all the earth! For your magnificence is elevated above the heavens.
verses.textLa: Domine Dominus noster, quam admirabile est nomen tuum in universa terra! Quoniam elevata est magnificentia tua, super cælos.

verses.textEn: Out of the mouths of babes and infants, you have perfected praise, because of your enemies, so that you may destroy the enemy and the revenger.
verses.textLa: Ex ore infantium et lactentium perfecisti laudem propter inimicos tuos, ut destruas inimicum et ultorem.
verses.notes: The word ‘lactentium’ literally refers to infants who are still nursing; and the word ‘infantium’ more generally refers to young children. Despite the similarity to the English word ‘infant,’ the word ‘infantium’ is better rendered as babes or toddlers, and ‘lactentium’ is a better fit for ‘infants.’

verses.textEn: For I will behold your heavens, the works of your fingers: the moon and the stars, which you have founded.
verses.textLa: Quoniam videbo cælos tuos, opera digitorum tuorum: lunam et stellas, quæ tu fundasti.

verses.textEn: What is man, that you are mindful of him, or the son of man, that you visit him?
verses.textLa: Quid est homo, quod memor es eius? aut filius hominis, quoniam visitas eum?

verses.textEn: You reduced him to a little less than the Angels; you have crowned him with glory and honor,
verses.textLa: Minuisti eum paulominus ab angelis, gloria et honore coronasti eum:

verses.textEn: and you have set him over the works of your hands.
verses.textLa: et constituisti eum super opera manuum tuarum.

verses.textEn: You have subjected all things under his feet, all sheep and oxen, and in addition: the beasts of the field,
verses.textLa: Omnia subiecisti sub pedibus eius, oves et boves universas: insuper et pecora campi.

verses.textEn: the birds of the air, and the fish of the sea, which pass through the paths of the sea.
verses.textLa: Volucres cæli, et pisces maris, qui perambulant semitas maris.

verses.textEn: O Lord, our Lord, how admirable is your name throughout all the earth!
verses.textLa: Domine Dominus noster, quam admirabile est nomen tuum in universa terra!

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the secrets of the Son. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro occultis filii, Psalmus David.
verses.notes: Or, ‘for the hidden things of the Son.’ Some psalms have an introductory verse that often contains an instruction concerning the reciting or singing of the psalm, or a statement about its topic, or dedication, or purpose. Even the most devout and knowledgeable Christian does not know everything, or even most things that could be known about the Son. He is ever partially hidden from our view.

verses.textEn: I will confess to you, Lord, with my whole heart. I will recount all your wonders.
verses.textLa: Confitebor tibi Domine in toto corde meo: narrabo omnia mirabilia tua.

verses.textEn: I will rejoice and exult in you. I will sing a psalm to your name, O Most High.
verses.textLa: Lætabor et exultabo in te: psallam nomini tuo Altissime,

verses.textEn: For my enemy will be turned back. They will be weakened and perish before your face.
verses.textLa: In convertendo inimicum meum retrorsum: infirmabuntur, et peribunt a facie tua.

verses.textEn: For you have accomplished my judgment and my cause. You have sat upon the throne that judges justice.
verses.textLa: Quoniam fecisti iudicium meum et causam meam: sedisti super thronum qui iudicas iustitiam.

verses.textEn: You have rebuked the Gentiles, and the impious one has perished. You have deleted their name in eternity and for all generations.
verses.textLa: Increpasti Gentes, et periit impius: nomen eorum delesti in æternum et in sæculum sæculi.
verses.notes: Their name has been deleted in eternity (Heaven) and for all future generations on earth. For at the general Resurrection God takes away Heaven and earth, and He makes a new Heaven and a new earth.

verses.textEn: The spears of the enemy have failed in the end, and their cities, you have destroyed. Their memory has perished with a loud noise.
verses.textLa: Inimici defecerunt frameæ in finem: et civitates eorum destruxisti. Periit memoria eorum cum sonitu:

verses.textEn: But the Lord remains in eternity. He has prepared his throne in judgment.
verses.textLa: et Dominus in æternum permanet. Paravit in iudicio thronum suum:

verses.textEn: And he will judge the whole world in equity. He will judge the people in justice.
verses.textLa: et ipse iudicabit orbem terræ in æquitate, iudicabit populos in iustitia.

verses.textEn: And the Lord has become a refuge for the poor, a helper in opportunity, in tribulation.
verses.textLa: Et factus est Dominus refugium pauperi: adiutor in opportunitatibus, in tribulatione.

verses.textEn: And may they hope in you, who know your name. For you have not abandoned those seeking you, Lord.
verses.textLa: Et sperent in te qui noverunt nomen tuum: quoniam non dereliquisti quærentes te Domine.

verses.textEn: Sing a psalm to the Lord, who dwells in Zion. Announce his study among the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Psallite Domino, qui habitat in Sion: annunciate inter Gentes studia eius:
verses.notes: The word ‘studia’ refers to a topic of study, devotion, or interest. The topic is the teaching of the Church.

verses.textEn: Because of those who yearned for their blood, he has remembered them. He has not forgotten the cry of the poor.
verses.textLa: Quoniam requirens sanguinem eorum recordatus est: non est oblitus clamorem pauperum.

verses.textEn: Have mercy on me, Lord. See my humiliation from my enemies.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Domine: vide humilitatem meam de inimicis meis.

verses.textEn: You lift me up from the gates of death, so that I may announce all your praises at the gates of the daughter of Zion.
verses.textLa: Qui exaltas me de portis mortis, ut annunciem omnes laudationes tuas in portis filiæ Sion.
verses.notes: Or, ‘at the gates of daughter Zion.’

verses.textEn: I will exult in your salvation. The Gentiles have become trapped in the ruin that they made. Their foot has been caught in the same snare that they themselves had hidden.
verses.textLa: Exultabo in salutari tuo: infixæ sunt Gentes in interitu, quem fecerunt. In laqueo isto, quem absconderunt, comprehensus est pes eorum.

verses.textEn: The Lord will be recognized when making judgments. The sinner has been caught in the works of his own hands.
verses.textLa: Cognoscetur Dominus iudicia faciens: in operibus manuum suarum comprehensus est peccator.

verses.textEn: The sinners will be turned into Hell: all the Gentiles who have forgotten God.
verses.textLa: Convertantur peccatores in infernum, omnes Gentes quæ obliviscuntur Deum.
verses.notes: Gentiles, in this context, refers to any and all who ignore or reject God, to non-believers rather merely to non-Jews.

verses.textEn: For the poor will not be forgotten in the end. The patience of the poor will not perish in the end.
verses.textLa: Quoniam non in finem oblivio erit pauperis: patientia pauperum non peribit in finem.

verses.textEn: Rise up, Lord: do not let man be strengthened. Let the Gentiles be judged in your sight.
verses.textLa: Exurge Domine, non confortetur homo: iudicentur Gentes in conspectu tuo:

verses.textEn: O Lord, establish a lawgiver over them, so that the Gentiles may know that they are only men.
verses.textLa: Constitue Domine legislatorem super eos: ut sciant Gentes quoniam homines sunt.

verses.textEn: So then, why, O Lord, have you withdrawn far away? Why have you overlooked us in opportunity, in tribulation?
verses.textLa: Ut quid Domine recessisti longe, despicis in opportunitatibus, in tribulatione?

verses.textEn: While the impious is arrogant, the poor is enflamed. They are held by the counsels that they devise.
verses.textLa: Dum superbit impius, incenditur pauper: comprehenduntur in consiliis quibus cogitant.

verses.textEn: For the sinner is praised by the desires of his soul, and the iniquitous is blessed.
verses.textLa: Quoniam laudatur peccator in desideriis animæ suæ: et iniquus benedicitur.
verses.notes: The meaning is that the sinner is given praise for his sins by the sinful desires in his soul, and likewise, the iniquitous person is given blessings by the iniquity in his soul. In this context, the word ‘benedicitur’ is not a euphemism for cursing. One finds this euphemism in Job 2:9, where the wife of Job is speaking about God. She says ‘Bless God,’ because she dare not say the words ‘Curse God.’ However, Scripture itself, when explaining the truth to us, does not refrain from using the word ‘curse.’

verses.textEn: The sinner has provoked the Lord; according to the multitude of his wrath, he will not seek him.
verses.textLa: Exacerbavit Dominum peccator, secundum multitudinem iræ suæ non quæret.

verses.textEn: God is not before his sight. His ways are stained at all times. Your judgments are removed from his face. He will be master of all his enemies.
verses.textLa: Non est Deus in conspectu eius: inquinatæ sunt viæ illius in omni tempore. Auferuntur iudicia tua a facie eius: omnium inimicorum suorum dominabitur.

verses.textEn: For he has said in his heart, “I will not be disturbed: from generation to generation without evil.”
verses.textLa: Dixit enim in corde suo: Non movebor a generatione in generationem, sine malo.
verses.notes: The word ‘movebor’ can be translated as ‘moved’ or as ‘disturbed.’ The word ‘malo’ can be translated as ‘evil’ or as ‘misfortune’ or ‘disaster.’

verses.textEn: His mouth is full of curses, and bitterness, and deceit. Under his tongue are hardship and sorrow.
verses.textLa: Cuius maledictione os plenum est, et amaritudine, et dolo: sub lingua eius labor et dolor.

verses.textEn: He sits in ambush, with resources in hidden places, so that he may execute the innocent.
verses.textLa: Sedet in insidiis cum divitibus in occultis, ut interficiat innocentem.

verses.textEn: His eyes catch sight of the poor. He lies in ambush, in hiding like a lion in his den. He lies in ambush, so that he may seize the poor, to seize the poor as he draws him in.
verses.textLa: Oculi eius in pauperem respiciunt: insidiatur in abscondito, quasi leo in spelunca sua. Insidiatur ut rapiat pauperem: rapere pauperem dum attrahit eum.

verses.textEn: With his snare, he will bring him down. He will crouch down and pounce, when he has power over the poor.
verses.textLa: In laqueo suo humiliabit eum, inclinabit se, et cadet cum dominatus fuerit pauperum.

verses.textEn: For he has said in his heart, “God has forgotten, he has turned away his face, lest he see to the end.”
verses.textLa: Dixit enim in corde suo: Oblitus est Deus, avertit faciem suam ne videat in finem.

verses.textEn: O Lord God, rise up. Let your hand be exalted. Do not forget the poor.
verses.textLa: Exurge Domine Deus, exaltetur manus tua: ne obliviscaris pauperum.

verses.textEn: How has the impious one provoked God? For he has said in his heart, “He will not inquire.”
verses.textLa: Propter quid irritavit impius Deum? dixit enim in corde suo: Non requiret.

verses.textEn: You do see, for you examine hardship and sorrow, so that you may deliver them into your hands. The poor one has been abandoned to you. You will be a helper to the orphan.
verses.textLa: Vides, quoniam tu laborem et dolorem consideras: ut tradas eos in manus tuas. Tibi derelictus est pauper: orphano tu eris adiutor.

verses.textEn: Break the arm of the sinner and the malicious. His sin will be sought, and it will not be found.
verses.textLa: Contere brachium peccatoris et maligni: quæretur peccatum illius, et non invenietur.
verses.notes: His sin will not be found because he has been defeated by God and his sinful deeds are no more.

verses.textEn: The Lord shall reign in eternity, even forever and ever. You will perish the Gentiles from his land.
verses.textLa: Dominus regnabit in æternum, et in sæculum sæculi: peribitis Gentes de terra illius.

verses.textEn: The Lord has heeded the desire of the poor. Your ear has listened to the preparation of their heart,
verses.textLa: Desiderium pauperum exaudivit Dominus: præparationem cordis eorum audivit auris tua.

verses.textEn: so as to judge for the orphan and the humble, so that man may no longer presume to magnify himself upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Iudicare pupillo et humili, ut non apponat ultra magnificare se homo super terram.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David.
verses.notes: The expression, ‘in finem’ can be interpreted to refer to a psalm that is sung or recited ‘in parts.’ It can also be interpreted to mean ‘unto the end.’

verses.textEn: I trust in the Lord. How can you say to my soul, “Sojourn to the mountain, like a sparrow.”
verses.textLa: In Domino confido: quomodo dicitis animæ meæ: Transmigra in montem sicut passer?

verses.textEn: For behold, the sinners have bent their bow. They have prepared their arrows in the quiver, so as to shoot arrows in the dark at the upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ecce peccatores intenderunt arcum, paraverunt sagittas suas in pharetra, ut sagittent in obscuro rectos corde.

verses.textEn: For they have destroyed the things that you have completed. But what has the just one done?
verses.textLa: Quoniam quæ perfecisti, destruxerunt: iustus autem quid fecit?

verses.textEn: The Lord is in his holy temple. The Lord’s throne is in heaven. His eyes look upon the poor. His eyelids question the sons of men.
verses.textLa: Dominus in templo sancto suo, Dominus in cælo sedes eius: Oculi eius in pauperem respiciunt: palpebræ eius interrogant filios hominum.

verses.textEn: The Lord questions the just and the impious. Yet he who loves iniquity, hates his own soul.
verses.textLa: Dominus interrogat iustum et impium: qui autem diligit iniquitatem, odit animam suam.

verses.textEn: He will rain down snares upon sinners. Fire and brimstone and windstorms will be the portion of their cup.
verses.textLa: Pluet super peccatores laqueos: ignis, et sulphur, et spiritus procellarum pars calicis eorum.
verses.notes: Or, ‘spiritual storms.’

verses.textEn: For the Lord is just, and he has chosen justice. His countenance has beheld equity.
verses.textLa: Quoniam iustus Dominus et iustitias dilexit: æquitatem vidit vultus eius.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the octave. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem pro octava, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: Save me, O Lord, because holiness has passed away, because truths have been diminished, before the sons of men.
verses.textLa: Salvum me fac Domine, quoniam defecit sanctus: quoniam diminutæ sunt veritates a filiis hominum.

verses.textEn: They have been speaking emptiness, each one to his neighbor; they have been speaking with deceitful lips and a duplicitous heart.
verses.textLa: Vana locuti sunt unusquisque ad proximum suum: labia dolosa, in corde et corde locuti sunt.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘in corde et corde’ is idiomatic, meaning with a duplicitous or double heart.

verses.textEn: May the Lord scatter all deceitful lips, along with the tongue that speaks malice.
verses.textLa: Disperdat Dominus universa labia dolosa, et linguam magniloquam.

verses.textEn: They have said: “We will magnify our tongue; our lips belong to us. Who is our Lord?”
verses.textLa: Qui dixerunt: Linguam nostram magnificabimus, labia nostra a nobis sunt, quis noster Dominus est?

verses.textEn: Because of the misery of the destitute and the groaning of the poor, now I will arise, says the Lord. I will place him in safety. I will act faithfully toward him.
verses.textLa: Propter miseriam inopum, et gemitum pauperum nunc exurgam, dicit Dominus. Ponam in salutari: fiducialiter agam in eo.

verses.textEn: The eloquence of the Lord is pure eloquence, silver tested by fire, purged from the earth, refined seven times.
verses.textLa: Eloquia Domini, eloquia casta: argentum igne examinatum, probatum terræ purgatum septuplum.

verses.textEn: You, O Lord, will preserve us, and you will guard us from this generation into eternity.
verses.textLa: Tu Domine servabis nos: et custodies nos a generatione hac in æternum.

verses.textEn: The impious wander aimlessly. According to your loftiness, you have multiplied the sons of men.
verses.textLa: In circuitu impii ambulant: secundum altitudinem tuam multiplicasti filios hominum.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David. How long, O Lord? Will you forget me until the end? How long will you turn your face away from me?
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David. Usquequo Domine oblivisceris me in finem? Usquequo avertis faciem tuam a me?

verses.textEn: How long can I take counsel in my soul, sorrowing in my heart throughout the day?
verses.textLa: Quamdiu ponam consilia in anima mea, dolorem in corde meo per diem?

verses.textEn: How long will my enemy be exalted over me?
verses.textLa: Usquequo exaltabitur inimicus meus super me?

verses.textEn: Look upon me and listen to me, O Lord my God. Enlighten my eyes, lest I fall asleep forever in death,
verses.textLa: Respice, et exaudi me Domine Deus meus. Illumina oculos meos ne umquam obdormiam in morte:

verses.textEn: lest at any time my enemy may say, “I have prevailed against him.” Those who trouble me will exult, if I have been disturbed.
verses.textLa: ne quando dicat inimicus meus: Prævalui adversus eum. Qui tribulant me, exultabunt si motus fuero:

verses.textEn: But I have hoped in your mercy. My heart will exult in your salvation. I will sing to the Lord, who assigns good things to me. And I will sing psalms to the name of the Lord Most High.
verses.textLa: ego autem in misericordia tua speravi. Exultabit cor meum in salutari tuo: cantabo Domino qui bona tribuit mihi: et psallam nomini Domini altissimi.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David. The fool has said in his heart, “There is no God.” They were corrupted, and they have become abominable in their studies. There is no one who does good; there is not even one.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David. Dixit insipiens in corde suo: Non est Deus. Corrupti sunt, et abominabiles facti sunt in studiis suis: non est qui faciat bonum, non est usque ad unum.

verses.textEn: The Lord has looked down from heaven upon the sons of men, to see if there were any who were considering or seeking God.
verses.textLa: Dominus de cælo prospexit super filios hominum, ut videat si est intelligens, aut requirens Deum.

verses.textEn: They have all gone astray; together they have become useless. There is no one who does good; there is not even one.
verses.textLa: Omnes declinaverunt, simul inutiles facti sunt: non est qui faciat bonum, non est usque ad unum.
verses.notes: This verse in the Vulgate is very long, encompassing 13:3 through 13:6 in this renumbered version of Psalm 13. The Vulgate probably kept verse 13:3 long in order to align with the same Psalm in the Hebrew version, which has a much shorter verse 13:3. I have renumbered this Psalm for the CPDV and for my edit of the Vulgate.

verses.textEn: Their throat is an open sepulcher. With their tongues, they have been acting deceitfully; the venom of asps is under their lips. Their mouth is full of curses and bitterness.
verses.textLa: Sepulchrum patens est guttur eorum: linguis suis dolose agebant, venenum aspidum sub labiis eorum. Quorum os maledictione et amaritudine plenum est:

verses.textEn: Their feet are swift to shed blood. Grief and unhappiness are in their ways; and the way of peace, they have not known.
verses.textLa: veloces pedes eorum ad effundendum sanguinem. Contritio et infelicitas in viis eorum, et viam pacis non cognoverunt:

verses.textEn: There is no fear of God before their eyes.
verses.textLa: non est timor Dei ante oculos eorum.

verses.textEn: Will they never learn: all those who work iniquity, who devour my people like a meal of bread?
verses.textLa: Nonne cognoscent omnes qui operantur iniquitatem, qui devorant plebem meam sicut escam panis?
verses.notes: The verb ‘cognoscent’ can refer to knowing or having knowledge; it can also refer to becoming aware of something, or to learning about something.

verses.textEn: They have not called upon the Lord. There, they have trembled in fear, where there was no fear.
verses.textLa: Dominum non invocaverunt, illic trepidaverunt timore, ubi non erat timor.

verses.textEn: For the Lord is with the just generation. You have confounded the counsel of the needy because the Lord is his hope.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Dominus in generatione iusta est, consilium inopis confudistis, quoniam Dominus spes eius est.

verses.textEn: Who will grant the salvation of Israel from Zion? When the Lord turns away the captivity of his people, Jacob will exult, and Israel will rejoice.
verses.textLa: Quis dabit ex Sion salutare Israel? cum averterit Dominus captivitatem plebis suæ, exultabit Iacob, et lætabitur Israel.
verses.notes: Literally, the verb ‘averterit’ is translated ‘will have turned away.’ But English tends to use the present tense in a clause such as this one. When translating, tenses do not always remain the same.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. O Lord, who will dwell in your tabernacle? Or who will rest on your holy mountain?
verses.textLa: Psalmus David. Domine quis habitabit in tabernaculo tuo? aut quis requiescet in monte sancto tuo?

verses.textEn: He who walks without blemish and who works justice.
verses.textLa: Qui ingreditur sine macula, et operatur iustitiam:

verses.textEn: He who speaks the truth in his heart, who has not acted deceitfully with his tongue, and has not done evil to his neighbor, and has not taken up a reproach against his neighbors.
verses.textLa: Qui loquitur veritatem in corde suo, qui non egit dolum in lingua sua: Nec fecit proximo suo malum, et opprobrium non accepit adversus proximos suos.

verses.textEn: In his sight, the malicious one has been reduced to nothing, but he glorifies those who fear the Lord. He who swears to his neighbor and does not deceive.
verses.textLa: Ad nihilum deductus est in conspectu eius malignus: timentes autem Dominum glorificat: Qui iurat proximo suo, et non decipit,

verses.textEn: He who has not given his money in usury, nor accepted bribes against the innocent. He who does these things will be undisturbed for eternity.
verses.textLa: qui pecuniam suam non dedit ad usuram, et munera super innocentem non accepit: Qui facit hæc, non movebitur in æternum.

verses.textEn: The inscription of a title: of David himself. Preserve me, O Lord, because I have hoped in you.
verses.textLa: Tituli inscriptio ipsi David. Conserva me Domine, quoniam speravi in te.

verses.textEn: I have said to the Lord: “You are my God, so you have no need of my goodness.”
verses.textLa: Dixi Domino: Deus meus es tu, quoniam bonorum meorum non eges.

verses.textEn: As for the saints, who are in his land: he has made all my desires wonderful in them.
verses.textLa: Sanctis, qui sunt in terra eius, mirificavit omnes voluntates meas in eis.

verses.textEn: Their infirmities have been multiplied; after this, they acted more quickly. I will not gather for their convocations of blood, nor will I remember their names with my lips.
verses.textLa: Multiplicatæ sunt infirmitates eorum: postea acceleraverunt. Non congregabo conventicula eorum de sanguinibus: nec memor ero nominum eorum per labia mea.

verses.textEn: The Lord is the portion of my inheritance and my cup. It is you who will restore my inheritance to me.
verses.textLa: Dominus pars hereditatis meæ, et calicis mei: tu es, qui restitues hereditatem meam mihi.

verses.textEn: The lots have fallen upon me with clarity. And, indeed, my inheritance has been very clear to me.
verses.textLa: Funes ceciderunt mihi in præclaris: etenim hereditas mea præclara est mihi.
verses.notes: The word ‘funes’ refers to a string or line or cord that is used in a manner similar to casting lots, to decide upon someone’s place or to decide upon future events.

verses.textEn: I will bless the Lord, who has bestowed understanding upon me. Moreover, my temperament has also corrected me, even through the night.
verses.textLa: Benedicam Dominum, qui tribuit mihi intellectum: insuper et usque ad noctem increpuerunt me renes mei.

verses.textEn: I have made provision for the Lord always in my sight. For he is at my right hand, so that I may not be disturbed.
verses.textLa: Providebam Dominum in conspectu meo semper: quoniam a dextris est mihi, ne commovear.

verses.textEn: Because of this, my heart has been joyful, and my tongue has exulted. Moreover, even my body will rest in hope.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc lætatum est cor meum, et exultavit lingua mea: insuper et caro mea requiescet in spe.

verses.textEn: For you will not abandon my soul to Hell, nor will you allow your holy one to see corruption.
verses.textLa: Quoniam non derelinques animam meam in inferno: nec dabis sanctum tuum videre corruptionem.

verses.textEn: You have made known to me the ways of life; you will fill me with joy by your countenance. At your right hand are delights, even to the end.
verses.textLa: Notas mihi fecisti vias vitæ, adimplebis me lætitia cum vultu tuo: delectationes in dextera tua usque in finem.

verses.textEn: A Prayer of David. Lord, listen to my justice, attend to my supplication. Pay attention to my prayer, which is not from deceitful lips.
verses.textLa: Oratio David. Exaudi Domine iustitiam meam: intende deprecationem meam. Auribus percipe orationem meam, non in labiis dolosis.

verses.textEn: Let my judgment proceed from your presence. Let your eyes behold fairness.
verses.textLa: De vultu tuo iudicium meum prodeat: oculi tui videant æquitates.

verses.textEn: You have tested my heart and visited it by night. You have examined me by fire, and iniquity has not been found in me.
verses.textLa: Probasti cor meum, et visitasti nocte: igne me examinasti, et non est inventa in me iniquitas.

verses.textEn: Therefore, may my mouth not speak the works of men. I have kept to difficult ways because of the words of your lips.
verses.textLa: Ut non loquatur os meum opera hominum: propter verba labiorum tuorum ego custodivi vias duras.

verses.textEn: Perfect my steps in your paths, so that my footsteps may not be disturbed.
verses.textLa: Perfice gressus meos in semitis tuis: ut non moveantur vestigia mea.

verses.textEn: I have cried out because you, O God, have listened to me. Incline your ear to me and heed my words.
verses.textLa: Ego clamavi, quoniam exaudisti me Deus: inclina aurem tuam mihi, et exaudi verba mea.

verses.textEn: Make your mercies wonderful, for you save those who hope in you.
verses.textLa: Mirifica misericordias tuas, qui salvos facis sperantes in te.

verses.textEn: From those who resist your right hand, preserve me like the pupil of your eye. Protect me under the shadow of your wings,
verses.textLa: A resistentibus dexteræ tuæ custodi me, ut pupillam oculi. Sub umbra alarum tuarum protege me:

verses.textEn: from the face of the impious who have afflicted me. My enemies have surrounded my soul.
verses.textLa: a facie impiorum qui me afflixerunt. Inimici mei animam meam circumdederunt,

verses.textEn: They have concealed their fatness; their mouth has been speaking arrogantly.
verses.textLa: adipem suum concluserunt: os eorum locutum est superbiam.

verses.textEn: They have cast me out, and now they have surrounded me. They have cast their eyes down to the earth.
verses.textLa: Proiicientes me nunc circumdederunt me: oculos suos statuerunt declinare in terram.
verses.notes: They look down on other people, even the whole world. They put on the mask of false humility, casting their eyes downward, as if humble, while they act with self-exaltation and condescension.

verses.textEn: They have taken me, like a lion ready for the prey, and like a young lion dwelling in hiding.
verses.textLa: Susceperunt me sicut leo paratus ad prædam: et sicut catulus leonis habitans in abditis.

verses.textEn: Rise up, O Lord, arrive before him and displace him. Deliver my soul from the impious one: your spear from the enemies of your hand.
verses.textLa: Exurge Domine, præveni eum, et supplanta eum: eripe animam meam ab impio, frameam tuam ab inimicis manus tuæ.

verses.textEn: Lord, divide them from the few of the earth in their life. Their gut has been filled from your hidden stores. They have been filled with sons, and they have bequeathed to their little ones the remainder.
verses.textLa: Domine a paucis de terra divide eos in vita eorum: de absconditis tuis adimpletus est venter eorum. Saturati sunt filiis: et dimiserunt reliquias suas parvulis suis.

verses.textEn: But as for me, I will appear before your sight in justice. I will be satisfied when your glory appears.
verses.textLa: Ego autem in iustitia apparebo conspectui tuo: satiabor cum apparuerit gloria tua.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For David, the servant of the Lord, who spoke the words of this canticle to the Lord, in the day that the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul. And he said:
verses.textLa: In finem, puero Domini David, qui locutus est Domino verba cantici huius, in die, qua eripuit eum Dominus de manu omnium inimicorum eius, et de manu Saul, et dixit:

verses.textEn: I will love you, O Lord my strength.
verses.textLa: Diligam te Domine fortitudo mea:

verses.textEn: The Lord is my firmament, my refuge, and my liberator. My God is my helper, and I hope in him: my protector, and the horn of my salvation, and my support.
verses.textLa: Dominus firmamentum meum, et refugium meum, et liberator meus. Deus meus adiutor meus, et sperabo in eum. Protector meus, et cornu salutis meæ, et susceptor meus.

verses.textEn: Praising, I will call upon the Lord. And I will be saved from my enemies.
verses.textLa: Laudans invocabo Dominum: et ab inimicis meis salvus ero.

verses.textEn: The sorrows of death surrounded me, and the torrents of iniquity dismayed me.
verses.textLa: Circumdederunt me dolores mortis: et torrentes iniquitatis conturbaverunt me.

verses.textEn: The sorrows of Hell encompassed me, and the snares of death intercepted me.
verses.textLa: Dolores inferni circumdederunt me: præoccupaverunt me laquei mortis.

verses.textEn: In my tribulation, I called upon the Lord, and I cried out to my God. And he listened to my voice from his holy temple. And my cry in his presence entered into his ears.
verses.textLa: In tribulatione mea invocavi Dominum, et ad Deum meum clamavi: et exaudivit de templo sancto suo vocem meam: et clamor meus in conspectu eius, introivit in aures eius.

verses.textEn: The earth was shaken, and it trembled. The foundations of the mountains were disturbed, and they were shaken, because he was angry with them.
verses.textLa: Commota est, et contremuit terra: fundamenta montium conturbata sunt, et commota sunt, quoniam iratus est eis.

verses.textEn: A smoke ascended by his wrath, and a fire flared up from his face: coals were kindled by it.
verses.textLa: Ascendit fumus in ira eius: et ignis a facie eius exarsit: carbones succensi sunt ab eo.

verses.textEn: He bent the heavens, and they descended. And darkness was under his feet.
verses.textLa: Inclinavit cælos, et descendit: et caligo sub pedibus eius.

verses.textEn: And he ascended upon the cherubim, and he flew: he flew upon the feathers of the winds.
verses.textLa: Et ascendit super cherubim, et volavit: volavit super pennas ventorum.

verses.textEn: And he set darkness as his hiding place, with his tabernacle all around him: dark waters in the clouds of the air.
verses.textLa: Et posuit tenebras latibulum suum, in circuitu eius tabernaculum eius: tenebrosa aqua in nubibus aeris.

verses.textEn: At the brightness that was before his sight, the clouds crossed by, with hail and coals of fire.
verses.textLa: Præ fulgore in conspectu eius nubes transierunt, grando et carbones ignis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord thundered from heaven, and the Most High uttered his voice: hail and coals of fire.
verses.textLa: Et intonuit de cælo Dominus, et Altissimus dedit vocem suam: grando et carbones ignis.

verses.textEn: And he sent forth his arrows and scattered them. He multiplied lightnings, and he set them in disarray.
verses.textLa: Et misit sagittas suas, et dissipavit eos: fulgura multiplicavit, et conturbavit eos.

verses.textEn: Then the fountains of waters appeared, and the foundations of the world were revealed, by your rebuke, O Lord, by the inspiration of the Spirit of your wrath.
verses.textLa: Et apparuerunt fontes aquarum, et revelata sunt fundamenta orbis terrarum: Ab increpatione tua Domine, ab inspiratione Spiritus iræ tuæ.

verses.textEn: He sent from on high, and he accepted me. And he took me up, out of many waters.
verses.textLa: Misit de summo, et accepit me: et assumpsit me de aquis multis.

verses.textEn: He rescued me from my strongest enemies, and from those who hated me. For they had been too strong for me.
verses.textLa: Eripuit me de inimicis meis fortissimis, et ab his qui oderunt me: quoniam confortati sunt super me.

verses.textEn: They intercepted me in the day of my affliction, and the Lord became my protector.
verses.textLa: Prævenerunt me in die afflictionis meæ: et factus est Dominus protector meus.

verses.textEn: And he led me out, into a wide place. He accomplished my salvation, because he willed me.
verses.textLa: Et eduxit me in latitudinem: salvum me fecit, quoniam voluit me.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘quoniam voluit me’ could be translated as ‘because he was pleased with me,’ or ‘because he wanted me,’ or ‘because he willed me.’ In terms of salvation theology, God does not save us because of us but because of Himself. Therefore, ‘because he willed me,’ is the better fit.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will reward me according to my justice, and he will repay me according to the purity of my hands.
verses.textLa: Et retribuet mihi Dominus secundum iustitiam meam, et secundum puritatem manuum mearum retribuet mihi:

verses.textEn: For I have preserved the ways of the Lord, and I have not behaved impiously before my God.
verses.textLa: Quia custodivi vias Domini, nec impie gessi a Deo meo.

verses.textEn: For all his judgments are in my sight, and his justice, I have not pushed away from me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam omnia iudicia eius in conspectu meo: et iustitias eius non repuli a me.

verses.textEn: And I will be immaculate together with him, and I will keep myself from my iniquity.
verses.textLa: Et ero immaculatus cum eo: et observabo me ab iniquitate mea.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will reward me according to my justice and according to the purity of my hands before his eyes.
verses.textLa: Et retribuet mihi Dominus secundum iustitiam meam: et secundum puritatem manuum mearum in conspectu oculorum eius.

verses.textEn: With the holy, you will be holy, and with the innocent, you will be innocent,
verses.textLa: Cum sancto sanctus eris, et cum viro innocente innocens eris:

verses.textEn: and with the elect, you will be elect, and with the perverse, you will be perverse.
verses.textLa: et cum electo electus eris: et cum perverso perverteris.

verses.textEn: For you will save the humble people, but you will bring down the eyes of the arrogant.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu populum humilem salvum facies: et oculos superborum humiliabis.

verses.textEn: For you illuminate my lamp, O Lord. My God, enlighten my darkness.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu illuminas lucernam meam Domine: Deus meus illumina tenebras meas.

verses.textEn: For in you, I will be delivered from temptation; and with my God, I will climb over a wall.
verses.textLa: Quoniam in te eripiar a tentatione, et in Deo meo transgrediar murum.

verses.textEn: As for my God, his way is undefiled. The eloquence of the Lord has been examined by fire. He is the protector of all who hope in him.
verses.textLa: Deus meus impolluta via eius: eloquia Domini igne examinata: protector est omnium sperantium in se.

verses.textEn: For who is God, except the Lord? And who is God, except our God?
verses.textLa: Quoniam quis Deus præter Dominum? aut quis Deus præter Deum nostrum?

verses.textEn: It is God who has wrapped me with virtue and made my way immaculate.
verses.textLa: Deus qui præcinxit me virtute: et posuit immaculatam viam meam.

verses.textEn: It is he who has perfected my feet, like the feet of deer, and who stations me upon the heights.
verses.textLa: Qui perfecit pedes meos tamquam cervorum, et super excelsa statuens me.

verses.textEn: It is he who trains my hands for battle. And you have set my arms like a bow of brass.
verses.textLa: Qui docet manus meas ad prælium: et posuisti, ut arcum æreum, brachia mea.

verses.textEn: And you have given me the protection of your salvation. And your right hand sustains me. And your discipline has corrected me unto the end. And your discipline itself will teach me.
verses.textLa: Et dedisti mihi protectionem salutis tuæ: et dextera tua suscepit me: Et disciplina tua correxit me in finem: et disciplina tua ipsa me docebit.
verses.notes: In most cases, ‘in finem’ means ‘in the end.’ In this context, perhaps the alternate translation of ‘in parts,’ also works. God does not wait until the end to correct, but He corrects in parts or in steps.

verses.textEn: You have expanded my footsteps under me, and my tracks have not been weakened.
verses.textLa: Dilatasti gressus meos subtus me: et non sunt infirmata vestigia mea:

verses.textEn: I will pursue my enemies and apprehend them. And I will not turn back until they have failed.
verses.textLa: Persequar inimicos meos, et comprehendam illos: et non convertar donec deficiant.

verses.textEn: I will break them, and they will not be able to stand. They will fall under my feet.
verses.textLa: Confringam illos, nec poterunt stare: cadent subtus pedes meos.

verses.textEn: And you have wrapped me with virtue for the battle. And those rising up against me, you have subdued under me.
verses.textLa: Et præcinxisti me virtute ad bellum: et supplantasti insurgentes in me subtus me.

verses.textEn: And you have given the back of my enemies to me, and you have destroyed those who hated me.
verses.textLa: Et inimicos meos dedisti mihi dorsum, et odientes me disperdidisti.
verses.notes: The word ‘dorsum’ can also refer to a downhill position (i.e. the less favorable position during a battle).

verses.textEn: They cried out, but there was none to save them, to the Lord, but he did not heed them.
verses.textLa: Clamaverunt, nec erat qui salvos faceret, ad Dominum: nec exaudivit eos.

verses.textEn: And I will crush them into dust before the face of the wind, so that I will obliterate them like the mud in the streets.
verses.textLa: Et comminuam eos, ut pulverem ante faciem venti: ut lutum platearum delebo eos.

verses.textEn: You will rescue me from the contradictions of the people. You will set me at the head of the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Eripies me de contradictionibus populi: constitues me in caput Gentium.

verses.textEn: A people I did not know has served me. As soon as their ears heard, they were obedient to me.
verses.textLa: Populus, quem non cognovi, servivit mihi: in auditu auris obedivit mihi.

verses.textEn: The sons of foreigners have been deceitful to me, the sons of foreigners have grown weak with time, and they have wavered from their paths.
verses.textLa: Filii alieni mentiti sunt mihi, filii alieni inveterati sunt, et claudicaverunt a semitis suis.

verses.textEn: The Lord lives, and blessed is my God, and may the God of my salvation be exalted:
verses.textLa: Vivit Dominus, et benedictus Deus meus, et exaltetur Deus salutis meæ.

verses.textEn: O God, who vindicates me and who subdues the people under me, my liberator from my enraged enemies.
verses.textLa: Deus qui das vindictas mihi, et subdis populos sub me, liberator meus de inimicis meis iracundis.

verses.textEn: And you will exalt me above those who rise up against me. From the iniquitous man, you will rescue me.
verses.textLa: Et ab insurgentibus in me exaltabis me: a viro iniquo eripies me.
verses.notes: Notice that the phrase ‘viro iniquo’ is translated using the word ‘man,’ but the word ‘iniquo’ by itself would be translated without the word ‘man.’

verses.textEn: Because of this, O Lord, I will confess to you among the nations, and I will compose a psalm to your name:
verses.textLa: Propterea confitebor tibi in nationibus Domine: et nomini tuo psalmum dicam,
verses.notes: The phrase ‘dicam psalmum’ can be translated as ‘I will recite a psalm,’ but such a translation would too weak for this context. The context is that of being vindicated and liberated from great harm, and of confessing to God among the nations of the world. Therefore, the phrase does not mean to merely recite a psalm, but to compose a psalm. (Composition in ancient times was probably most often done in spoken words, since most persons were illiterate and those who were literate did much less reading and writing than the average person today.)

verses.textEn: magnifying the salvation of his king, and showing mercy to David, his Christ, and to his offspring, even for all time.
verses.textLa: magnificans salutes regis eius, et faciens misericordiam christo suo David, et semini eius usque in sæculum.
verses.notes: The term ‘christo suo David’ refers to David, and the term ‘semini eius’ refers to Jesus Christ. However, references to David can often be taken as figurative references to Christ, because David was a foreshadowing of Christ, the son of David.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: The heavens describe the glory of God, and the firmament announces the work of his hands.
verses.textLa: Cæli enarrant gloriam Dei, et opera manuum eius annunciat firmamentum.

verses.textEn: Day proclaims the word to day, and night to night imparts knowledge.
verses.textLa: Dies diei eructat verbum, et nox nocti indicat scientiam.

verses.textEn: There are no speeches or conversations, where their voices are not being heard.
verses.textLa: Non sunt loquelæ, neque sermones, quorum non audiantur voces eorum.
verses.notes: These ‘loquelæ’ and ‘sermones’ are between the various parts of Creation, such as the days, the nights, the heavens, etc. It is not referring to literal conversations between people.

verses.textEn: Their sound has gone forth through all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.
verses.textLa: In omnem terram exivit sonus eorum: et in fines orbis terræ verba eorum.

verses.textEn: He has placed his tabernacle in the sun, and he is like a bridegroom coming out of his bedroom. He has exulted like a giant running along the way;
verses.textLa: In sole posuit tabernaculum suum: et ipse tamquam sponsus procedens de thalamo suo: Exultavit ut gigas ad currendam viam,

verses.textEn: his departure is from the summit of heaven. And his course reaches all the way to its summit. Neither is there anyone who can hide himself from his heat.
verses.textLa: a summo cælo egressio eius: Et occursus eius usque ad summum eius: nec est qui se abscondat a calore eius.

verses.textEn: The law of the Lord is immaculate, converting souls. The testimony of the Lord is faithful, providing wisdom to little ones.
verses.textLa: Lex Domini immaculata convertens animas: testimonium Domini fidele, sapientiam præstans parvulis.

verses.textEn: The justice of the Lord is right, rejoicing hearts. The precepts of the Lord are brilliant, enlightening the eyes.
verses.textLa: Iustitiæ Domini rectæ, lætificantes corda: præceptum Domini lucidum; illuminans oculos.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is holy, enduring for all generations. The judgments of the Lord are true, justified in themselves:
verses.textLa: Timor Domini sanctus, permanens in sæculum sæculi: iudicia Domini vera, iustificata in semetipsa.

verses.textEn: desirable beyond gold and many precious stones, and sweeter than honey and the honeycomb.
verses.textLa: Desiderabilia super aurum et lapidem pretiosum multum: et dulciora super mel et favum.

verses.textEn: For, indeed, your servant keeps them, and in keeping them, there are many rewards.
verses.textLa: Etenim servus tuus custodit ea, in custodiendis illis retributio multa.

verses.textEn: Who can understand transgression? From my hidden faults, cleanse me, O Lord,
verses.textLa: Delicta quis intelligit? ab occultis meis munda me:

verses.textEn: and from those of others, spare your servant. If they will have no dominion over me, then I will be immaculate, and I will be cleansed from the greatest transgression.
verses.textLa: et ab alienis parce servo tuo. Si mei non fuerint dominati, tunc immaculatus ero: et emundabor a delicto maximo.

verses.textEn: And the eloquence of my mouth will be so as to please, along with the meditation of my heart, in your sight, forever, O Lord, my helper and my redeemer.
verses.textLa: Et erunt ut complaceant eloquia oris mei: et meditatio cordis mei in conspectu tuo semper. Domine adiutor meus, et redemptor meus.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: May the Lord hear you in the day of tribulation. May the name of the God of Jacob protect you.
verses.textLa: Exaudiat te Dominus in die tribulationis: protegat te nomen Dei Iacob.

verses.textEn: May he send you help from the sanctuary and watch over you from Zion.
verses.textLa: Mittat tibi auxilium de sancto: et de Sion tueatur te.

verses.textEn: May he be mindful of all your sacrifices, and may your burnt-offerings be fat.
verses.textLa: Memor sit omnis sacrificii tui: et holocaustum tuum pingue fiat.

verses.textEn: May he grant to you according to your heart, and confirm all your counsels.
verses.textLa: Tribuat tibi secundum cor tuum: et omne consilium tuum confirmet.

verses.textEn: We will rejoice in your salvation, and in the name of our God, we will be magnified.
verses.textLa: Lætabimur in salutari tuo: et in nomine Dei nostri magnificabimur.

verses.textEn: May the Lord fulfill all your petitions. Now I know that the Lord has saved his Christ. He will hear him from his holy heaven. The salvation of his right hand is in his power.
verses.textLa: Impleat Dominus omnes petitiones tuas: nunc cognovi quoniam salvum fecit Dominus CHRISTUM suum. Exaudiet illum de cælo sancto suo: in potentatibus salus dexteræ eius.

verses.textEn: Some trust in chariots, and some in horses, but we will call upon the name of the Lord our God.
verses.textLa: Hi in curribus, et hi in equis: nos autem in nomine Domini Dei nostri invocabimus.

verses.textEn: They have been bound, and they have fallen. But we have risen up, and we have been set upright.
verses.textLa: Ipsi obligati sunt, et ceciderunt: nos autem surreximus et erecti sumus.

verses.textEn: O Lord, save the king, and hear us on the day that we will call upon you.
verses.textLa: Domine salvum fac regem: et exaudi nos in die, qua invocaverimus te.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: In your virtue, Lord, the king will rejoice, and over your salvation, he will exult exceedingly.
verses.textLa: Domine in virtute tua lætabitur rex: et super salutare tuum exultabit vehementer.

verses.textEn: You have granted him the desire of his heart, and you have not cheated him of the wish of his lips.
verses.textLa: Desiderium cordis eius tribuisti ei: et voluntate labiorum eius non fraudasti eum.

verses.textEn: For you have gone ahead of him with blessings of sweetness. You have placed a crown of precious stones on his head.
verses.textLa: Quoniam prævenisti eum in benedictionibus dulcedinis: posuisti in capite eius coronam de lapide pretioso.

verses.textEn: He petitioned you for life, and you have granted him length of days, in the present time, and forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Vitam petiit a te: et tribuisti ei longitudinem dierum in sæculum, et in sæculum sæculi.
verses.notes: This expression ‘in sæculum, et in sæculum sæculi’ refers both to the here and now on earth, and to eternity. So his prayer for long life is answered by a long life on earth in his own generation (in sæculum), and in eternity (in sæculum sæculi).

verses.textEn: Great is his glory in your salvation. Glory and great adornment, you will lay upon him.
verses.textLa: Magna est gloria eius in salutari tuo: gloriam et magnum decorem impones super eum.

verses.textEn: For you will give him as a blessing forever and ever. You will make him rejoice with gladness in your presence.
verses.textLa: Quoniam dabis eum in benedictionem in sæculum sæculi: lætificabis eum in gaudio cum vultu tuo.
verses.notes: He himself is given to the people as a blessing upon them. The text is not merely saying that he is given blessings, but that he is given as a blessing. The one given as a blessing is Christ, foreshadowed by David.

verses.textEn: Because the king hopes in the Lord, and in the mercy of the Most High, he will not be disturbed.
verses.textLa: Quoniam rex sperat in Domino: et in misericordia Altissimi non commovebitur.

verses.textEn: May your hand be found by all your enemies. May your right hand discover all those who hate you.
verses.textLa: Inveniatur manus tua omnibus inimicis tuis: dextera tua inveniat omnes, qui te oderunt.

verses.textEn: You will make them like an oven of fire, in the time of your presence. The Lord will stir them up with his wrath, and fire will devour them.
verses.textLa: Pones eos ut clibanum ignis in tempore vultus tui: Dominus in ira sua conturbabit eos, et devorabit eos ignis.

verses.textEn: You will destroy their fruit from the earth and their offspring from the sons of men.
verses.textLa: Fructum eorum de terra perdes: et semen eorum a filiis hominum.

verses.textEn: For they have turned evils upon you; they have devised plans, which they have not been able to accomplish.
verses.textLa: Quoniam declinaverunt in te mala; cogitaverunt consilia, quæ non potuerunt stabilire.

verses.textEn: For you will make them turn their back; with your remnants, you will prepare their countenance.
verses.textLa: Quoniam pones eos dorsum: in reliquiis tuis præparabis vultum eorum.
verses.notes: The first part of this verse is an idiomatic expression which refers to the back as a point of weakness, as in battle when one’s enemy turns their back to you. The second part of the verse uses ‘vultum’ to refer to the expression on their faces after God punishes them, i.e. to the effect of the punishment.

verses.textEn: Be exalted, Lord, by your own power. We will play music and sing psalms to your virtues.
verses.textLa: Exaltare Domine in virtute tua: cantabimus et psallemus virtutes tuas.
verses.notes: The word ‘psallemus’ can refer to playing a musical instrument or to singing psalms. The word ‘cantabimus’ can refer to singing songs or playing a musical instrument. The overall meaning of those two words used together, in this context, is to play musical instruments and to sing psalms or hymns to God.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the tasks of early morning. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro susceptione matutina, Psalmus David.
verses.notes: This psalm is about the time of early morning, metaphorically referring to the end of a dark time, and to the beginning of a time of light, when God saves at the end of suffering. It is also a fitting psalm for the start of the day.

verses.textEn: O God, my God, look upon me. Why have you forsaken me? Far from my salvation are the words of my offenses.
verses.textLa: Deus, Deus meus, respice in me: quare me dereliquisti? longe a salute mea verba delictorum meorum.

verses.textEn: My God, I will cry out by day, and you will not heed, and by night, and it will not be foolishness for me.
verses.textLa: Deus meus clamabo per diem, et non exaudies: et nocte, et non ad insipientiam mihi.

verses.textEn: But you dwell in holiness, O Praise of Israel.
verses.textLa: Tu autem in sancto habitas, Laus Israel.

verses.textEn: In you, our fathers have hoped. They hoped, and you freed them.
verses.textLa: In te speraverunt patres nostri: speraverunt, et liberasti eos.

verses.textEn: They cried out to you, and they were saved. In you, they hoped and were not confounded.
verses.textLa: Ad te clamaverunt, et salvi facti sunt: in te speraverunt, et non sunt confusi.

verses.textEn: But I am a worm and not a man: a disgrace among men, and an outcast of the people.
verses.textLa: Ego autem sum vermis, et non homo: opprobrium hominum, et abiectio plebis.

verses.textEn: All those who saw me have derided me. They have spoken with the lips and shook the head.
verses.textLa: Omnes videntes me, deriserunt me: locuti sunt labiis, et moverunt caput.

verses.textEn: He has hoped in the Lord, let him rescue him. Let him save him because he chooses him.
verses.textLa: Speravit in Domino, eripiat eum: salvum faciat eum, quoniam vult eum.

verses.textEn: For you are the one who has drawn me out of the womb, my hope from the breasts of my mother.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu es, qui extraxisti me de ventre: spes mea ab uberibus matris meæ.

verses.textEn: I have been thrown upon you from the womb; from the womb of my mother, you are my God.
verses.textLa: In te proiectus sum ex utero: de ventre matris meæ Deus meus es tu,

verses.textEn: Do not depart from me. For tribulation is near, since there is no one who may help me.
verses.textLa: ne discesseris a me: Quoniam tribulatio proxima est: quoniam non est qui adiuvet.

verses.textEn: Many calves have surrounded me; fat bulls have besieged me.
verses.textLa: Circumdederunt me vituli multi: tauri pingues obsederunt me.

verses.textEn: They have opened their mouths over me, just like a lion seizing and roaring.
verses.textLa: Aperuerunt super me os suum, sicut leo rapiens et rugiens.

verses.textEn: And so, I have been poured out like water, and all my bones have been scattered. My heart has become like wax, melting in the midst of my chest.
verses.textLa: Sicut aqua effusus sum: et dispersa sunt omnia ossa mea. Factum est cor meum tamquam cera liquescens in medio ventris mei.

verses.textEn: My strength has dried up like clay, and my tongue has adhered to my jaws. And you have pulled me down, into the dust of death.
verses.textLa: Aruit tamquam testa virtus mea, et lingua mea adhæsit faucibus meis: et in pulverem mortis deduxisti me.

verses.textEn: For many dogs have surrounded me. The council of the malicious has besieged me. They have pierced my hands and feet.
verses.textLa: Quoniam circumdederunt me canes multi: concilium malignantium obsedit me. Foderunt manus meas et pedes meos:

verses.textEn: They have numbered all my bones. And they have examined me and stared at me.
verses.textLa: dinumeraverunt omnia ossa mea. Ipsi vero consideraverunt et inspexerunt me:

verses.textEn: They divided my garments among them, and over my vestment, they cast lots.
verses.textLa: diviserunt sibi vestimenta mea, et super vestem meam miserunt sortem.

verses.textEn: But you, O Lord, do not take your help far from me; be attentive to my defense.
verses.textLa: Tu autem Domine ne elongaveris auxilium tuum a me: ad defensionem meam conspice.

verses.textEn: O God, rescue my soul from the spear, and my only one from the hand of the dog.
verses.textLa: Erue a framea Deus animam meam: et de manu canis unicam meam:

verses.textEn: Save me from the mouth of the lion, and my humility from the horns of the single-horned beast.
verses.textLa: Salva me ex ore leonis: et a cornibus unicornium humilitatem meam.
verses.notes:
The word ‘unicornium’ does not refer to the mythical horse with a single horn. It refers literally to some type of wild animal with one horn in ancient times. This animal is most likely some species that has since gone extinct. Some have speculated that it could refer to the rhinoceros of India (Rhinoceros unicornis), which has one horn, unlike its African cousin, which has two horns. It also has a figurative meaning. Notice that the first part of the verse refers to being saved by lions. It is not the case that the Israelites were largely afraid of being eaten by lions; rather, the lion is figurative for a king or for governmental authority. Save me from governmental authority gone astray. Likewise, save my humility from the horns of the single-horned beast. This beast could represent law enforcement and military bodies gone astray. Guns and tanks can be figuratively said to have a single horn, yet they shoot many horns (bullets, etc.) from their single horn. May I be humble in the face of law enforcement and military authorities gone astray.
 The single-horned beast can also be said to be a figure of the Antichrist’s kingdom. The figure of a horn is often used in the Old Testament to signify a leader of a kingdom. The Antichrist’s kingdom has a single horn, in the sense that he is one leader who will have dominion over nearly the whole world. And it has many horns, in that there are many other leaders who exercise authority under the Antichrist.

verses.textEn: I will declare your name to my brothers. In the midst of the Church, I will praise you.
verses.textLa: Narrabo nomen tuum fratribus meis: in medio ecclesiæ laudabo te.

verses.textEn: You who fear the Lord, praise him. All the offspring of Jacob, glorify him.
verses.textLa: Qui timetis Dominum laudate eum: universum semen Iacob glorificate eum:

verses.textEn: May all the offspring of Israel fear him. For he has neither spurned nor despised the pleas of the poor. Neither has he turned his face away from me. And when I cried out to him, he heeded me.
verses.textLa: Timeat eum omne semen Israel: quoniam non sprevit, neque despexit deprecationem pauperis: Nec avertit faciem suam a me: et cum clamarem ad eum exaudivit me.

verses.textEn: My praise is with you, within a great church. I will pay my vows in the sight of those who fear him.
verses.textLa: Apud te laus mea in ecclesia magna: vota mea reddam in conspectu timentium eum.

verses.textEn: The poor will eat and be satisfied, and those who yearn for the Lord will praise him. Their hearts will live forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Edent pauperes, et saturabuntur: et laudabunt Dominum qui requirunt eum: vivent corda eorum in sæculum sæculi.

verses.textEn: All the ends of the earth will remember, and they will be converted to the Lord. And all the families of the Gentiles will adore in his sight.
verses.textLa: Reminiscentur et convertentur ad Dominum universi fines terræ: Et adorabunt in conspectu eius universæ familiæ Gentium.

verses.textEn: For the kingdom belongs to the Lord, and he will have dominion over the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Domini est regnum: et ipse dominabitur Gentium.

verses.textEn: All the fat of the earth have gnashed their teeth, and they have adored. In his sight, they will fall down, all those who descend to the ground.
