verses.textLa: Manducaverunt et adoraverunt omnes pingues terræ: in conspectu eius cadent omnes qui descendunt in terram.

verses.textEn: And my soul will live for him, and my offspring will serve him.
verses.textLa: Et anima mea illi vivet: et semen meum serviet ipsi.

verses.textEn: There will be announced for the Lord a future generation, and the heavens will announce his justice to a people who will be born, whom the Lord has made.
verses.textLa: Annunciabitur Domino generatio ventura: et annunciabunt cæli iustitiam eius populo qui nascetur, quem fecit Dominus.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘quem fecit Dominus’ refers to the people whom the Lord has made (a future generation, not yet born), not to the justice. The word ‘justitiam’ is feminine, but the word ‘populo’ and the word ‘quem’ are each masculine.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. The Lord directs me, and nothing will be lacking to me.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David. Dominus regit me, et nihil mihi deerit:
verses.notes: The often quoted phrasing: “The Lord is my shepherd. I shall not want.” cannot be arrived at from the Latin. There is no mention of shepherd, but of the Lord guiding or directing. And the term ‘want’ is in the sense of ‘I shall not lack,’ not in the sense of ‘I shall not desire anything.’

verses.textEn: He has settled me here, in a place of pasture. He has led me out to the water of refreshment.
verses.textLa: in loco pascuæ ibi me collocavit. Super aquam refectionis educavit me:
verses.notes: The word ‘ibi’ generally means ‘there,’ but in this context, ‘here’ is a better fit. So, we start in a place of pasture, here. Then we go out to water of refreshment.

verses.textEn: He has converted my soul. He has led me away on the paths of justice, for the sake of his name.
verses.textLa: animam meam convertit. Deduxit me super semitas iustitiæ, propter nomen suum.
verses.notes: Next, we are led away on the path of righteousness, for the holy must go forth, out of safe pastures, to do the work of the Lord.

verses.textEn: For, even if I should walk in the midst of the shadow of death, I will fear no evils. For you are with me. Your rod and your staff, they have given me consolation.
verses.textLa: Nam, et si ambulavero in medio umbræ mortis, non timebo mala: quoniam tu mecum es. Virga tua, et baculus tuus: ipsa me consolata sunt.
verses.notes: On this journey of righteousness, we encounter danger and even the shadow of death. The rod and the staff, which give consolation, are the Sacraments of Confession (a rod of correction) and Communion (the bread of life is our staff for the journey of life). Notice that a word meaning ‘valley’ is not found in the Latin text.

verses.textEn: You have prepared a table in my sight, opposite those who trouble me. You have anointed my head with oil, and my cup, which inebriates me, how brilliant it is!
verses.textLa: Parasti in conspectu meo mensam, adversus eos, qui tribulant me. Impinguasti in oleo caput meum: et calix meus inebrians quam præclarus est!

verses.textEn: And your mercy will follow me all the days of my life, and so may I dwell in the house of the Lord for length of days.
verses.textLa: Et misericordia tua subsequetur me omnibus diebus vitæ meæ: et ut inhabitem in domo Domini, in longitudinem dierum.

verses.textEn: For the First Sabbath. A Psalm of David. The earth and all its fullness belong to the Lord: the whole world and all that dwells in it.
verses.textLa: Prima sabbati, Psalmus David. Domini est terra, et plenitudo eius: orbis terrarum, et universi, qui habitant in eo.
verses.notes: There are two First Sabbaths. The first of the First Sabbaths is the Sabbath during the Feast of Passover. After that Sabbath, the counting of the Feast of Weeks begins with the very next day. The first week in the counting of the Feast of Weeks ends with the second First Sabbath, that is, the First Sabbath in the count of Seven Sabbaths leading up to the Feast of Weeks. Because there was no clear concept of a number zero (which would, in modern counting be the first Sabbath of Passover), there must be two first Sabbaths.

verses.textEn: For he has founded it upon the seas, and he has prepared it upon the rivers.
verses.textLa: Quia ipse super maria fundavit eum: et super flumina præparavit eum.

verses.textEn: Who will ascend to the mountain of the Lord? And who will stand in his holy place?
verses.textLa: Quis ascendet in montem Domini? aut quis stabit in loco sancto eius?

verses.textEn: The innocent of hands and the clean of heart, who has not received his soul in vain, nor sworn deceitfully to his neighbor.
verses.textLa: Innocens manibus et mundo corde, qui non accepit in vano animam suam, nec iuravit in dolo proximo suo.

verses.textEn: He will receive a blessing from the Lord, and mercy from God, his Savior.
verses.textLa: Hic accipiet benedictionem a Domino: et misericordiam a Deo salutari suo.

verses.textEn: This is the generation that seeks him, that seeks the face of the God of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Hæc est generatio quærentium eum, quærentium faciem Dei Iacob.

verses.textEn: Lift up your gates, you princes, and be lifted up, eternal gates. And the King of Glory shall enter.
verses.textLa: Attollite portas principes vestras, et elevamini portæ æternales: et introibit Rex gloriæ.

verses.textEn: Who is this King of Glory? The Lord who is strong and powerful; the Lord powerful in battle.
verses.textLa: Quis est iste rex gloriæ? Dominus fortis et potens: Dominus potens in prælio.

verses.textEn: Lift up your gates, you princes, and be lifted up, eternal gates. And the King of Glory shall enter.
verses.textLa: Attollite portas principes vestras, et elevamini portæ æternales: et introibit Rex gloriæ.

verses.textEn: Who is this King of Glory? The Lord of virtue. He himself is the King of Glory.
verses.textLa: Quis est iste rex gloriæ? Dominus virtutum ipse est Rex gloriæ.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David. To you, Lord, I have lifted up my soul.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David. Ad te Domine levavi animam meam:

verses.textEn: In you, my God, I trust. Let me not be put to shame.
verses.textLa: Deus meus in te confido, non erubescam:

verses.textEn: And do not let my enemies laugh at me. For all who remain with you will not be confounded.
verses.textLa: Neque irrideant me inimici mei: etenim universi, qui sustinent te, non confundentur.

verses.textEn: May all those who act unjustly over nothing be confounded. O Lord, demonstrate your ways to me, and teach me your paths.
verses.textLa: Confundantur omnes iniqua agentes supervacue. Vias tuas Domine demonstra mihi: et semitas tuas edoce me.

verses.textEn: Direct me in your truth, and teach me. For you are God, my Savior, and I remain with you all day long.
verses.textLa: Dirige me in veritate tua, et doce me: quia tu es Deus salvator meus, et te sustinui tota die.

verses.textEn: O Lord, remember your compassion and your mercies, which are from ages past.
verses.textLa: Reminiscere miserationum tuarum Domine, et misericordiarum tuarum, quæ a sæculo sunt.
verses.notes: Or, ‘which are from time immemorial.’

verses.textEn: Do not remember the offenses of my youth and my ignorances. Remember me according to your mercy, because of your goodness, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Delicta iuventutis meæ, et ignorantias meas ne memineris. Secundum misericordiam tuam memento mei tu: propter bonitatem tuam Domine.

verses.textEn: The Lord is sweet and righteous. Because of this, he will grant a law to those who fall short in the way.
verses.textLa: Dulcis et rectus Dominus: propter hoc legem dabit delinquentibus in via.
verses.notes: Those who fall short in following the Way of Christ will be granted laws to help them along the way.

verses.textEn: He will direct the mild in judgment. He will teach the meek his ways.
verses.textLa: Diriget mansuetos in iudicio: docebit mites vias suas.

verses.textEn: All the ways of the Lord are mercy and truth, to those who yearn for his covenant and his testimonies.
verses.textLa: Universæ viæ Domini, misericordia et veritas, requirentibus testamentum eius et testimonia eius.

verses.textEn: Because of your name, O Lord, you will pardon my sin, for it is great.
verses.textLa: Propter nomen tuum Domine propitiaberis peccato meo: multum est enim.

verses.textEn: Which is the man who fears the Lord? He has established a law for him, on the way that he has chosen.
verses.textLa: Quis est homo qui timet Dominum? legem statuit ei in via, quam elegit.

verses.textEn: His soul will dwell upon good things, and his offspring will inherit the earth.
verses.textLa: Anima eius in bonis demorabitur: et semen eius hereditabit terram.

verses.textEn: The Lord is a firmament to those who fear him, and his covenant will be made manifest to them.
verses.textLa: Firmamentum est Dominus timentibus eum: et testamentum ipsius ut manifestetur illis.

verses.textEn: My eyes are ever toward the Lord, for he will pull my feet from the snare.
verses.textLa: Oculi mei semper ad Dominum: quoniam ipse evellet de laqueo pedes meos.

verses.textEn: Look upon me and have mercy on me; for I am alone and poor.
verses.textLa: Respice in me, et miserere mei: quia unicus et pauper sum ego.

verses.textEn: The troubles of my heart have been multiplied. Deliver me from my needfulness.
verses.textLa: Tribulationes cordis mei multiplicatæ sunt: de necessitatibus meis erue me.

verses.textEn: See my lowliness and my hardship, and release all my offenses.
verses.textLa: Vide humilitatem meam, et laborem meum: et dimitte universa delicta mea.

verses.textEn: Consider my enemies, for they have been multiplied, and they have hated me with an unjust hatred.
verses.textLa: Respice inimicos meos quoniam multiplicati sunt, et odio iniquo oderunt me.

verses.textEn: Preserve my soul and rescue me. I will not be ashamed, for I have hoped in you.
verses.textLa: Custodi animam meam, et erue me: non erubescam, quoniam speravi in te.

verses.textEn: The innocent and the righteous have adhered to me, because I have remained with you.
verses.textLa: Innocentes et recti adhæserunt mihi: quia sustinui te.

verses.textEn: Free Israel, O God, from all his tribulations.
verses.textLa: Libera Deus Israel ex omnibus tribulationibus suis.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David. Judge me, Lord, for I have been walking in my innocence, and by hoping in the Lord, I will not be weakened.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David. Iudica me Domine, quoniam ego in innocentia mea ingressus sum: et in Domino sperans non infirmabor.

verses.textEn: Examine me, Lord, and test me: enkindle my temperament and my heart.
verses.textLa: Proba me Domine, et tenta me: ure renes meos et cor meum.
verses.notes: Here again ‘renes’ literally means ‘kidneys,’ but is used metaphorically to refer to one’s temperament.

verses.textEn: For your mercy is before my eyes, and I am serene in your truth.
verses.textLa: Quoniam misericordia tua ante oculos meos est: et complacui in veritate tua.

verses.textEn: I have not sat with the council of emptiness, and I will not enter with those who carry out injustice.
verses.textLa: Non sedi cum concilio vanitatis: et cum iniqua gerentibus non introibo.

verses.textEn: I have hated the assembly of the malicious; and I will not sit with the impious.
verses.textLa: Odivi ecclesiam malignantium: et cum impiis non sedebo.

verses.textEn: I will wash my hands among the innocent, and I will surround your altar, O Lord,
verses.textLa: Lavabo inter innocentes manus meas: et circumdabo altare tuum Domine:

verses.textEn: so that I may hear the voice of your praise and describe all your wonders.
verses.textLa: Ut audiam vocem laudis, et enarrem universa mirabilia tua.

verses.textEn: O Lord, I have loved the beauty of your house and the dwelling place of your glory.
verses.textLa: Domine dilexi decorem domus tuæ, et locum habitationis gloriæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: O God, do not let my soul perish with the impious, nor my life with the men of blood,
verses.textLa: Ne perdas cum impiis Deus animam meam, et cum viris sanguinum vitam meam:

verses.textEn: in whose hands are iniquities: their right hand has been filled by bribes.
verses.textLa: In quorum manibus iniquitates sunt: dextera eorum repleta est muneribus.

verses.textEn: But as for me, I have been walking in my innocence. Redeem me, and have mercy on me.
verses.textLa: Ego autem in innocentia mea ingressus sum: redime me, et miserere mei.

verses.textEn: My foot has stood firm in the straight path. In the churches, I will bless you, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Pes meus stetit in directo: in ecclesiis benedicam te Domine.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David, before he was sealed. The Lord is my light and my salvation, whom shall I fear? The Lord is the protector of my life, of whom shall I be afraid?
verses.textLa: Psalmus David priusquam liniretur. Dominus illuminatio mea, et salus mea, quem timebo? Dominus protector vitæ meæ, a quo trepidabo?
verses.notes: Or, ‘before he was anointed.’ David is similar in many respects to the great monarch, who will receive the visible seal of God on his forehead, prior to beginning his reign as king of that vast territory formerly occupied by the Arab nations (led by Iraq and Iran).

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, the guilty draw near to me, so as to eat my flesh. Those who trouble me, my enemies, have themselves been weakened and have fallen.
verses.textLa: Dum appropiant super me nocentes, ut edant carnes meas: Qui tribulant me inimici mei, ipsi infirmati sunt et ceciderunt.

verses.textEn: If entrenched armies were to stand together against me, my heart would not fear. If a battle were to rise up against me, I would have hope in this.
verses.textLa: Si consistant adversum me castra, non timebit cor meum. Si exurgat adversum me prælium, in hoc ego sperabo.

verses.textEn: One thing I have asked of the Lord, this I will seek: that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life, so that I may behold the delight of the Lord, and may visit his temple.
verses.textLa: Unam petii a Domino, hanc requiram, ut inhabitem in domo Domini omnibus diebus vitæ meæ: Ut videam voluptatem Domini, et visitem templum eius.

verses.textEn: For he has hidden me in his tabernacle. In the day of evils, he has protected me in the hidden place of his tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Quoniam abscondit me in tabernaculo suo: in die malorum protexit me in abscondito tabernaculi sui.
verses.notes: During the latter half of the Antichrist’s reign (3.5 years), a part of the Church will be hidden from the world in a secret place.

verses.textEn: He has exalted me upon the rock, and now he has exalted my head above my enemies. I have circled around and offered a sacrifice of loud exclamation in his tabernacle. I will sing, and I will compose a psalm, to the Lord.
verses.textLa: In petra exaltavit me: et nunc exaltavit caput meum super inimicos meos. Circuivi, et immolavi in tabernaculo eius hostiam vociferationis: cantabo, et psalmum dicam Domino.
verses.notes: The word ‘vociferationis’ does not refer specifically to jubilation, but to a loud, even disruptive outcry, either of protest or of gladness. The Rock upon which he is exalted is the Church. This psalm is about David, who composed psalms to the Lord; therefore, the translation ‘compose a psalm’ is more fitting than merely ‘recite a psalm.’ Also, the word psalm is singular here. If the meaning were merely to recite rather than to compose, then the word psalm would likely be plural.

verses.textEn: Hear my voice, O Lord, with which I have cried out to you. Have mercy on me, and hear me.
verses.textLa: Exaudi Domine vocem meam, qua clamavi ad te: miserere mei, et exaudi me.

verses.textEn: My heart has spoken to you; my face has sought you. I yearn for your face, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Tibi dixit cor meum, exquisivit te facies mea: faciem tuam Domine requiram.

verses.textEn: Do not turn your face away from me. In your wrath, do not turn aside from your servant. Be my helper. Do not abandon me, and do not despise me, O God, my Savior.
verses.textLa: Ne avertas faciem tuam a me: ne declines in ira a servo tuo. Adiutor meus esto: ne derelinquas me, neque despicias me Deus salutaris meus.

verses.textEn: For my father and my mother have left me behind, but the Lord has taken me up.
verses.textLa: Quoniam pater meus, et mater mea dereliquerunt me: Dominus autem assumpsit me.

verses.textEn: O Lord, establish a law for me in your way, and direct me in the right path, because of my enemies.
verses.textLa: Legem pone mihi Domine in via tua: et dirige me in semitam rectam propter inimicos meos.

verses.textEn: Do not surrender me to the souls of those who trouble me. For unjust witnesses have risen up against me, and iniquity has lied to itself.
verses.textLa: Ne tradideris me in animas tribulantium me: quoniam insurrexerunt in me testes iniqui, et mentita est iniquitas sibi.

verses.textEn: I believe that I shall see the good things of the Lord in the land of the living.
verses.textLa: Credo videre bona Domini in terra viventium.

verses.textEn: Wait for the Lord, act manfully; and let your heart be strengthened, and remain with the Lord.
verses.textLa: Expecta Dominum, viriliter age: et confortetur cor tuum, et sustine Dominum.
verses.notes: Most translations obscure this male reference (‘viriliter’), or drop the phrase entirely. “... and if anyone takes away from the words in this prophetic book, God will take away his share in the tree of life and in the holy city described in this book.” (Rev 22:19). This translation does not omit or deliberately obscure gender-specific references in the words of Sacred Scripture.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. To you, Lord, I will cry out. My God, do not be silent toward me. For if you remain silent toward me, I will become like those who descend into the pit.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David. Ad te Domine clamabo, Deus meus ne sileas a me: ne quando taceas a me, et assimilabor descendentibus in lacum.

verses.textEn: Hear, O Lord, the voice of my supplication, when I pray to you, when I lift up my hands toward your holy temple.
verses.textLa: Exaudi Domine vocem deprecationis meæ dum oro ad te: dum extollo manus meas ad templum sanctum tuum.

verses.textEn: Do not draw me away together with sinners; and let me not perish with those who work iniquity, who speak peacefully to their neighbor, yet evils are in their hearts.
verses.textLa: Ne simul trahas me cum peccatoribus: et cum operantibus iniquitatem ne perdas me: Qui loquuntur pacem cum proximo suo, mala autem in cordibus eorum.

verses.textEn: Give to them according to their works and according to the wickedness of their inventions. Assign to them according to the works of their hands. Repay them with their own retribution.
verses.textLa: Da illis secundum opera eorum, et secundum nequitiam adinventionum ipsorum. Secundum opera manuum eorum tribue illis: redde retributionem eorum ipsis.

verses.textEn: Since they have not understood the works of the Lord and the works of his hands, you will destroy them, and you will not build them up.
verses.textLa: Quoniam non intellexerunt opera Domini, et in opera manuum eius destrues illos, et non ædificabis eos.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord, for he has heard the voice of my supplication.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus: quoniam exaudivit vocem deprecationis meæ.

verses.textEn: The Lord is my helper and my protector. In him, my heart has hoped and I have been helped. And my flesh has flourished again. And from my will, I shall confess to him.
verses.textLa: Dominus adiutor meus, et protector meus: in ipso speravit cor meum, et adiutus sum. Et refloruit caro mea: et ex voluntate mea confitebor ei.

verses.textEn: The Lord is the strength of his people and the protector of the salvation of his Christ.
verses.textLa: Dominus fortitudo plebis suæ: et protector salvationum Christi sui est.
verses.notes: The term ‘Christ’ in the Old Testament can refer to Jesus Christ and/or it can refer to one who is anointed and who foreshadows the Christ, such as David.

verses.textEn: O Lord, save your people and bless your inheritance, and reign over them and exalt them, even unto eternity.
verses.textLa: Salvum fac populum tuum Domine, et benedic hereditati tuæ: et rege eos, et extolle illos usque in æternum.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David, at the completion of the tabernacle. Bring to the Lord, O sons of God, bring to the Lord the sons of rams.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, In consummatione tabernaculi. Afferte Domino filii Dei: afferte Domino filios arietum:

verses.textEn: Bring to the Lord, glory and honor. Bring to the Lord, glory for his name. Adore the Lord in his holy court.
verses.textLa: Afferte Domino gloriam et honorem, afferte Domino gloriam nomini eius: adorate Dominum in atrio sancto eius.

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord is over the waters. The God of majesty has thundered. The Lord is over many waters.
verses.textLa: Vox Domini super aquas, Deus maiestatis intonuit: Dominus super aquas multas.

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord is in virtue. The voice of the Lord is in magnificence.
verses.textLa: Vox Domini in virtute: vox Domini in magnificentia.

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord shatters the cedars. And the Lord will shatter the cedars of Lebanon.
verses.textLa: Vox Domini confringentis cedros: et confringet Dominus cedros Libani:

verses.textEn: And it will break them into pieces, like a calf of Lebanon, and in the same way as the beloved son of the single-horned beast.
verses.textLa: Et comminuet eas tamquam vitulum Libani: et dilectus quemadmodum filius unicornium.

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord cuts through the flame of fire.
verses.textLa: Vox Domini intercidentis flammam ignis:

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord shakes the desert. And the Lord will quake the desert of Kadesh.
verses.textLa: vox Domini concutientis desertum: et commovebit Dominus desertum Cades.

verses.textEn: The voice of the Lord is preparing the stags, and he will reveal the dense woods. And in his temple, all will speak his glory.
verses.textLa: Vox Domini præparantis cervos, et revelabit condensa: et in templo eius omnes dicent gloriam.

verses.textEn: The Lord causes the great flood to dwell. And the Lord will sit as King in eternity.
verses.textLa: Dominus diluvium inhabitare facit: et sedebit Dominus Rex in æternum.
verses.notes: The great flood is a great flood of people who return to the Lord and who, thereafter, dwell with him.

verses.textEn: The Lord will give virtue to his people. The Lord will bless his people in peace.
verses.textLa: Dominus virtutem populo suo dabit: Dominus benedicet populo suo in pace.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm. In dedication to the house of David.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Cantici In dedicatione domus David.

verses.textEn: I will extol you, Lord, for you have sustained me, and you have not allowed my enemies to delight over me.
verses.textLa: Exaltabo te Domine quoniam suscepisti me: nec delectasti inimicos meos super me.

verses.textEn: O Lord my God, I have cried out to you, and you have healed me.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus meus clamavi ad te, et sanasti me.

verses.textEn: Lord, you led my soul away from Hell. You have saved me from those who descend into the pit.
verses.textLa: Domine eduxisti ab inferno animam meam: salvasti me a descendentibus in lacum.

verses.textEn: Sing a psalm to the Lord, you his saints, and confess with remembrance of his holiness.
verses.textLa: Psallite Domino sancti eius: et confitemini memoriæ sanctitatis eius.

verses.textEn: For wrath is in his indignation, and life is in his will. Toward evening, weeping will linger, and toward morning, gladness.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ira in indignatione eius: et vita in voluntate eius. Ad vesperum demorabitur fletus: et ad matutinum lætitia.

verses.textEn: But I have said in my abundance: “I will never be disturbed.”
verses.textLa: Ego autem dixi in abundantia mea: Non movebor in æternum.

verses.textEn: O Lord, in your will, you made virtue preferable to beauty for me. You turned your face away from me, and I became disturbed.
verses.textLa: Domine in voluntate tua, præstitisti decori meo virtutem. Avertisti faciem tuam a me, et factus sum conturbatus.

verses.textEn: To you, Lord, I will cry out. And I will make supplication to my God.
verses.textLa: Ad te Domine clamabo: et ad Deum meum deprecabor.

verses.textEn: What use would there be in my blood, if I descend into corruption? Will dust confess to you or announce your truth?
verses.textLa: Quæ utilitas in sanguine meo, dum descendo in corruptionem? Numquid confitebitur tibi pulvis, aut annunciabit veritatem tuam?

verses.textEn: The Lord has heard, and he has been merciful to me. The Lord has become my helper.
verses.textLa: Audivit Dominus, et misertus est mei: Dominus factus est adiutor meus.

verses.textEn: You have turned my mourning into gladness for me. You have cut off my sackcloth, and you have surrounded me with joy.
verses.textLa: Convertisti planctum meum in gaudium mihi: conscidisti saccum meum, et circumdedisti me lætitia:

verses.textEn: So then, may my glory sing to you, and may I not regret it. O Lord, my God, I will confess to you for eternity.
verses.textLa: Ut cantet tibi gloria mea: et non compungar: Domine Deus meus in æternum confitebor tibi.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David according to an ecstasy.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David, pro extasi.

verses.textEn: In you, Lord, I have hoped; let me never be confounded. In your justice, deliver me.
verses.textLa: In te Domine speravi non confundar in æternum: in iustitia tua libera me.

verses.textEn: Incline your ear to me. Hasten to rescue me. Be for me a protector God and a house of refuge, so as to accomplish my salvation.
verses.textLa: Inclina ad me aurem tuam, accelera ut eruas me. Esto mihi in Deum protectorem: et in domum refugii, ut salvum me facias.

verses.textEn: For you are my strength and my refuge; and for the sake of your name, you will lead me and nourish me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam fortitudo mea, et refugium meum es tu: et propter nomen tuum deduces me, et enutries me.

verses.textEn: You will lead me out of this snare, which they have hidden for me. For you are my protector.
verses.textLa: Educes me de laqueo hoc, quem absconderunt mihi: quoniam tu es protector meus.

verses.textEn: Into your hands, I commend my spirit. You have redeemed me, O Lord, God of truth.
verses.textLa: In manus tuas commendo spiritum meum: redemisti me Domine Deus veritatis.

verses.textEn: You have hated those who practice emptiness to no purpose. But I have hoped in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Odisti observantes vanitates, supervacue. Ego autem in Domino speravi:

verses.textEn: I will exult and rejoice in your mercy. For you have looked upon my humility; you have saved my soul from needfulness.
verses.textLa: exultabo, et lætabor in misericordia tua. Quoniam respexisti humilitatem meam, salvasti de necessitatibus animam meam.

verses.textEn: And you have not enclosed me in the hands of the enemy. You have set my feet in a spacious place.
verses.textLa: Nec conclusisti me in manibus inimici: statuisti in loco spatioso pedes meos.

verses.textEn: Have mercy on me, Lord, for I am troubled. My eye has been disturbed by wrath, along with my soul and my gut.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Domine quoniam tribulor: conturbatus est in ira oculus meus, anima mea, et venter meus:

verses.textEn: For my life has fallen into sorrow, and my years into sighing. My virtue has been weakened in poverty, and my bones have been disturbed.
verses.textLa: Quoniam defecit in dolore vita mea: et anni mei in gemitibus. Infirmata est in paupertate virtus mea: et ossa mea conturbata sunt.

verses.textEn: I have become a disgrace among all my enemies, and even more so to my neighbors, and a dread to my acquaintances. Those who catch sight of me, flee away from me.
verses.textLa: Super omnes inimicos meos factus sum opprobrium et vicinis meis valde: et timor notis meis. Qui videbant me, foras fugerunt a me:

verses.textEn: I have become forgotten, like one dead to the heart. I have become like a damaged utensil.
verses.textLa: oblivioni datus sum, tamquam mortuus a corde. Factus sum tamquam vas perditum:

verses.textEn: For I have heard the harsh criticism of many who linger in the area. While assembled together against me in that place, they deliberated on how to take away my life.
verses.textLa: quoniam audivi vituperationem multorum commorantium in circuitu: In eo dum convenirent simul adversum me, accipere animam meam consiliati sunt.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘commorantium in circuitu’ refers to people who are not living in the general area, but who have come to the area and are lingering there. The phrase ‘in eo’ refers to the phrase ‘in circuitu,’ i.e. it refers to a place, so it is translated loosely as ‘there,’ rather than as ‘in it.’

verses.textEn: But I have hoped in you, O Lord. I said, “You are my God.”
verses.textLa: Ego autem in te speravi Domine: dixi: Deus meus es tu:

verses.textEn: My fate is in your hands. Rescue me from the hand of my enemies and from those who are persecuting me.
verses.textLa: in manibus tuis sortes meæ. Eripe me de manu inimicorum meorum, et a persequentibus me.

verses.textEn: Shine your face upon your servant. Save me in your mercy.
verses.textLa: Illustra faciem tuam super servum tuum, salvum me fac in misericordia tua:

verses.textEn: Do not let me be confounded, Lord, for I have called upon you. Let the impious be ashamed and be drawn down into Hell.
verses.textLa: Domine non confundar, quoniam invocavi te. Erubescant impii, et deducantur in infernum:

verses.textEn: May deceitful lips be silenced: those that speak iniquity against the just, in arrogance and in abusiveness.
verses.textLa: muta fiant labia dolosa. Quæ loquuntur adversus iustum iniquitatem, in superbia, et in abusione.

verses.textEn: How great is the multitude of your sweetness, O Lord, which you keep hidden for those who fear you, which you have perfected for those who hope in you, in the sight of the sons of men.
verses.textLa: Quam magna multitudo dulcedinis tuæ Domine, quam abscondisti timentibus te. Perfecisti eis, qui sperant in te, in conspectu filiorum hominum.

verses.textEn: You hide them in the concealment of your face, from the disturbance of men. You protect them in your tabernacle, from the contradiction of tongues.
verses.textLa: Abscondes eos in abscondito faciei tuæ a conturbatione hominum. Proteges eos in tabernaculo tuo a contradictione linguarum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord. For he has shown his wonderful mercy to me, in a fortified city.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus: quoniam mirificavit misericordiam suam mihi in civitate munita.

verses.textEn: But I said in the excess of my mind: “I have been cast away from the glance of your eyes.” And so, you heeded the voice of my prayer, while I was still crying out to you.
verses.textLa: Ego autem dixi in excessu mentis meæ: Proiectus sum a facie oculorum tuorum. Ideo exaudisti vocem orationis meæ, dum clamarem ad te.

verses.textEn: Love the Lord, all you his saints. For the Lord will require truth, and he will abundantly repay those who act with arrogance.
verses.textLa: Diligite Dominum omnes sancti eius: quoniam veritatem requiret Dominus, et retribuet abundanter facientibus superbiam.

verses.textEn: Act manfully, and let your heart be strengthened, all you who hope in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Viriliter agite, et confortetur cor vestrum, omnes qui speratis in Domino.

verses.textEn: The understanding of David himself. Blessed are they whose iniquities have been forgiven and whose sins have been covered.
verses.textLa: Ipsi David intellectus. Beati, quorum remissæ sunt iniquitates: et quorum tecta sunt peccata.
verses.notes: Or, “The understanding of David to himself.” Or, “David’s own understanding.” This phrase has been often misunderstood. The word ‘intellectus’ is nominative, so it is the subject. The name David, and other non-Latin names written in Latin, often do not change their ending, despite being in various cases in various sentences. The word ‘David’ in this sentence is genitive (the understanding of David, or, David’s understanding). The word ‘ipsi’ is dative (to himself), but in English we would express this idea not by saying ‘The understanding of David to himself,’ but by saying, ‘The understanding of David himself.’ In other words, this psalm is about David’s own understanding. It is a psalm that describes things from David’s point of view.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord has not imputed sin, and in whose spirit there is no deceit.
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, cui non imputavit Dominus peccatum, nec est in spiritu eius dolus.

verses.textEn: Because I was silent, my bones grew old, while still I cried out all day long.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tacui, inveteraverunt ossa mea, dum clamarem tota die.

verses.textEn: For, day and night, your hand was heavy upon me. I have been converted in my anguish, while still the thorn is piercing.
verses.textLa: Quoniam die ac nocte gravata est super me manus tua: conversus sum in ærumna mea, dum configitur spina.

verses.textEn: I have acknowledged my offense to you, and I have not concealed my injustice. I said, “I will confess against myself, my injustice to the Lord,” and you forgave the impiety of my sin.
verses.textLa: Delictum meum cognitum tibi feci: et iniustitiam meam non abscondi. Dixi: Confitebor adversum me iniustitiam meam Domino: et tu remisisti impietatem peccati mei.

verses.textEn: For this, everyone who is holy will pray to you in due time. Yet truly, in a flood of many waters, they will not draw near to him.
verses.textLa: Pro hac orabit ad te omnis sanctus, in tempore opportuno. Verumtamen in diluvio aquarum multarum, ad eum non approximabunt.
verses.notes: A flood immediately precedes the reign of the Antichrist over the world. Those who repent before God will not draw near to him (the Antichrist) during that time.

verses.textEn: You are my refuge from the tribulation that has surrounded me. You are my exultation: rescue me from those who are surrounding me.
verses.textLa: Tu es refugium meum a tribulatione, quæ circumdedit me: exultatio mea erue me a circumdantibus me.

verses.textEn: I will give you understanding, and I will instruct you in this way, in which you will walk. I will fix my eyes upon you.
verses.textLa: Intellectum tibi dabo, et instruam te in via hac, qua gradieris: firmabo super te oculos meos.

verses.textEn: Do not become like the horse and the mule, which have no understanding. Their jaws are constrained with bit and bridle, so as not to draw near to you.
verses.textLa: Nolite fieri sicut equus et mulus, quibus non est intellectus. In camo et freno maxillas eorum constringe, qui non approximant ad te.

verses.textEn: Many are the scourges of the sinner, but mercy will surround him that hopes in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Multa flagella peccatoris, sperantem autem in Domino misericordia circumdabit.

verses.textEn: Rejoice in the Lord and exult, you just ones, and glory, all you upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Lætamini in Domino et exultate iusti, et gloriamini omnes recti corde.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. Exult in the Lord, you just ones; together praise the upright.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David. Exultate iusti in Domino: rectos decet collaudatio.

verses.textEn: Confess to the Lord with stringed instruments; sing psalms to him with the psaltery, the instrument of ten strings.
verses.textLa: Confitemini Domino in cithara: in psalterio decem chordarum psallite illi.

verses.textEn: Sing to him a new song. Sing psalms to him skillfully, with loud exclamation.
verses.textLa: Cantate ei canticum novum: bene psallite ei in vociferatione.

verses.textEn: For the word of the Lord is upright, and all his works are in faith.
verses.textLa: Quia rectum est verbum Domini, et omnia opera eius in fide.

verses.textEn: He loves mercy and judgment. The earth is full of the mercy of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Diligit misericordiam et iudicium: misericordia Domini plena est terra.

verses.textEn: By the word of the Lord, the heavens were established, and all their power, by the Spirit of his mouth:
verses.textLa: Verbo Domini cæli firmati sunt: et spiritu oris eius omnis virtus eorum.

verses.textEn: gathering together the waters of the sea, as if in a container, placing the depths in storage.
verses.textLa: Congregans sicut in utre aquas maris: ponens in thesauris abyssos.

verses.textEn: Let all the earth fear the Lord, and may all the inhabitants of the world quake before him.
verses.textLa: Timeat Dominum omnis terra: ab eo autem commoveantur omnes inhabitantes orbem.

verses.textEn: For he spoke, and they became. He commanded, and they were created.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ipse dixit, et facta sunt: ipse mandavit, et creata sunt.

verses.textEn: The Lord scatters the counsels of the nations. Moreover, he reproves the thoughts of the people, and he rejects the counsels of the leaders.
verses.textLa: Dominus dissipat consilia gentium: reprobat autem cogitationes populorum, et reprobat consilia principum.
verses.notes: Democracy is not necessarily good, nor does it necessarily please God.

verses.textEn: But the counsel of the Lord remains for eternity, the thoughts of his heart from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Consilium autem Domini in æternum manet: cogitationes cordis eius in generatione et generationem.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the nation whose God is the Lord, the people whom he has chosen as his inheritance.
verses.textLa: Beata gens, cuius est Dominus, Deus eius: populus, quem elegit in hereditatem sibi.

verses.textEn: The Lord has looked down from heaven. He has seen all the sons of men.
verses.textLa: De cælo respexit Dominus: vidit omnes filios hominum.

verses.textEn: From his well-prepared dwelling place, he has gazed upon all who dwell on the earth.
verses.textLa: De præparato habitaculo suo respexit super omnes, qui habitant terram.

verses.textEn: He has formed the hearts of each one of them; he understands all their works.
verses.textLa: Qui finxit sigillatim corda eorum: qui intelligit omnia opera eorum.

verses.textEn: The king is not saved by great power, nor will the giant be saved by his many powers.
verses.textLa: Non salvatur rex per multam virtutem: et gigas non salvabitur in multitudine virtutis suæ.

verses.textEn: The horse is false safety; for he will not be saved by the abundance of his powers.
verses.textLa: Fallax equus ad salutem: in abundantia autem virtutis suæ non salvabitur.

verses.textEn: Behold, the eyes of the Lord are on those who fear him and on those who hope in his mercy,
verses.textLa: Ecce oculi Domini super metuentes eum: et in eis, qui sperant super misericordia eius.

verses.textEn: so as to rescue their souls from death and to feed them during famine.
verses.textLa: Ut eruat a morte animas eorum: et alat eos in fame.

verses.textEn: Our soul remains with the Lord. For he is our helper and protector.
verses.textLa: Anima nostra sustinet Dominum: quoniam adiutor et protector noster est.

verses.textEn: For in him, our heart will rejoice, and in his holy name, we have hoped.
verses.textLa: Quia in eo lætabitur cor nostrum: et in nomine sancto eius speravimus.

verses.textEn: Let your mercy be upon us, O Lord, just as we have hoped in you.
verses.textLa: Fiat misericordia tua Domine super nos: quemadmodum speravimus in te.

verses.textEn: To David, when he changed his appearance in the sight of Abimelech, and so he dismissed him, and he went away.
verses.textLa: Davidi, cum immutavit vultum suum coram Achimelech, et dimisit eum et abiit.

verses.textEn: I will bless the Lord at all times. His praise will be ever in my mouth.
verses.textLa: Benedicam Dominum in omni tempore: semper laus eius in ore meo.

verses.textEn: In the Lord, my soul will be praised. May the meek listen and rejoice.
verses.textLa: In Domino laudabitur anima mea: audiant mansueti, et lætentur.

verses.textEn: Magnify the Lord with me, and let us extol his name in itself.
verses.textLa: Magnificate Dominum mecum: et exaltemus nomen eius in idipsum.

verses.textEn: I sought the Lord, and he heeded me, and he carried me away from all my tribulations.
verses.textLa: Exquisivi Dominum, et exaudivit me: et ex omnibus tribulationibus meis eripuit me.

verses.textEn: Approach him and be enlightened, and your faces will not be confounded.
verses.textLa: Accedite ad eum, et illuminamini: et facies vestræ non confundentur.

verses.textEn: This poor one cried out, and the Lord heeded him, and he saved him from all his tribulations.
verses.textLa: Iste pauper clamavit, et Dominus exaudivit eum: et de omnibus tribulationibus eius salvavit eum.

verses.textEn: The Angel of the Lord will encamp around those who fear him, and he will rescue them.
verses.textLa: Immittet angelus Domini in circuitu timentium eum: et eripiet eos.

verses.textEn: Taste and see that the Lord is sweet. Blessed is the man who hopes in him.
verses.textLa: Gustate, et videte quoniam suavis est Dominus: beatus vir, qui sperat in eo.

verses.textEn: Fear the Lord, all you his saints. For there is no destitution for those who fear him.
verses.textLa: Timete Dominum omnes sancti eius: quoniam non est inopia timentibus eum.

verses.textEn: The rich have been needy and hungry, but those who seek the Lord will not be deprived of any good thing.
verses.textLa: Divites eguerunt et esurierunt: inquirentes autem Dominum non minuentur omni bono.

verses.textEn: Come forward, sons. Listen to me. I will teach you the fear of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Venite filii, audite me: timorem Domini docebo vos.

verses.textEn: Which is the man who wills life, who chooses to see good days?
verses.textLa: Quis est homo qui vult vitam: diligit dies videre bonos?

verses.textEn: Prohibit your tongue from evil and your lips from speaking deceit.
verses.textLa: Prohibe linguam tuam a malo: et labia tua ne loquantur dolum.

verses.textEn: Turn away from evil, and do good. Inquire about peace, and pursue it.
verses.textLa: Diverte a malo, et fac bonum: inquire pacem, et persequere eam.

verses.textEn: The eyes of the Lord are on the just, and his ears are with their prayers.
verses.textLa: Oculi Domini super iustos: et aures eius in preces eorum.

verses.textEn: But the countenance of the Lord is upon those who do evil, to perish the remembrance of them from the earth.
verses.textLa: Vultus autem Domini super facientes mala: ut perdat de terra memoriam eorum.

verses.textEn: The just cried out, and the Lord heard them, and he freed them from all their tribulations.
verses.textLa: Clamaverunt iusti, et Dominus exaudivit eos: et ex omnibus tribulationibus eorum liberavit eos.

verses.textEn: The Lord is near to those who are troubled in heart, and he will save the humble in spirit.
verses.textLa: Iuxta est Dominus iis, qui tribulato sunt corde: et humiles spiritu salvabit.

verses.textEn: Many are the afflictions of the just, but from them all the Lord will free them.
verses.textLa: Multæ tribulationes iustorum: et de omnibus his liberabit eos Dominus.

verses.textEn: The Lord preserves all of their bones, not one of them shall be broken.
verses.textLa: Custodit Dominus omnia ossa eorum: unum ex his non conteretur.

verses.textEn: The death of a sinner is very harmful, and those who hate the just will fare badly.
verses.textLa: Mors peccatorum pessima: et qui oderunt iustum delinquent.
verses.notes: The death of an unrepentant sinner is a very bad thing, but those who hate the just will fare much worse. The word ‘pessima’ in this context does not mean morally bad, as if there were sin in dying itself, but it refers to something that is harmful, for there is great harm to oneself and to the world when someone dies without repenting.

verses.textEn: The Lord will redeem the souls of his servants, and none of those who hope in him will fare badly.
verses.textLa: Redimet Dominus animas servorum suorum: et non delinquent omnes qui sperant in eo.

verses.textEn: Of David himself. O Lord, judge those who harm me; assail those who attack me.
verses.textLa: Ipsi David. Iudica Domine nocentes me, expugna impugnantes me.
verses.notes: The expression ‘ipsi David’ indicates that this is David’s point of view. Or, ‘expunge those who impugn me.’

verses.textEn: Take hold of weapons and a shield, and rise up in assistance to me.
verses.textLa: Apprehende arma et scutum: et exurge in adiutorium mihi.

verses.textEn: Bring forth the spear, and close in on those who persecute me. Say to my soul, “I am your salvation.”
verses.textLa: Effunde frameam, et conclude adversus eos, qui persequuntur me: dic animæ meæ: Salus tua ego sum.

verses.textEn: Let them be confounded and in awe, who pursue my soul. Let them be turned back and be confounded, who think up evil against me.
verses.textLa: Confundantur et revereantur, quærentes animam meam. Avertantur retrorsum, et confundantur cogitantes mihi mala.

verses.textEn: May they become like dust before the face of the wind, and let the Angel of the Lord hem them in.
verses.textLa: Fiant tamquam pulvis ante faciem venti: et angelus Domini coarctans eos.

verses.textEn: May their way become dark and slippery, and may the Angel of the Lord pursue them.
verses.textLa: Fiat via illorum tenebræ et lubricum: et angelus Domini persequens eos.

verses.textEn: For, without cause, they have concealed their snare for me unto destruction. Over nothing, they have rebuked my soul.
verses.textLa: Quoniam gratis absconderunt mihi interitum laquei sui: supervacue exprobraverunt animam meam.

verses.textEn: Let the snare, of which he is ignorant, come upon him, and let the deception, which he has hidden, take hold of him: and may he fall into that very snare.
verses.textLa: Veniat illi laqueus, quem ignorat: et captio, quam abscondit, apprehendat eum: et in laqueum cadat in ipsum.

verses.textEn: But my soul will exult in the Lord and delight over his salvation.
verses.textLa: Anima autem mea exultabit in Domino: et delectabitur super salutari suo.

verses.textEn: All my bones will say, “Lord, who is like you?” He rescues the needy from the hand of the stronger one, the indigent and the poor from those who plunder him.
verses.textLa: Omnia ossa mea dicent: Domine, quis similis tibi? Eripiens inopem de manu fortiorum eius: egenum et pauperem a diripientibus eum.

verses.textEn: Unfair witnesses have risen up, interrogating me about things of which I am ignorant.
verses.textLa: Surgentes testes iniqui, quæ ignorabam interrogabant me.
verses.notes: Notice that in translation, the participle ‘surgentes’ becomes the main verb and the verb ‘interrogabant’ becomes a participle. Otherwise the sentence would be awkward in English and no more meaningful.

verses.textEn: They repaid me evil for good, to the deprivation of my soul.
verses.textLa: Retribuebant mihi mala pro bonis: sterilitatem animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: But as for me, when they were harassing me, I was clothed with haircloth. I humbled my soul with fasting, and my prayer will become my sinews.
verses.textLa: Ego autem cum mihi molesti essent, induebar cilicio. Humiliabam in ieiunio animam meam: et oratio mea in sinu meo convertetur.

verses.textEn: Like a neighbor, and like our brother, so did I please; like one mourning and contrite, so was I humbled.
verses.textLa: Quasi proximum, et quasi fratrem nostrum, sic complacebam: quasi lugens et contristatus sic humiliabar.

verses.textEn: And they have been joyful against me, and they joined together. Scourges have been gathered over me, and I was ignorant of it.
verses.textLa: Et adversum me lætati sunt, et convenerunt: congregata sunt super me flagella, et ignoravi.

verses.textEn: They have been scattered, yet they were unremorseful. They have tested me. They scoffed at me with scorn. They gnashed their teeth over me.
verses.textLa: Dissipati sunt, nec compuncti, tentaverunt me, subsannaverunt me subsannatione: frenduerunt super me dentibus suis.

verses.textEn: Lord, when will you look down upon me? Restore my soul from before their malice, my only one from before the lions.
verses.textLa: Domine quando respicies? restitue animam meam a malignitate eorum, a leonibus unicam meam.

verses.textEn: I will confess to you in a great Church. I will praise you among a weighty people.
verses.textLa: Confitebor tibi in Ecclesia magna, in populo gravi laudabo te.

verses.textEn: May those who are my unjust adversaries not be glad over me: those who have hated me without cause, and who nod agreement with their eyes.
verses.textLa: Non supergaudeant mihi qui adversantur mihi inique: qui oderunt me gratis et annuunt oculis.
verses.notes: Literally, this last phrase means ‘to nod (in agreement) with the eyes.’

verses.textEn: For indeed, they spoke peacefully to me; and speaking with passion to the earth, they intended deceit.
verses.textLa: Quoniam mihi quidem pacifice loquebantur: et in iracundia terræ loquentes, dolos cogitabant.

verses.textEn: And they opened their mouth wide over me. They said, “Well, well, our eyes have seen.”
verses.textLa: Et dilataverunt super me os suum: dixerunt: Euge, euge, viderunt oculi nostri.

verses.textEn: You have seen, O Lord, do not be silent. Lord, do not depart from me.
verses.textLa: Vidisti Domine, ne sileas: Domine ne discedas a me.

verses.textEn: Rise up and be attentive to my judgment, to my cause, my God and my Lord.
verses.textLa: Exurge et intende iudicio meo: Deus meus, et Dominus meus in causam meam.

verses.textEn: Judge me according to your justice, O Lord, my God, and do not let them be glad over me.
verses.textLa: Iudica me secundum iustitiam tuam Domine Deus meus, et non supergaudeant mihi.

verses.textEn: Do not let them say in their hearts, “Well, well, to our soul.” Neither let them say, “We have devoured him.”
verses.textLa: Non dicant in cordibus suis: Euge, euge, animæ nostræ: nec dicant: Devoravimus eum.

verses.textEn: Let them blush and be in awe together, those who congratulate at my misfortunes. Let them be clothed with confusion and awe, who speak great things against me.
verses.textLa: Erubescant et revereantur simul, qui gratulantur malis meis. Induantur confusione et reverentia qui magna loquuntur super me.

verses.textEn: Let them exult and rejoice, who wish my justice, and let them ever say, “The Lord be magnified,” who will the peace of his servant.
verses.textLa: Exultent et lætentur qui volunt iustitiam meam: et dicant semper: Magnificetur Dominus, qui volunt pacem servi eius.

verses.textEn: And so my tongue will express your justice: your praise all day long.
verses.textLa: Et lingua mea meditabitur iustitiam tuam, tota die laudem tuam.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. To the servant of the Lord, David himself.
verses.textLa: In finem, servo Domini ipsi David.

verses.textEn: The unjust one has said within himself that he would commit offenses. There is no fear of God before his eyes.
verses.textLa: Dixit iniustus ut delinquat in semetipso: non est timor Dei ante oculos eius.

verses.textEn: For he has acted deceitfully in his sight, such that his iniquity will be found to be hatred.
verses.textLa: Quoniam dolose egit in conspectu eius: ut inveniatur iniquitas eius ad odium.

verses.textEn: The words of his mouth are iniquity and deceit. He is unwilling to understand, so that he may act well.
verses.textLa: Verba oris eius iniquitas, et dolus: noluit intelligere ut bene ageret.

verses.textEn: He has been considering iniquity on his bed. He has set himself on every way that is not good; moreover, he has not hated evil.
verses.textLa: Iniquitatem meditatus est in cubili suo: astitit omni viæ non bonæ, malitiam autem non odivit.

verses.textEn: Lord, your mercy is in heaven, and your truth is even to the clouds.
verses.textLa: Domine in cælo misericordia tua: et veritas tua usque ad nubes.

verses.textEn: Your justice is like the mountains of God. Your judgments are a great abyss. Men and beasts, you will save, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Iustitia tua sicut montes Dei: iudicia tua abyssus multa. Homines, et iumenta salvabis Domine:

verses.textEn: How you have multiplied your mercy, O God! And so the sons of men will hope under the cover of your wings.
verses.textLa: quemadmodum multiplicasti misericordiam tuam Deus. Filii autem hominum, in tegmine alarum tuarum sperabunt.

verses.textEn: They will be inebriated with the fruitfulness of your house, and you will give them to drink from the torrent of your enjoyment.
verses.textLa: Inebriabuntur ab ubertate domus tuæ: et torrente voluptatis tuæ potabis eos.

verses.textEn: For with you is the fountain of life; and within your light, we will see the light.
verses.textLa: Quoniam apud te est fons vitæ: et in lumine tuo videbimus lumen.

verses.textEn: Extend your mercy before those who know you, and your justice to these, who are upright in heart.
verses.textLa: Prætende misericordiam tuam scientibus te, et iustitiam tuam his, qui recto sunt corde.

verses.textEn: May arrogant feet not approach me, and may the hand of the sinner not disturb me.
verses.textLa: Non veniat mihi pes superbiæ: et manus peccatoris non moveat me.
verses.notes: Notice that the word ‘pes’ is singular, but the translation makes it plural. The reason is that English uses this same type of expression (referring to feet figuratively), but with the plural, not the singular.

verses.textEn: In that place, those who work iniquity have fallen. They have been expelled; they were not able to stand.
verses.textLa: Ibi ceciderunt qui operantur iniquitatem: expulsi sunt, nec potuerunt stare.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. Do not choose to imitate the malicious; neither should you envy those who work iniquity.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David. Noli æmulari in malignantibus: neque zelaveris facientes iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: For they will quickly wither away like dry grass, and in like manner to kitchen herbs, they will soon droop.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tamquam fœnum velociter arescent: et quemadmodum olera herbarum cito decident.
verses.notes: The word ‘foenum’ is usually translated as ‘hay,’ but it can refer to any type of crop or grass that is cut and dried, or to dry grass in the field. The word ‘olera’ refers to vegetables or herbs for use in a kitchen; so, as a phrase, ‘olera herbarum’ refers to herb that are for use in cooking: ‘kitchen herbs.’ These last dry out and droop easily, because they are delicate plants (often grown indoors).

verses.textEn: Hope in the Lord and do good, and dwell in the land, and so you shall be pastured with its riches.
verses.textLa: Spera in Domino, et fac bonitatem: et inhabita terram, et pasceris in divitiis eius.

verses.textEn: Delight in the Lord, and he will grant to you the petitions of your heart.
verses.textLa: Delectare in Domino: et dabit tibi petitiones cordis tui.

verses.textEn: Reveal your way to the Lord, and hope in him, and he will accomplish it.
verses.textLa: Revela Domino viam tuam, et spera in eo: et ipse faciet.

verses.textEn: And he will bring forth your justice like the light, and your judgment like the midday.
verses.textLa: Et educet quasi lumen iustitiam tuam: et iudicium tuum tamquam meridiem:

verses.textEn: Be subject to the Lord and pray to him. Do not choose to compete with him who prospers in his way, with the man who does injustice.
verses.textLa: subditus esto Domino, et ora eum. Noli æmulari in eo, qui prosperatur in via sua: in homine faciente iniustitias.

verses.textEn: Cease from wrath and leave behind rage. Do not choose to imitate the malicious.
verses.textLa: Desine ab ira, et derelinque furorem: noli æmulari ut maligneris.

verses.textEn: For those who are malicious will be exterminated. But those who remain with the Lord, these will inherit the land.
verses.textLa: Quoniam qui malignantur, exterminabuntur: sustinentes autem Dominum, ipsi hereditabunt terram.

verses.textEn: Yet still a little while, and the sinner will not be. And you will search his place and find nothing.
verses.textLa: Et adhuc pusillum, et non erit peccator: et quæres locum eius, et non invenies.

verses.textEn: But the meek shall inherit the earth, and they will delight in the multitude of peace.
verses.textLa: Mansueti autem hereditabunt terram, et delectabuntur in multitudine pacis.

verses.textEn: The sinner will observe the just, and he will gnash his teeth over him.
verses.textLa: Observabit peccator iustum: et stridebit super eum dentibus suis.

verses.textEn: But the Lord will laugh at him: for he knows in advance that his day will come.
verses.textLa: Dominus autem irridebit eum: quoniam prospicit quod veniet dies eius.

verses.textEn: The sinners have drawn the sword, they have bent their bow, so as to cast down the poor and the needy, so as to massacre the upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Gladium evaginaverunt peccatores: intenderunt arcum suum. Ut deiiciant pauperem et inopem: ut trucident rectos corde.

verses.textEn: Let their sword enter into their own hearts, and let their bow be broken.
verses.textLa: Gladius eorum intret in corda ipsorum: et arcus eorum confringatur.

verses.textEn: A little is better to the just than the many riches of sinners.
verses.textLa: Melius est modicum iusto, super divitias peccatorum multas.

verses.textEn: For the arms of sinners will be crushed, but the Lord confirms the just.
verses.textLa: Quoniam brachia peccatorum conterentur: confirmat autem iustos Dominus.

verses.textEn: The Lord knows the days of the immaculate, and their inheritance will be in eternity.
verses.textLa: Novit Dominus dies immaculatorum: et hereditas eorum in æternum erit.

verses.textEn: They will not be confounded in an evil time; and in days of famine, they will be satisfied:
verses.textLa: Non confundentur in tempore malo, et in diebus famis saturabuntur:

verses.textEn: for sinners will perish. Truly, the adversaries of the Lord, soon after they have been honored and exalted, will fade away, in the same way that smoke fades away.
verses.textLa: quia peccatores peribunt. Inimici vero Domini mox ut honorificati fuerint et exaltati: deficientes, quemadmodum fumus deficient.

verses.textEn: The sinner will lend and not release, but the just one shows compassion and donates.
verses.textLa: Mutuabitur peccator, et non solvet: iustus autem miseretur et tribuet.
verses.notes: Or, ‘The sinner borrows and does not repay.’ The words ‘Mutuabitur’ and ‘solvet’ seem to indicate lending and releasing from debit. But based on the meaning of the remainder of the sentence, other translators have translated the text as ‘borrow’ and ‘repay.’

verses.textEn: For those who bless him will inherit the earth, but those who curse him will perish.
verses.textLa: Quia benedicentes ei hereditabunt terram: maledicentes autem ei disperibunt.

verses.textEn: The steps of a man will be directed by the Lord, and he will choose his way.
verses.textLa: Apud Dominum gressus hominis dirigentur: et viam eius volet.

verses.textEn: When he falls, he will not be harmed, because the Lord places his hand under him.
verses.textLa: Cum ceciderit, non collidetur: quia Dominus supponit manum suam.

verses.textEn: I have been young, and now I am old; and I have not seen the just forsaken, nor his offspring seeking bread.
verses.textLa: Iunior fui, etenim senui: et non vidi iustum derelictum, nec semen eius quærens panem.

verses.textEn: He shows compassion and lends, all day long, and his offspring will be in blessing.
verses.textLa: Tota die miseretur et commodat: et semen illius in benedictione erit.
verses.notes: The word ‘miseretur’ refers to showing mercy, or compassion, or pity for someone.

verses.textEn: Turn away from evil and do good, and dwell forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Declina a malo, et fac bonum: et inhabita in sæculum sæculi.

verses.textEn: For the Lord loves judgment, and he will not abandon his saints. They will be kept safe in eternity. The unjust will be punished, and the offspring of the impious will perish.
verses.textLa: Quia Dominus amat iudicium, et non derelinquet sanctos suos: in æternum conservabuntur. Iniusti punientur: et semen impiorum peribit.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘offspring of,’ or ‘sons of,’ is a figure of speech often used in the Old Testament. It does not literally mean that a child will perish if his parents sin. It means that if you sin continually, you are acting as if you were the offspring of sin. Thus, ‘semen impiorum peribit’ could be translated as ‘the offspring of impiety will perish.’ In another example, the ‘sons of adultery’ are not the biological sons of adulterers, but they are those who act as if they had adultery itself as a parent. This figure of speech is predicated on the idea that children learn most from their parents. If you commit adultery, it is as if your parents were adulterers, or as if your parent was adultery itself.

verses.textEn: But the just will inherit the earth, and they will dwell upon it forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Iusti autem hereditabunt terram: et inhabitabunt in sæculum sæculi super eam.

verses.textEn: The mouth of the just one will express wisdom, and his tongue will speak judgment.
verses.textLa: Os iusti meditabitur sapientiam, et lingua eius loquetur iudicium.

verses.textEn: The law of his God is in his heart, and his steps shall not be supplanted.
verses.textLa: Lex Dei eius in corde ipsius: et non supplantabuntur gressus eius.

verses.textEn: The sinner considers the just one and seeks to put him to death.
verses.textLa: Considerat peccator iustum: et quærit mortificare eum.

verses.textEn: But the Lord will not abandon him into his hands, nor condemn him, when he will be judged.
verses.textLa: Dominus autem non derelinquet eum in manibus eius: nec damnabit eum cum iudicabitur illi.

verses.textEn: Wait for the Lord, and keep to his way. And he will exalt you, so as to inherit the land that you may seize. When the sinners will have passed away, then you shall see.
verses.textLa: Expecta Dominum, et custodi viam eius: et exaltabit te ut hereditate capias terram: cum perierint peccatores videbis.
verses.notes: The word ‘capias’ is in the Clementine Vulgate, but it’s translation is not found in the Wycliffe, Douay, or Challoner versions. The word ‘capias’ refers to the land that the just ‘seize’ when the sinners pass away.

verses.textEn: I have seen the impious over-exalted, and lifted up like the cedars of Lebanon.
verses.textLa: Vidi impium superexaltatum, et elevatum sicut cedros Libani.

verses.textEn: And I passed by, and behold, he was not. And I sought him, and his place was not found.
verses.textLa: Et transivi, et ecce non erat: et quæsivi eum, et non est inventus locus eius.

verses.textEn: Keep to innocence, and gaze upon fairness: because there are allotments for the peaceful man.
verses.textLa: Custodi innocentiam, et vide æquitatem: quoniam sunt reliquiæ homini pacifico.
verses.notes: In this context, the word ‘reliquiae’ could be accurately translated as ‘bequests,’ or ‘bestowals,’ or ‘bequeathments,’ or ‘endowments,’ or ‘allotments.’

verses.textEn: But the unjust will be destroyed together: the allotments of the impious will pass away.
verses.textLa: Iniusti autem disperibunt simul: reliquiæ impiorum interibunt.
verses.notes: The word ‘interibunt’ literally means ‘they will go between.’ This was an expression used to refer to going between this life and the next, i.e. passing away or crossing over. People still sometimes say that someone has ‘passed between the veil of this life and the next.’

verses.textEn: But the salvation of the just is from the Lord, and he is their protector in time of tribulation.
verses.textLa: Salus autem iustorum a Domino: et protector eorum in tempore tribulationis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will help them and free them. And he will rescue them from sinners and save them, because they have hoped in him.
verses.textLa: Et adiuvabit eos Dominus, et liberabit eos: et eruet eos a peccatoribus, et salvabit eos: quia speraverunt in eo.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David, in commemoration of the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, in rememorationem de Sabbato.

verses.textEn: O Lord, do not rebuke me in your fury, nor chastise me in your wrath.
verses.textLa: Domine ne in furore tuo arguas me, neque in ira tua corripias me.

verses.textEn: For your arrows have been driven into me, and your hand has been confirmed over me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam sagittæ tuæ infixæ sunt mihi: et confirmasti super me manum tuam.

verses.textEn: There is no health in my flesh before the face of your wrath. There is no peace for my bones before the face of my sins.
verses.textLa: Non est sanitas in carne mea a facie iræ tuæ: non est pax ossibus meis a facie peccatorum meorum.

verses.textEn: For my iniquities have walked over my head, and they have been like a heavy burden weighing upon me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam iniquitates meæ supergressæ sunt caput meum: et sicut onus grave gravatæ sunt super me.

verses.textEn: My sores have putrefied and been corrupted before the face of my foolishness.
verses.textLa: Putruerunt et corruptæ sunt cicatrices meæ, a facie insipientiæ meæ.

verses.textEn: I have become miserable, and I have been bent down, even to the end. I have walked with contrition all day long.
verses.textLa: Miser factus sum, et curvatus sum usque in finem: tota die contristatus ingrediebar.

verses.textEn: For my loins have been filled with illusions, and there is no health in my flesh.
verses.textLa: Quoniam lumbi mei impleti sunt illusionibus: et non est sanitas in carne mea.

verses.textEn: I have been afflicted and greatly humbled. I bellowed from the groaning of my heart.
verses.textLa: Afflictus sum, et humiliatus sum nimis: rugiebam a gemitu cordis mei.

verses.textEn: O Lord, all my desire is before you, and my groaning before you has not been hidden.
verses.textLa: Domine, ante te omne desiderium meum: et gemitus meus a te non est absconditus.

verses.textEn: My heart has been disturbed. My strength has abandoned me, and the light of my eyes has abandoned me, and it is not with me.
verses.textLa: Cor meum conturbatum est: dereliquit me virtus mea, et lumen oculorum meorum: et ipsum non est mecum.
verses.notes: The verb for ‘lumen oculorum meorum’ is the same as the verb for the previous phrase, ‘dereliquit me virtus mea.’ This grammatical arrangement is common in Biblical Latin. The word ‘ipsum’ is nominative singular neuter, just as lumen is nominative singular neuter; therefore, ipsum refers to ‘lumen.’

verses.textEn: My friends and my neighbors have drawn near and stood against me. And those who were next to me stood far apart. And those who sought my soul used violence.
verses.textLa: Amici mei et proximi mei adversum me appropinquaverunt, et steterunt. Et qui iuxta me erant, de longe steterunt: et vim faciebant qui quærebant animam meam.

verses.textEn: And those who sought evil accusations against me were speaking emptiness. And they practiced deceitfulness all day long.
verses.textLa: Et qui inquirebant mala mihi, locuti sunt vanitates: et dolos tota die meditabantur.

verses.textEn: But, like someone deaf, I did not hear. And I was like someone mute, not opening his mouth.
verses.textLa: Ego autem tamquam surdus non audiebam: et sicut mutus non aperiens os suum.

verses.textEn: And I became like a man who does not hear, and who has no reproofs in his mouth.
verses.textLa: Et factus sum sicut homo non audiens: et non habens in ore suo redargutiones.

verses.textEn: For in you, Lord, I have hoped. You will listen to me, O Lord my God.
verses.textLa: Quoniam in te Domine speravi: tu exaudies me Domine Deus meus.

verses.textEn: For I said, “Lest at any time, my enemies might rejoice over me,” and, “While my feet are being shaken, they have spoken great things against me.”
verses.textLa: Quia dixi: Nequando supergaudeant mihi inimici mei: et dum commoventur pedes mei, super me magna locuti sunt.

verses.textEn: For I have been prepared for scourges, and my sorrow is ever before me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ego in flagella paratus sum: et dolor meus in conspectu meo semper.

verses.textEn: For I will announce my iniquity, and I will think about my sin.
verses.textLa: Quoniam iniquitatem meam annuntiabo: et cogitabo pro peccato meo.

verses.textEn: But my enemies live, and they have been stronger than me. And those who have wrongfully hated me have been multiplied.
verses.textLa: Inimici autem mei vivunt, et confirmati sunt super me: et multiplicati sunt qui oderunt me inique.

verses.textEn: Those who render evil for good have dragged me down, because I followed goodness.
verses.textLa: Qui retribuunt mala pro bonis, detrahebant mihi: quoniam sequebar bonitatem.

verses.textEn: Do not forsake me, O Lord my God. Do not depart from me.
verses.textLa: Ne derelinquas me Domine Deus meus: ne discesseris a me.

verses.textEn: Be attentive to my help, O Lord, the God of my salvation.
verses.textLa: Intende in adiutorium meum, Domine Deus salutis meæ.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For Jeduthun himself. A Canticle of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, ipsi Idithun, Canticum David.

verses.textEn: I said, “I will keep to my ways, so that I will not offend with my tongue.” I posted a guard at my mouth, when a sinner took up a position against me.
verses.textLa: Dixi: Custodiam vias meas: ut non delinquam in lingua mea. Posui ori meo custodiam, cum consisteret peccator adversum me.

verses.textEn: I was silenced and humbled, and I was quiet before good things, and my sorrow was renewed.
verses.textLa: Obmutui, et humiliatus sum, et silui a bonis: et dolor meus renovatus est.

verses.textEn: My heart grew hot within me, and, during my meditation, a fire would flare up.
verses.textLa: Concaluit cor meum intra me: et in meditatione mea exardescet ignis.

verses.textEn: I spoke with my tongue, “O Lord, make me know my end, and what the number of my days will be, so that I may know what is lacking to me.”
verses.textLa: Locutus sum in lingua mea: Notum fac mihi Domine finem meum. Et numerum dierum meorum quis est: ut sciam quid desit mihi.

verses.textEn: Behold, you have made my days measurable, and, before you, my substance is as nothing. Yet truly, all things are vanity: every living man.
verses.textLa: Ecce mensurabiles posuisti dies meos: et substantia mea tamquam nihilum ante te. Verumtamen universa vanitas, omnis homo vivens.

verses.textEn: So then, truly man passes by like an image; even so, he is disquieted in vain. He stores up, and he knows not for whom he will gather these things.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen in imagine pertransit homo: sed et frustra conturbatur. Thesaurizat: et ignorat cui congregabit ea.

verses.textEn: And now, what is it that awaits me? Is it not the Lord? And my substance is with you.
verses.textLa: Et nunc quæ est expectatio mea? nonne Dominus? et substantia mea apud te est.

verses.textEn: Rescue me from all my iniquities. You have handed me over as a reproach to the foolish.
verses.textLa: Ab omnibus iniquitatibus meis erue me: opprobrium insipienti dedisti me.

verses.textEn: I was silenced, and I did not open my mouth, because it was you who acted.
verses.textLa: Obmutui, et non aperui os meum, quoniam tu fecisti:

verses.textEn: Remove your scourges from me.
verses.textLa: amove a me plagas tuas.

verses.textEn: I fall short at corrections from the strength of your hand. For you have chastised man for iniquity. And you have made his soul shrink away like a spider. Nevertheless, it is in vain that any man be disquieted.
verses.textLa: A fortitudine manus tuæ ego defeci in increpationibus: propter iniquitatem corripuisti hominem. Et tabescere fecisti sicut araneam animam eius: verumtamen vane conturbatur omnis homo.

verses.textEn: O Lord, heed my prayer and my supplication. Pay attention to my tears. Do not be silent. For I am a newcomer with you, and a sojourner, just as all my fathers were.
verses.textLa: Exaudi orationem meam Domine, et deprecationem meam: auribus percipe lacrimas meas. Ne sileas: quoniam advena ego sum apud te, et peregrinus, sicut omnes patres mei.

verses.textEn: Forgive me, so that I may be refreshed, before I will go forth and be no more.
verses.textLa: Remitte mihi, ut refrigerer priusquam abeam, et amplius non ero.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David himself.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus ipsi David.
verses.notes: In other words, ‘A Psalm of David about David himself.’

verses.textEn: I have waited expectantly for the Lord, and he was attentive to me.
verses.textLa: Expectans expectavi Dominum, et intendit mihi.
verses.notes: The repetition of the verb intensifies its meaning. A more loose translation: ‘I have waited and waited for the Lord....’

verses.textEn: And he heard my prayers and he led me out of the pit of misery and the quagmire. And he stationed my feet upon a rock, and he directed my steps.
verses.textLa: Et exaudivit preces meas: et eduxit me de lacu miseriæ, et de luto fæcis. Et statuit super petram pedes meos: et direxit gressus meos.

verses.textEn: And he sent a new canticle into my mouth, a song to our God. Many will see, and they will fear; and they will hope in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et immisit in os meum canticum novum, carmen Deo nostro. Videbunt multi, et timebunt: et sperabunt in Domino.
verses.notes: The word ‘carmen’ refers to a song or a play or a card used for wool/flax, i.e. it refers to anything that is divided into parts: ‘a song in parts to our God.’

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man whose hope is in the name of the Lord, and who has no respect for vanities and absurd falsehoods.
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, cuius est nomen Domini spes eius: et non respexit in vanitates et insanias falsas.

verses.textEn: You have accomplished your many wonders, O Lord my God, and there is no one similar to you in your thoughts. I have announced and I have spoken: they are multiplied beyond number.
verses.textLa: Multa fecisti tu Domine Deus meus mirabilia tua: et cogitationibus tuis non est qui similis sit tibi. Annunciavi et locutus sum: multiplicati sunt super numerum.
verses.notes: The word ‘cogitationibus’ is plural and refers to thoughts, perceptions, things that are understood, and/or intentions. The word ‘cognitions’ expresses nearly the same range of meanings as ‘cogitationibus,’ but the English word is more obscure. Sometimes an obscure word that more fully expresses the meaning is a better choice than a common easily understood word that expresses less of the meaning.

verses.textEn: Sacrifice and oblation, you did not want. But you have perfected ears for me. Holocaust and sin offering, you did not require.
verses.textLa: Sacrificium et oblationem noluisti: aures autem perfecisti mihi. Holocaustum et pro peccato non postulasti:

verses.textEn: Then I said, “Behold, I draw near.” At the head of the book, it has been written of me:
verses.textLa: tunc dixi: Ecce venio. In capite libri scriptum est de me

verses.textEn: that I should do your will. My God, I have willed it. And your law is in the midst of my heart.
verses.textLa: ut facerem voluntatem tuam: Deus meus volui, et legem tuam in medio cordis mei.

verses.textEn: I have announced your justice in a great Church: behold, I will not restrain my lips. O Lord, you have known it.
verses.textLa: Annunciavi iustitiam tuam in Ecclesia magna, ecce labia mea non prohibebo: Domine tu scisti.

verses.textEn: I have not concealed your justice within my heart. I have spoken your truth and your salvation. I have not concealed your mercy and your truth from a great assembly.
verses.textLa: Iustitiam tuam non abscondi in corde meo: veritatem tuam et salutare tuum dixi. Non abscondi misericordiam tuam, et veritatem tuam a concilio multo.

verses.textEn: O Lord, do not take your tender mercies far from me. Your mercy and your truth ever sustain me.
verses.textLa: Tu autem Domine ne longe facias miserationes tuas a me: misericordia tua et veritas tua semper susceperunt me.

verses.textEn: For evils without number have surrounded me. My iniquities have taken hold of me, and I was not able to see. They have been multiplied beyond the hairs of my head. And my heart has forsaken me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam circumdederunt me mala, quorum non est numerus: comprehenderunt me iniquitates meæ, et non potui ut viderem. Multiplicatæ sunt super capillos capitis mei: et cor meum dereliquit me.

verses.textEn: Be pleased, O Lord, to rescue me. Look down, O Lord, to help me.
verses.textLa: Complaceat tibi Domine ut eruas me: Domine, ad adiuvandum me respice.

verses.textEn: Let them together be confounded and awed, who seek after my soul to steal it away. Let them be turned back and be in awe, who wish evils upon me.
verses.textLa: Confundantur et revereantur simul, qui quærunt animam meam, ut auferant eam. Convertantur retrorsum, et revereantur qui volunt mihi mala.

verses.textEn: Let them bear their confusion all at once, who say to me, “Well, well.”
verses.textLa: Ferant confestim confusionem suam, qui dicunt mihi: Euge, euge.

verses.textEn: Let all who seek you exult and rejoice over you. And let those who love your salvation always say, “May the Lord be magnified.”
verses.textLa: Exultent et lætentur super te omnes quærentes te: et dicant semper: Magnificetur Dominus: qui diligunt salutare tuum.

verses.textEn: But I am a beggar and poor. The Lord has been concerned about me. You are my helper and my protector. My God, do not delay.
verses.textLa: Ego autem mendicus sum, et pauper: Dominus sollicitus est mei. Adiutor meus, et protector meus tu es: Deus meus ne tardaveris.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David himself.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus ipsi David.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he who shows understanding toward the needy and the poor. The Lord will deliver him in the evil day.
verses.textLa: Beatus qui intelligit super egenum, et pauperem: in die mala liberabit eum Dominus.

verses.textEn: May the Lord preserve him and give him life, and make him blessed upon the earth. And may he not hand him over to the will of his adversaries.
verses.textLa: Dominus conservet eum, et vivificet eum, et beatum faciat eum in terra: et non tradat eum in animam inimicorum eius.

verses.textEn: May the Lord bring him help on his bed of sorrow. In his infirmity, you have changed his entire covering.
verses.textLa: Dominus opem ferat illi super lectum doloris eius: universum stratum eius versasti in infirmitate eius.

verses.textEn: I said, “O Lord, be merciful to me. Heal my soul, because I have sinned against you.”
verses.textLa: Ego dixi: Domine miserere mei: sana animam meam, quia peccavi tibi.

verses.textEn: My enemies have spoken evils against me. When will he die and his name perish?
verses.textLa: Inimici mei dixerunt mala mihi: Quando morietur, et peribit nomen eius?

verses.textEn: And when he came in to see me, he was speaking emptiness. His heart gathered iniquity to itself. He went outside, and he was speaking in the same way.
verses.textLa: Et si ingrediebatur ut videret, vana loquebatur, cor eius congregavit iniquitatem sibi. Egrediebatur foras, et loquebatur

verses.textEn: All my enemies were whispering against me. They were thinking up evils against me.
verses.textLa: in idipsum. Adversum me susurrabant omnes inimici mei: adversum me cogitabant mala mihi.

verses.textEn: They established an unjust word against me. Will he that sleeps no longer rise again?
verses.textLa: Verbum iniquum constituerunt adversum me: Numquid qui dormit non adiiciet ut resurgat?

verses.textEn: For even the man of my peace, in whom I hoped, who ate my bread, has greatly supplanted me.
