verses.textLa: Etenim homo pacis meæ, in quo speravi: qui edebat panes meos, magnificavit super me supplantationem.

verses.textEn: But you, O Lord, have mercy on me, and raise me up again. And I will requite them.
verses.textLa: Tu autem Domine miserere mei, et resuscita me: et retribuam eis.

verses.textEn: By this, I knew that you preferred me: because my adversary will not rejoice over me.
verses.textLa: In hoc cognovi quoniam voluisti me: quoniam non gaudebit inimicus meus super me.

verses.textEn: But you have sustained me, because of my innocence, and you have confirmed me in your sight in eternity.
verses.textLa: Me autem propter innocentiam suscepisti: et confirmasti me in conspectu tuo in æternum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, for all generations and even forever. Amen. Amen.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus Deus Israel a sæculo, et usque in sæculum: fiat, fiat.
verses.notes: The words ‘fiat, fiat’ call to mind the words of the Virgin Mary in the Gospel of Luke: “Ecce ancilla Domini, fiat mihi secundum verbum tuum.” The Latin ‘fiat’ in this Psalm is a translation of the Hebrew ‘Amen’ (which is also used in Aramaic). Fiat can be translated as ‘let it be’ or as ‘so be it.’ Amen can be translated in the same way, and also as ‘truly.’

verses.textEn: Unto the end. The understanding of the sons of Korah.
verses.textLa: In finem, Intellectus filiis Core.
verses.notes: More literally, this says, ‘Understanding to (or for) the sons of Korah.’ But the meaning is that this Psalm expresses the spiritual life of the faithful as the sons of Korah may have understood and expressed it.

verses.textEn: As the deer longs for fountains of water, so my soul longs for you, O God.
verses.textLa: Quemadmodum desiderat cervus ad fontes aquarum: ita desiderat anima mea ad te Deus.

verses.textEn: My soul has thirsted for the strong living God. When will I draw close and appear before the face of God?
verses.textLa: Sitivit anima mea ad Deum fortem vivum: quando veniam et apparebo ante faciem Dei?

verses.textEn: My tears have been my bread, day and night. Meanwhile, it is said to me daily: “Where is your God?”
verses.textLa: Fuerunt mihi lacrimæ meæ panes die ac nocte: dum dicitur mihi quotidie: Ubi est Deus tuus?

verses.textEn: These things I have remembered; and my soul within me, I have poured out. For I will cross into the place of the wonderful tabernacle, all the way to the house of God, with a voice of exultation and confession, the sound of feasting.
verses.textLa: Hæc recordatus sum, et effudi in me animam meam: quoniam transibo in locum tabernaculi admirabilis, usque ad donum Dei: In voce exultationis, et confessionis: sonus epulantis.

verses.textEn: Why are you sad, my soul? And why do you disquiet me? Hope in God, for I will still confess to him: the salvation of my countenance,
verses.textLa: Quare tristis es anima mea? et quare conturbas me? Spera in Deo, quoniam adhuc confitebor illi: salutare vultus mei,

verses.textEn: and my God. My soul has been troubled within myself. Because of this, I will remember you from the land of the Jordan and from Hermon, from the little mountain.
verses.textLa: et Deus meus. Ad meipsum anima mea conturbata est: propterea memor ero tui de terra Iordanis, et Hermoniim a monte modico.

verses.textEn: Abyss calls upon abyss, with the voice of your floodgate. All your heights and your waves have passed over me.
verses.textLa: Abyssus abyssum invocat, in voce cataractarum tuarum. Omnia excelsa tua, et fluctus tui super me transierunt.

verses.textEn: In the daylight, the Lord has ordered his mercy; and in the night, a canticle to him. With me is a prayer to the God of my life.
verses.textLa: In die mandavit Dominus misericordiam suam: et nocte canticum eius. Apud me oratio Deo vitæ meæ,

verses.textEn: I will say to God, “You are my supporter. Why have you forgotten me? And why do I walk in mourning, while my adversary afflicts me?”
verses.textLa: dicam Deo: Susceptor meus es, Quare oblitus es mei? et quare contristatus incedo, dum affligit me inimicus?

verses.textEn: While my bones are being broken, my enemies, who trouble me, have reproached me. Meanwhile, they say to me every single day, “Where is your God?”
verses.textLa: Dum confringuntur ossa mea, exprobraverunt mihi qui tribulant me inimici mei: Dum dicunt mihi per singulos dies: Ubi est Deus tuus?

verses.textEn: My soul, why are you saddened? And why do you disquiet me? Hope in God, for I will still confess to him: the salvation of my countenance and my God.
verses.textLa: quare tristis es anima mea? et quare conturbas me? Spera in Deo, quoniam adhuc confitebor illi: salutare vultus mei, et Deus meus.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. Judge me, O God, and discern my cause from that of a nation not holy; rescue me from a man unjust and deceitful.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David. Iudica me Deus, et discerne causam meam de gente non sancta, ab homine iniquo, et doloso erue me.

verses.textEn: For you are God, my strength. Why have you rejected me? And why do I walk in sadness, while the adversary afflicts me?
verses.textLa: Quia tu es Deus fortitudo mea: quare me repulisti? et quare tristis incedo, dum affligit me inimicus?

verses.textEn: Send forth your light and your truth. They have guided me and led me, to your holy mountain and into your tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Emitte lucem tuam et veritatem tuam: ipsa me deduxerunt, et adduxerunt in montem sanctum tuum, et in tabernacula tua.

verses.textEn: And I will enter, upto the altar of God, to God who enlivens my youthfulness. To you, O God, my God, I will confess upon a stringed instrument.
verses.textLa: Et introibo ad altare Dei: ad Deum, qui lætificat iuventutem meam. Confitebor tibi in cithara Deus, Deus meus:

verses.textEn: Why are you sad, my soul? And why do you disquiet me? Hope in God, for I will still give praise to him: the salvation of my countenance and my God.
verses.textLa: quare tristis es anima mea? et quare conturbas me? Spera in Deo, quoniam adhuc confitebor illi: salutare vultus mei, et Deus meus.
verses.notes: The Clementine Vulgate has only five verses in Psalm 42. Therefore, the CPDV uses the same arrangement. Other versions arrange the same words into six verses for this Psalm.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. To the sons of Korah, toward understanding.
verses.textLa: In finem, Filiis Core ad intellectum.

verses.textEn: We have heard, O God, with our own ears. Our fathers have announced to us the work that you wrought in their days and in the days of antiquity.
verses.textLa: Deus auribus nostris audivimus: patres nostri annunciaverunt nobis. Opus, quod operatus es in diebus eorum: et in diebus antiquis.

verses.textEn: Your hand dispersed the Gentiles, and you transplanted them. You afflicted a people, and you expelled them.
verses.textLa: Manus tua gentes disperdidit, et plantasti eos: afflixisti populos, et expulisti eos:

verses.textEn: For they did not take possession of the land by their sword, and their own arm did not save them. But your right hand and your arm, and the light of your countenance did so, because you were pleased with them.
verses.textLa: Nec enim in gladio suo possederunt terram, et brachium eorum non salvavit eos: Sed dextera tua, et brachium tuum, et illuminatio vultus tui: quoniam complacuisti in eis.

verses.textEn: You yourself are my king and my God, who commands the salvation of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Tu es ipse rex meus et Deus meus: qui mandas salutes Iacob.

verses.textEn: With you, we will brandish a horn before our enemies; and in your name, we will spurn those rising up against us.
verses.textLa: In te inimicos nostros ventilabimus cornu, et in nomine tuo spernemus insurgentes in nobis.
verses.notes: The word ‘ventilabimus’ refers to waving a fan in order to start a fire; it also can refer to brandishing a weapon. The figure of a horn is used to represent a weapon, since horned animals uses their horns as weapons.

verses.textEn: For I will not hope in my bow, and my sword will not save me.
verses.textLa: Non enim in arcu meo sperabo: et gladius meus non salvabit me.

verses.textEn: For you have saved us from those who afflict us, and you have bewildered those who hate us.
verses.textLa: Salvasti enim nos de affligentibus nos: et odientes nos confudisti.

verses.textEn: In God, we will give praise all day long; and in your name, we will confess forever.
verses.textLa: In Deo laudabimur tota die: et in nomine tuo confitebimur in sæculum.

verses.textEn: But now, you have rejected and bewildered us, and you will not go forth with our armies, O God.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem repulisti et confudisti nos: et non egredieris Deus in virtutibus nostris.
verses.notes: Or, ‘go forth with our strength.’

verses.textEn: You have turned our back to our enemies, and those who hated us have plundered for themselves.
verses.textLa: Avertisti nos retrorsum post inimicos nostros: et qui oderunt nos, diripiebant sibi.

verses.textEn: You have given us over like sheep for food. You have scattered us among the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Dedisti nos tamquam oves escarum: et in Gentibus dispersisti nos.

verses.textEn: You have sold your people without a price, and no great number was exchanged for them.
verses.textLa: Vendidisti populum tuum sine pretio: et non fuit multitudo in commutationibus eorum.
verses.notes: This last phrase could mean that no great amount of money (or wealth) was given in exchange for them, or that there was no great crowd of people given in exchange for them. God handed over his people for free and He did not receive any remuneration, nor did he receive a new and more numerous people in exchange.

verses.textEn: You have set us as a disgrace to our neighbors, a scoff and a derision to those who are around us.
verses.textLa: Posuisti nos opprobrium vicinis nostris, subsannationem et derisum his, qui sunt in circuitu nostro.

verses.textEn: You have set us as a parable among the Gentiles, a shaking of the head among the peoples.
verses.textLa: Posuisti nos in similitudinem Gentibus: commotionem capitis in populis.

verses.textEn: All day long my shame is before me, and the confusion of my face has covered me,
verses.textLa: Tota die verecundia mea contra me est, et confusio faciei meæ cooperuit me,

verses.textEn: before the voice of the reproacher and the commentator, before the face of the adversary and the pursuer.
verses.textLa: a voce exprobrantis, et obloquentis: a facie inimici, et persequentis.

verses.textEn: All these things have come upon us, yet we have not forgotten you, and we have not acted unjustly in your covenant.
verses.textLa: Hæc omnia venerunt super nos, nec obliti sumus te: et inique non egimus in testamento tuo.

verses.textEn: And our heart has not turned back. And you have not diverted our steps from your way.
verses.textLa: Et non recessit retro cor nostrum: et declinasti semitas nostras a via tua:

verses.textEn: For you humbled us in a place of affliction, and the shadow of death has covered us.
verses.textLa: Quoniam humiliasti nos in loco afflictionis, et cooperuit nos umbra mortis.

verses.textEn: If we have forgotten the name of our God, and if we have extended our hands to a foreign god,
verses.textLa: Si obliti sumus nomen Dei nostri, et si expandimus manus nostras ad deum alienum:

verses.textEn: will not God find this out? For he knows the secrets of the heart. For, because of you, we are being killed all day long. We are considered as sheep for the slaughter.
verses.textLa: Nonne Deus requiret ista? ipse enim novit abscondita cordis. Quoniam propter te mortificamur tota die: æstimati sumus sicut oves occisionis.

verses.textEn: Rise up. Why do you fall asleep, O Lord? Rise up, and do not reject us in the end.
verses.textLa: Exurge, quare obdormis Domine? exurge, et ne repellas in finem.

verses.textEn: Why do you turn your face away, and why do you forget our needfulness and our tribulation?
verses.textLa: Quare faciem tuam avertis, oblivisceris inopiæ nostræ et tribulationis nostræ?

verses.textEn: For our soul has been humbled into the dust. Our belly has been bound to the earth.
verses.textLa: Quoniam humiliata est in pulvere anima nostra: conglutinatus est in terra venter noster.

verses.textEn: Rise up, O Lord. Help us and redeem us, because of your name.
verses.textLa: Exurge Domine, adiuva nos: et redime nos propter nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For those who will be changed. To the sons of Korah, toward understanding. A Canticle for the Beloved.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro iis, qui commutabuntur, filiis Core, ad intellectum, Canticum pro dilecto.

verses.textEn: My heart has uttered a good word. I speak of my works to the king. My tongue is like the pen of a scribe who writes quickly.
verses.textLa: Eructavit cor meum verbum bonum: dico ego opera mea regi. Lingua mea calamus scribæ, velociter scribentis.

verses.textEn: You are a brilliant form before the sons of men. Grace has been poured freely into your lips. Because of this, God has blessed you in eternity.
verses.textLa: Speciosus forma præ filiis hominum, diffusa est gratia in labiis tuis: propterea benedixit te Deus in æternum.
verses.notes: This verse refers to the Virgin Mary, into whose lips grace has been freely poured. She is blessed by God in eternity.

verses.textEn: Fasten your sword to your thigh, O most powerful one.
verses.textLa: Accingere gladio tuo super femur tuum, potentissime.
verses.notes: But this subsequent verse now refers to Christ himself, for the word ‘potentissime’ is singular masculine. Also, the superlative expression ‘most powerful one’ is fitting only for God, so it must refer to Christ, not Mary. As does the next verse also.

verses.textEn: With your splendor and your excellence extended, proceed prosperously, and reign for the sake of truth and meekness and justice, and so will your right hand lead you wondrously.
verses.textLa: Specie tua et pulchritudine tua intende, prospere procede, et regna, propter veritatem et mansuetudinem, et iustitiam: et deducet te mirabiliter dextera tua.

verses.textEn: Your arrows are sharp; the people will fall under you, with the hearts of the enemies of the king.
verses.textLa: Sagittæ tuæ acutæ, populi sub te cadent, in corda inimicorum regis.

verses.textEn: Your throne, O God, is forever and ever. The scepter of your kingdom is a scepter of true aim.
verses.textLa: Sedes tua Deus in sæculum sæculi: virga directionis virga regni tui.

verses.textEn: You have loved justice and hated iniquity. Because of this, God, your God, has anointed you, before your co-heirs, with the oil of gladness.
verses.textLa: Dilexisti iustitiam, et odisti iniquitatem: propterea unxit te Deus, Deus tuus oleo lætitiæ præ consortibus tuis.
verses.notes: The word ‘consortibus’ has a fairly wide range of meaning in Latin. It can refer to siblings, to associates or co-workers, but it can also refer to those who are to inherit something, to siblings who are co-heirs. The verse has the meaning of someone being anointed, while others who are also anointed watch. It also has the meaning of someone who is an heir, standing among others who are co-heirs. But the one being anointed is an Anointed among anointed ones, an Heir among co-heirs, a Prince among princes, a King among kings.

verses.textEn: Myrrh and balsam and cinnamon perfume your garments, from the houses of ivory. From these, they have delighted you:
verses.textLa: Myrrha, et gutta, et casia a vestimentis tuis, a domibus eburneis: ex quibus delectaverunt te
verses.notes: The word ‘gutta’ refers to a tree or plant resin that is aromatic. The translation ‘balsam’ is used because a balsam is any type of tree or plant resin, but typically one that is aromatic.

verses.textEn: the daughters of kings in your honor. The queen assisted at your right hand, in clothing of gold, encircled with diversity.
verses.textLa: filiæ regum in honore tuo. Astitit regina a dextris tuis in vestitu deaurato: circumdata varietate.

verses.textEn: Listen, daughter, and see, and incline your ear. And forget your people and your father’s house.
verses.textLa: Audi filia, et vide, et inclina aurem tuam: et obliviscere populum tuum, et domum patris tui.

verses.textEn: And the king will desire your beauty. For he is the Lord your God, and they will adore him.
verses.textLa: Et concupiscet rex decorem tuum: quoniam ipse est Dominus Deus tuus, et adorabunt eum.

verses.textEn: And the daughters of Tyre will entreat your countenance with gifts: all the rich men of the people.
verses.textLa: Et filiæ Tyri in muneribus vultum tuum deprecabuntur: omnes divites plebis.
verses.notes: The word ‘filiæ’ is clearly feminine plural: ‘And the daughters of Tyre.’ Tyre was a wealthy city due to its prosperous dye (Tyrian purple) and clothier industry in Biblical times. However, ‘divites’ is clearly masculine plural: ‘all the rich men of the people.’ Ordinarily, a translator ought to prefer to translate one noun with one noun, but English does not allow one to indicate gender, even with many words that refer to people, such as ‘the rich’ or ‘the wealthy.’ Since the first part of the verse is clearly referring to the women of wealthy Tyre, the last part is also specifically meant to indicate the successful wealthy men among the people (not merely any or all of the people. Keeping the gender references intact in this verse is essential to understanding its meaning.

verses.textEn: All the glory of the daughter of its king is inside, in golden fringes,
verses.textLa: Omnis gloria eius filiæ regis ab intus, in fimbriis aureis

verses.textEn: clothed all around with diversities. After her, virgins will be led to the king. Her neighbors will be brought to you.
verses.textLa: circumamicta varietatibus. Adducentur regi virgines post eam: proximæ eius afferentur tibi.

verses.textEn: They will be brought with gladness and exultation. They will be led into the temple of the king.
verses.textLa: Afferentur in lætitia et exultatione: adducentur in templum regis.

verses.textEn: For your fathers, sons have been born to you. You will establish them as leaders over all the earth.
verses.textLa: Pro patribus tuis nati sunt tibi filii: constitues eos principes super omnem terram.

verses.textEn: They will remember your name always, for generation after generation. Because of this, people will confess to you in eternity, even forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Memores erunt nominis tui in omni generatione et generationem. Propterea populi confitebuntur tibi in æternum: et in sæculum sæculi.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. To the sons of Korah, for confidants. A Psalm.
verses.textLa: In finem, filiis Core pro arcanis, Psalmus.
verses.notes: The word ‘arcanis’ can refer to things that are understood or known only to a few, to things that are hidden or secret, or it can refer to persons who can be trusted with esoteric knowledge or secrets, i.e. confidants or trustworthy friends.

verses.textEn: Our God is our refuge and strength, a helper in the tribulations that have greatly overwhelmed us.
verses.textLa: Deus noster refugium, et virtus: adiutor in tribulationibus, quæ invenerunt nos nimis.

verses.textEn: Because of this, we will not be afraid when the earth will be turbulent and the mountains will be transferred into the heart of the sea.
verses.textLa: Propterea non timebimus dum turbabitur terra: et transferentur montes in cor maris.

verses.textEn: They thundered, and the waters were stirred up among them; the mountains have been disturbed by his strength.
verses.textLa: Sonuerunt, et turbatæ sunt aquæ eorum: conturbati sunt montes in fortitudine eius.
verses.notes: The word ‘eorum’ does not refer to ‘aquæ,’ because the former is masculine and the latter is feminine. The word ‘eorum’ refers to the mountains, ‘montes’ is masculine plural, as is ‘eorum.’ So, the mountains thundered (as they were being transferred to the sea), and the waters among them (among the mountains) were stirred up.

verses.textEn: The frenzy of the river rejoices the city of God. The Most High has sanctified his tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Fluminis impetus lætificat civitatem Dei: sanctificavit tabernaculum suum Altissimus.

verses.textEn: God is in its midst; it will not be shaken. God will assist it in the early morning.
verses.textLa: Deus, in medio eius, non commovebitur: adiuvabit eam Deus mane diluculo.

verses.textEn: The peoples have been disturbed, and the kingdoms have been bowed down. He uttered his voice: the earth has been moved.
verses.textLa: Conturbatæ sunt gentes, et inclinata sunt regna: dedit vocem suam, mota est terra.

verses.textEn: The Lord of hosts is with us. The God of Jacob is our supporter.
verses.textLa: Dominus virtutum nobiscum: susceptor noster Deus Iacob.

verses.textEn: Draw near and behold the works of the Lord: what portents he has set upon the earth,
verses.textLa: Venite, et videte opera Domini, quæ posuit prodigia super terram:

verses.textEn: carrying away wars even to the end of the earth. He will crush the bow and break the weapons, and he will burn the shield with fire.
verses.textLa: auferens bella usque ad finem terræ. Arcum conteret, et confringet arma: et scuta comburet igni:

verses.textEn: Be empty, and see that I am God. I will be exalted among the peoples, and I will be exalted upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Vacate, et videte quoniam ego sum Deus: exaltabor in gentibus, et exaltabor in terra.

verses.textEn: The Lord of hosts is with us. The God of Jacob is our supporter.
verses.textLa: Dominus virtutum nobiscum: susceptor noster Deus Iacob.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm for the sons of Korah.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro filiis Core Psalmus.
verses.notes: Notice that this verse has ‘pro filiis Core,’ whereas other Psalms have simply ‘filiis Core.’ Thus, the translation of this verse is ‘for the sons of Korah,’ whereas the other verses should be translated as ‘to the sons of Korah,’ or, more loosely, ‘of the sons of Korah.’

verses.textEn: All nations, clap your hands. Shout joyfully to God with a voice of exultation.
verses.textLa: Omnes gentes plaudite manibus: iubilate Deo in voce exultationis.
verses.notes: Or, ‘all Gentiles,’ or, ‘all unbelievers.’

verses.textEn: For the Lord is exalted and terrible: a great King over all the earth.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Dominus excelsus, terribilis: Rex magnus super omnem terram.

verses.textEn: He has subjected the peoples to us and subdued the nations under our feet.
verses.textLa: Subiecit populos nobis: et gentes sub pedibus nostris.

verses.textEn: He has chosen us for his inheritance: the splendor of Jacob, whom he has loved.
verses.textLa: Elegit nobis hereditatem suam: speciem Iacob, quam dilexit.

verses.textEn: God ascends with jubilation, and the Lord with the voice of the trumpet.
verses.textLa: Ascendit Deus in iubilo: et Dominus in voce tubæ.

verses.textEn: Sing psalms to our God, sing psalms. Sing psalms to our King, sing psalms.
verses.textLa: Psallite Deo nostro, psallite: psallite Regi nostro, psallite.

verses.textEn: For God is the King of all the earth. Sing psalms wisely.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Rex omnis terræ Deus: psallite sapienter.

verses.textEn: God will reign over the peoples. God sits upon his holy throne.
verses.textLa: Regnabit Deus super gentes: Deus sedet super sedem sanctam suam.

verses.textEn: The leaders of the peoples have been gathered together by the God of Abraham. For the strong gods of the earth have been exceedingly exalted.
verses.textLa: Principes populorum congregati sunt cum Deo Abraham: quoniam dii fortes terræ, vehementer elevati sunt.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm. To the sons of Korah, on the second Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Cantici, filiis Core, secunda sabbati.
verses.notes: The second Sabbath is the second of the seven Sabbaths after Passover, counting towards the Feast of Weeks (Pentecost). This verse calls to mind the mention of the second first Sabbath in the Gospel. The first Sabbath is the Sabbath during Passover (zero in the count of the seven weeks and seven Sabbaths leading up to the Feast of Weeks). The second first Sabbath is the first Sabbath after Passover (one in the same count).

verses.textEn: The Lord is great and exceedingly praiseworthy, in the city of our God, on his holy mountain.
verses.textLa: Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis in civitate Dei nostri, in monte sancto eius.

verses.textEn: Mount Zion is being founded with the exultation of the whole earth, on the north side, the city of the great king.
verses.textLa: Fundatur exultatione universæ terræ mons Sion, latera Aquilonis, civitas Regis magni.

verses.textEn: In her houses, God will be known, since he will support her.
verses.textLa: Deus in domibus eius cognoscetur, cum suscipiet eam.

verses.textEn: For behold, the kings of the earth have been gathered together; they have convened as one.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ecce reges terræ congregati sunt: convenerunt in unum.

verses.textEn: Such did they see, and they were astonished: they were disturbed, they were moved.
verses.textLa: Ipsi videntes sic admirati sunt, conturbati sunt, commoti sunt:

verses.textEn: Trembling took hold of them. In that place, their pains were that of a woman in labor.
verses.textLa: tremor apprehendit eos. Ibi dolores ut parturientis,

verses.textEn: With a vehement spirit, you will crush the ships of Tarshish.
verses.textLa: in spiritu vehementi conteres naves Tharsis.

verses.textEn: As we have heard, so we have seen, in the city of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God. God has founded it in eternity.
verses.textLa: Sicut audivimus, sic vidimus in civitate Domini virtutum, in civitate Dei nostri: Deus fundavit eam in æternum.

verses.textEn: We have received your mercy, O God, in the midst of your temple.
verses.textLa: Suscepimus Deus misericordiam tuam, in medio templi tui.

verses.textEn: According to your name, O God, so does your praise reach to the ends of the earth. Your right hand is full of justice.
verses.textLa: Secundum nomen tuum Deus, sic et laus tua in fines terræ: iustitia plena est dextera tua.

verses.textEn: Let mount Zion rejoice, and let the daughters of Judah exult, because of your judgments, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Lætetur mons Sion, et exultent filiæ Iudæ, propter iudicia tua Domine.

verses.textEn: Encircle Zion and embrace her. Discourse in her towers.
verses.textLa: Circumdate Sion, et complectimini eam: narrate in turribus eius.

verses.textEn: Set your hearts on her virtue. And distribute her houses, so that you may discourse of it in another generation.
verses.textLa: Ponite corda vestra in virtute eius: et distribuite domos eius, ut enarretis in progenie altera.

verses.textEn: For this is God, our God, in eternity and forever and ever. He will rule us forever.
verses.textLa: Quoniam hic est Deus, Deus noster in æternum, et in sæculum sæculi: ipse reget nos in sæcula.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm to the sons of Korah.
verses.textLa: In finem, filiis Core Psalmus.

verses.textEn: Hear these things, all nations. Pay attention, all inhabitants of the world:
verses.textLa: Audite hæc omnes gentes: auribus percipite omnes, qui habitatis orbem:

verses.textEn: whoever is earth-born, you sons of men, together as one, the rich and the poor.
verses.textLa: Quique terrigenæ, et filii hominum: simul in unum dives et pauper.

verses.textEn: My mouth will speak wisdom, and the meditation of my heart will speak prudence.
verses.textLa: Os meum loquetur sapientiam: et meditatio cordis mei prudentiam.

verses.textEn: I will incline my ear to a parable. I will open my case with the psaltery.
verses.textLa: Inclinabo in parabolam aurem meam: aperiam in psalterio propositionem meam.
verses.notes: Although the word ‘psalterio’ refers to an ancient stringed musical instrument, it brings to mind the Psalter (the Psalms), and our Lady’s Psalter (the Rosary).

verses.textEn: Why should I fear in the evil day? The iniquity at my heel will surround me.
verses.textLa: Cur timebo in die mala? iniquitas calcanei mei circumdabit me:

verses.textEn: Those who trust in their own strength and who glory in the multitude of their riches,
verses.textLa: Qui confidunt in virtute sua: et in multitudine divitiarum suarum gloriantur.

verses.textEn: no brother redeems, nor will man buy back. He will not give to God his appeasement,
verses.textLa: Frater non redimit, redimet homo: non dabit Deo placationem suam.

verses.textEn: nor the price for the redemption of his soul. And he will labor continuously,
verses.textLa: Et pretium redemptionis animæ suæ: et laborabit in æternum,

verses.textEn: and he will still live, until the end.
verses.textLa: et vivet adhuc in finem.

verses.textEn: He will not see death, when he sees the wise dying: the foolish and the senseless will perish together. And they will leave their riches to strangers.
verses.textLa: Non videbit interitum, cum viderit sapientes morientes: simul insipiens, et stultus peribunt. Et relinquent alienis divitias suas:

verses.textEn: And their sepulchers will be their houses forever, their tabernacles from generation to generation. They have called their names in their own lands.
verses.textLa: et sepulchra eorum domus illorum in æternum. Tabernacula eorum in progenie, et progenie: vocaverunt nomina sua in terris suis.
verses.notes: In this last part, ‘nomina sua’ is accusative, not nominative. They (the sepulchers) have called their names in their own lands. In other words, their deaths and their final resting place is calling for them.

verses.textEn: And man, when he was held in honor, did not understand. He has been compared to the senseless beasts, and he has become like them.
verses.textLa: Et homo, cum in honore esset, non intellexit: comparatus est iumentis insipientibus, et similis factus est illis.

verses.textEn: This way of theirs is a scandal to them. And afterwards, they will delight in their mouth.
verses.textLa: Hæc via illorum scandalum ipsis: et postea in ore suo complacebunt.

verses.textEn: They have been placed in Hell like sheep. Death will feed on them. And the just will have dominion over them in the morning. And their help will grow old in Hell for their glory.
verses.textLa: Sicut oves in inferno positi sunt: mors depascet eos. Et dominabuntur eorum iusti in matutino: et auxilium eorum veterascet in inferno a gloria eorum.

verses.textEn: Even so, truly God will redeem my soul from the hand of Hell, when he will receive me.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen Deus redimet animam meam de manu inferi, cum acceperit me.

verses.textEn: Do not be afraid, when a man will have been made rich, and when the glory of his house will have been multiplied.
verses.textLa: Ne timueris cum dives factus fuerit homo: et cum multiplicata fuerit gloria domus eius.

verses.textEn: For when he dies, he will take nothing away, and his glory will not descend with him.
verses.textLa: Quoniam cum interierit, non sumet omnia: neque descendet cum eo gloria eius.

verses.textEn: For his soul will be blessed in his lifetime, and he will admit to you when you do good to him.
verses.textLa: Quia anima eius in vita ipsius benedicetur: confitebitur tibi cum benefeceris ei.

verses.textEn: He will even enter with the progeny of his fathers, but, even in eternity, he will not see the light.
verses.textLa: Introibit usque in progenies patrum suorum: et usque in æternum non videbit lumen.

verses.textEn: Man, when he was in honor, did not understand. He has been compared to the senseless beasts, and he has become like them.
verses.textLa: Homo, cum in honore esset, non intellexit: comparatus est iumentis insipientibus, et similis factus est illis.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of Asaph. The God of gods, the Lord has spoken, and he has called the earth, from the rising of the sun even to its setting,
verses.textLa: Psalmus Asaph. Deus deorum Dominus locutus est: et vocavit terram, A solis ortu usque ad occasum:

verses.textEn: from Zion, the brilliance of his beauty.
verses.textLa: ex Sion species decoris eius.

verses.textEn: God will arrive manifestly. Our God also will not keep silence. A fire will flare up in his sight, and a mighty tempest will surround him.
verses.textLa: Deus manifeste veniet: Deus noster et non silebit. Ignis in conspectu eius exardescet: et in circuitu eius tempestas valida.

verses.textEn: He will call to heaven from above, and to the earth, to discern his people.
verses.textLa: Advocabit cælum desursum: et terram discernere populum suum.

verses.textEn: Gather his holy ones to him, you who order his covenant above sacrifices.
verses.textLa: Congregate illi sanctos eius: qui ordinant testamentum eius super sacrificia.

verses.textEn: And the heavens will announce his justice. For God is the judge.
verses.textLa: Et annunciabunt cæli iustitiam eius: quoniam Deus iudex est.

verses.textEn: Listen, my people, and I will speak. Listen, Israel, and I will testify for you. I am God, your God.
verses.textLa: Audi populus meus, et loquar: Israel, et testificabor tibi: Deus, Deus tuus ego sum.

verses.textEn: I will not reprove you for your sacrifices. Moreover, your holocausts are ever in my sight.
verses.textLa: Non in sacrificiis tuis arguam te: holocausta autem tua in conspectu meo sunt semper.

verses.textEn: I will not accept calves from your house, nor he-goats from your flocks.
verses.textLa: Non accipiam de domo tua vitulos: neque de gregibus tuis hircos.

verses.textEn: For all the wild beasts of the forest are mine: the cattle on the hills and the oxen.
verses.textLa: Quoniam meæ sunt omnes feræ silvarum, iumenta in montibus et boves.

verses.textEn: I know all the flying things of the air, and the beauty of the field is with me.
verses.textLa: Cognovi omnia volatilia cæli: et pulchritudo agri mecum est.

verses.textEn: If I should be hungry, I would not tell you: for the whole world is mine, and all its plentitude.
verses.textLa: Si esuriero, non dicam tibi: meus est enim orbis terræ, et plenitudo eius.

verses.textEn: Shall I gnaw on the flesh of bulls? Or would I drink the blood of goats?
verses.textLa: Numquid manducabo carnes taurorum? aut sanguinem hircorum potabo?

verses.textEn: Offer to God the sacrifice of praise, and pay your vows to the Most High.
verses.textLa: Immola Deo sacrificium laudis: et redde Altissimo vota tua.

verses.textEn: And call upon me in the day of tribulation. I will rescue you, and you will honor me.
verses.textLa: Et invoca me in die tribulationis: eruam te, et honorificabis me.

verses.textEn: But to the sinner, God has said: Why do you discourse on my justices, and take up my covenant through your mouth?
verses.textLa: Peccatori autem dixit Deus: Quare tu enarras iustitias meas, et assumis testamentum meum per os tuum?

verses.textEn: Truly, you have hated discipline, and you have cast my sermons behind you.
verses.textLa: Tu vero odisti disciplinam: et proiecisti sermones meos retrorsum:

verses.textEn: If you saw a thief, you ran with him, and you have placed your portion with adulterers.
verses.textLa: Si videbas furem, currebas cum eo: et cum adulteris portionem tuam ponebas.
verses.notes: Some take part in adultery and other sins, not by committing those acts themselves, but by supporting and encouraging those who do so.

verses.textEn: Your mouth has abounded with malice, and your tongue has concocted deceits.
verses.textLa: Os tuum abundavit malitia: et lingua tua concinnabat dolos.

verses.textEn: Sitting, you spoke against your brother, and you set up a scandal against your mother’s son.
verses.textLa: Sedens adversus fratrem tuum loquebaris, et adversus filium matris tuæ ponebas scandalum:

verses.textEn: These things you have done, and I was silent. You thought, unjustly, that I ought to be like you. But I will reprove you, and I will set myself against your face.
verses.textLa: hæc fecisti, et tacui. Existimasti inique quod ero tui similis: arguam te, et statuam contra faciem tuam.

verses.textEn: Understand these things, you who forget God; lest at any time, he might quickly take you away, and there would be no one to rescue you.
verses.textLa: Intelligite hæc qui obliviscimini Deum: nequando rapiat, et non sit qui eripiat.

verses.textEn: The sacrifice of praise will honor me. And in that place is the journey by which I will reveal to him the salvation of God.
verses.textLa: Sacrificium laudis honorificabit me: et illic iter, quo ostendam illi salutare Dei.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David,
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David,

verses.textEn: when Nathan the prophet came to him, after he went to Bathsheba.
verses.textLa: Cum venit ad eum Nathan Propheta, quando intravit ad Bethsabee.

verses.textEn: Be merciful to me, O God, according to your great mercy. And, according to the plentitude of your compassion, wipe out my iniquity.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Deus, secundum magnam misericordiam tuam. Et secundum multitudinem miserationum tuarum, dele iniquitatem meam.

verses.textEn: Wash me once again from my iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.
verses.textLa: Amplius lava me ab iniquitate mea: et a peccato meo munda me.

verses.textEn: For I know my iniquity, and my sin is ever before me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam iniquitatem meam ego cognosco: et peccatum meum contra me est semper.

verses.textEn: Against you only have I sinned, and I have done evil before your eyes. And so, you are justified in your words, and you will prevail when you give judgment.
verses.textLa: Tibi soli peccavi, et malum coram te feci: ut iustificeris in sermonibus tuis, et vincas cum iudicaris.

verses.textEn: For behold, I was conceived in iniquities, and in sinfulness did my mother conceive me.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim in iniquitatibus conceptus sum: et in peccatis concepit me mater mea.

verses.textEn: For behold, you have loved truth. The obscure and hidden things of your wisdom, you have manifested to me.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim veritatem dilexisti: incerta, et occulta sapientiæ tuæ manifestasti mihi.

verses.textEn: You will sprinkle me with hyssop, and I will be cleansed. You will wash me, and I will be made whiter than snow.
verses.textLa: Asperges me hyssopo, et mundabor: lavabis me, et super nivem dealbabor.

verses.textEn: In my hearing, you will grant gladness and rejoicing. And the bones that have been humbled will exult.
verses.textLa: Auditui meo dabis gaudium et lætitiam: et exultabunt ossa humiliata.

verses.textEn: Turn your face away from my sins, and erase all my iniquities.
verses.textLa: Averte faciem tuam a peccatis meis: et omnes iniquitates meas dele.

verses.textEn: Create a clean heart in me, O God. And renew an upright spirit within my inmost being.
verses.textLa: Cor mundum crea in me Deus: et spiritum rectum innova in visceribus meis.

verses.textEn: Do not cast me away from your face; and do not take your Holy Spirit from me.
verses.textLa: Ne proiicias me a facie tua: et Spiritum Sanctum tuum ne auferas a me.
verses.notes: The words ‘Spiritum Sanctum’ have been capitalized, and are translated as ‘Holy Spirit’ because this translation takes the point of view of the Roman Catholic Church. The Old Testament is therefore seen in the light of the New Testament and of the teachings of the Church.

verses.textEn: Restore to me the joy of your salvation, and confirm me with an unsurpassed spirit.
verses.textLa: Redde mihi lætitiam salutaris tui: et spiritu principali confirma me.

verses.textEn: I will teach the unjust your ways, and the impious will be converted to you.
verses.textLa: Docebo iniquos vias tuas: et impii ad te convertentur.

verses.textEn: Free me from blood, O God, the God of my salvation, and my tongue will extol your justice.
verses.textLa: Libera me de sanguinibus Deus, Deus salutis meæ: et exultabit lingua mea iustitiam tuam.

verses.textEn: O Lord, you will open my lips, and my mouth will announce your praise.
verses.textLa: Domine, labia mea aperies: et os meum annunciabit laudem tuam.

verses.textEn: For if you had desired sacrifice, I would certainly have given it, but with holocausts, you will not be delighted.
verses.textLa: Quoniam si voluisses sacrificium, dedissem utique: holocaustis non delectaberis.

verses.textEn: A crushed spirit is a sacrifice to God. A contrite and humbled heart, O God, you will not spurn.
verses.textLa: Sacrificium Deo spiritus contribulatus: cor contritum, et humiliatum Deus non despicies.

verses.textEn: Act kindly, Lord, in your good will toward Zion, so that the walls of Jerusalem may be built up.
verses.textLa: Benigne fac Domine in bona voluntate tua Sion: ut ædificentur muri Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: Then you will accept the sacrifice of justice, oblations, and holocausts. Then they will lay calves upon your altar.
verses.textLa: Tunc acceptabis sacrificium iustitiæ, oblationes, et holocausta: tunc imponent super altare tuum vitulos.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. The understanding of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Intellectus David,

verses.textEn: When Doeg the Edomite came and reported to Saul, David went to the house of Ahimelech.
verses.textLa: Cum venit Doeg Idumæus, et nunciavit Sauli: Venit David in domum Achimelech.

verses.textEn: Why do you glory in malice, you who are powerful in iniquity?
verses.textLa: Quid gloriaris in malitia, qui potens es in iniquitate?

verses.textEn: All day long your tongue thinks up injustice. Like a sharp razor, you have wrought deceit.
verses.textLa: Tota die iniustitiam cogitavit lingua tua: sicut novacula acuta fecisti dolum.

verses.textEn: You have loved malice above goodness, and iniquity more than speaking righteousness.
verses.textLa: Dilexisti malitiam super benignitatem: iniquitatem magis quam loqui æquitatem.

verses.textEn: You have loved all precipitous words, you deceitful tongue.
verses.textLa: Dilexisti omnia verba præcipitationis, lingua dolosa.

verses.textEn: Because of this, God will destroy you in the end. He will pull you up, and he will remove you from your tabernacle and your root from the land of the living.
verses.textLa: Propterea Deus destruet te in finem, evellet te, et emigrabit te de tabernaculo tuo: et radicem tuam de terra viventium.

verses.textEn: The just will see and be afraid, and they will laugh over him, and say:
verses.textLa: Videbunt iusti, et timebunt, et super eum ridebunt, et dicent:

verses.textEn: “Behold the man who did not set God as his helper. But he hoped in the multitude of his riches, and so he prevailed in his emptiness.”
verses.textLa: ecce homo, qui non posuit Deum adiutorem suum: Sed speravit in multitudine divitiarum suarum: et prævaluit in vanitate sua.

verses.textEn: But I, like a fruitful olive tree in the house of God, have hoped in the mercy of God unto eternity, and forever and ever.
verses.textLa: Ego autem, sicut oliva fructifera in domo Dei, speravi in misericordia Dei in æternum: et in sæculum sæculi.

verses.textEn: I will confess to you forever, because you have accomplished it. And I will wait on your name, for it is good in the sight of your saints.
verses.textLa: Confitebor tibi in sæculum quia fecisti: et expectabo nomen tuum, quoniam bonum est in conspectu sanctorum tuorum.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For Mahalath: the thoughts of David. The fool has said in his heart, “There is no God.”
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro Maeleth intelligentiæ David. Dixit insipiens in corde suo: Non est Deus.

verses.textEn: They were corrupted, and they became abominable with iniquities. There is no one who does good.
verses.textLa: Corrupti sunt, et abominabiles facti sunt in iniquitatibus: non est qui faciat bonum.

verses.textEn: God gazed down from heaven on the sons of men, to see if there were any who were considering or seeking God.
verses.textLa: Deus de cælo prospexit super filios hominum: ut videat si est intelligens, aut requirens Deum.

verses.textEn: All have gone astray; together they have become useless. There is no one who does good; there is not even one.
verses.textLa: Omnes declinaverunt, simul inutiles facti sunt: non est qui faciat bonum, non est usque ad unum.

verses.textEn: Will they never learn: all those who work iniquity, who devour my people like a meal of bread?
verses.textLa: Nonne scient omnes qui operantur iniquitatem, qui devorant plebem meam ut cibum panis?

verses.textEn: They have not called upon God. In that place, they have trembled in fear, where there was no fear. For God has scattered the bones of those who please men. They have been confounded, because God has spurned them.
verses.textLa: Deum non invocaverunt: illic trepidaverunt timore, ubi non erat timor. Quoniam Deus dissipavit ossa eorum qui hominibus placent: confusi sunt, quoniam Deus sprevit eos.

verses.textEn: Who will grant from Zion the salvation of Israel? Jacob will exult, when God will convert the captivity of his people; and Israel will rejoice.
verses.textLa: Quis dabit ex Sion salutare Israel? cum converterit Deus captivitatem plebis suæ, exultabit Iacob, et lætabitur Israel.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. In verses, the understanding of David,
verses.textLa: In finem, In carminibus, intellectus David,

verses.textEn: when the Ziphites had arrived and they said to Saul, “Has not David been hidden with us?”
verses.textLa: Cum venissent Ziphæi, et dixissent ad Saul: Nonne David absconditus est apud nos?

verses.textEn: Save me, O God, by your name, and judge me in your virtue.
verses.textLa: Deus in nomine tuo salvum me fac: et in virtute tua iudica me.

verses.textEn: O God, listen to my prayer. Pay attention to the words of my mouth.
verses.textLa: Deus exaudi orationem meam: auribus percipe verba oris mei.

verses.textEn: For strangers have risen up against me, and the strong have sought my soul. And they have not set God before their eyes.
verses.textLa: Quoniam alieni insurrexerunt adversum me, et fortes quæsierunt animam meam: et non proposuerunt Deum ante conspectum suum.

verses.textEn: For behold, God is my helper, and the Lord is the protector of my soul.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim Deus adiuvat me: et Dominus susceptor est animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: Turn back the evils upon my adversaries, and ruin them by your truth.
verses.textLa: Averte mala inimicis meis: et in veritate tua disperde illos.

verses.textEn: I will freely sacrifice to you, and I will confess your name, O God, because it is good.
verses.textLa: Voluntarie sacrificabo tibi, et confitebor nomini tuo Domine: quoniam bonum est:

verses.textEn: For you have quickly rescued me from all tribulation, and my eye has looked down upon my enemies.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ex omni tribulatione eripuisti me: et super inimicos meos despexit oculus meus.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. In verses, the understanding of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, In carminibus, intellectus David.

verses.textEn: Listen to my prayer, O God, and despise not my supplication.
verses.textLa: Exaudi Deus orationem meam, et ne despexeris deprecationem meam:

verses.textEn: Be attentive to me, and heed me. I have been grieved in my training, and I have been disturbed
verses.textLa: intende mihi, et exaudi me. Contristatus sum in exercitatione mea: et conturbatus sum

verses.textEn: at the voice of the adversary and at the tribulation of the sinner. For they have diverted iniquities toward me, and they have been harassing me with rage.
verses.textLa: a voce inimici, et a tribulatione peccatoris. Quoniam declinaverunt in me iniquitates, et in ira molesti erant mihi.

verses.textEn: My heart has become disturbed within me, and the dread of death has fallen over me.
verses.textLa: Cor meum conturbatum est in me: et formido mortis cecidit super me.

verses.textEn: Fear and trembling have overwhelmed me, and darkness has buried me.
verses.textLa: Timor et tremor venerunt super me: et contexerunt me tenebræ:

verses.textEn: And I said, “Who will give me wings like the dove, so that I may fly away and take rest?”
verses.textLa: Et dixi: Quis dabit mihi pennas sicut columbæ, et volabo, et requiescam?

verses.textEn: Behold, I have fled far away, and I linger in solitude.
verses.textLa: Ecce elongavi fugiens: et mansi in solitudine.

verses.textEn: I waited for him who saved me from a weak-minded spirit and from a tempest.
verses.textLa: Expectabam eum, qui salvum me fecit a pusillanimitate spiritus, et tempestate.
verses.notes: The word ‘pusillanimitate’ is actually two Latin words put together. The first refers to a very young animal, but is used to express the idea of weakness. The second word refers to the mind, or soul, or spirit. The effect of putting the two words together results in an expression of the idea of a weak soul or a weak mind. Thus, ‘pusillanimitate spiritus’ refers to a weak-minded soul. The last word, ‘tempestate,’ in this context, refers not to a literal wind-storm, but to a tempest of the mind and soul, i.e. to inner turmoil. It can also be taken to refer to a storm of words or of various kinds of opposition to truth and justice.

verses.textEn: Cast them down, O Lord, and divide their tongues. For I have seen iniquity and contradiction in the city.
verses.textLa: Præcipita Domine, divide linguas eorum: quoniam vidi iniquitatem, et contradictionem in civitate.

verses.textEn: Day and night, iniquity will surround it upon its walls, and hardship is in its midst,
verses.textLa: Die ac nocte circumdabit eam super muros eius iniquitas: et labor in medio eius,

verses.textEn: with injustice. And usury and deceit have not fallen away from its streets.
verses.textLa: et iniustitia. Et non defecit de plateis eius usura et dolus.

verses.textEn: For if my enemy had spoken evil about me, certainly, I would have sustained it. And if he who hated me had been speaking great things against me, I would perhaps have hidden myself from him.
verses.textLa: Quoniam si inimicus meus maledixisset mihi, sustinuissem utique. Et si is, qui oderat me, super me magna locutus fuisset: abscondissem me forsitan ab eo.

verses.textEn: Truly, you are a man of one mind: my leader and my acquaintance,
verses.textLa: Tu vero homo unanimis: dux meus, et notus meus:

verses.textEn: who took sweet food together with me. In the house of God, we walked side-by-side.
verses.textLa: Qui simul mecum dulces capiebas cibos: in domo Dei ambulavimus cum consensu.
verses.notes: The expression ‘ambulavimus cum consensu’ means to agree to walk together, much like the English expression, ‘we walked side-by-side.’

verses.textEn: Let death come upon them, and let them descend alive into Hellfire. For there is wickedness in their dwellings, in their midst.
verses.textLa: Veniat mors super illos: et descendant in infernum viventes: Quoniam nequitiæ in habitaculis eorum: in medio eorum.
verses.notes: The Book of Revelation teaches that the Antichrist and the false prophet will be thrown alive into the fires of Hell. Those who are still alive on earth at the time of the general Resurrection, and who are unrepentant evil-doers, will also be sent alive into the fires of Hell, with a resurrected body and soul.

verses.textEn: But I have cried out to God, and the Lord will save me.
verses.textLa: Ego autem ad Deum clamavi: et Dominus salvabit me.

verses.textEn: Evening and morning and midday, I will discourse and announce, and he will heed my voice.
verses.textLa: Vespere, et mane, et meridie narrabo et annuntiabo: et exaudiet vocem meam.

verses.textEn: He will redeem my soul in peace from those who draw near to me. For, among the many, they were with me.
verses.textLa: Redimet in pace animam meam ab his, qui appropinquant mihi: quoniam inter multos erant mecum.

verses.textEn: God will hear, and He who is before time will humble them. For there is no change with them, and they have not feared God.
verses.textLa: Exaudiet Deus, et humiliabit illos, qui est ante sæcula. Non enim est illis commutatio, et non timuerunt Deum:

verses.textEn: He has stretched forth his hand in retribution. They have contaminated his covenant.
verses.textLa: extendit manum suam in retribuendo. Contaminaverunt testamentum eius,

verses.textEn: They were divided by the wrath of his countenance, and his heart has drawn near. His words are smoother than oil, and they are arrows.
verses.textLa: divisi sunt ab ira vultus eius: et appropinquavit cor illius. Molliti sunt sermones eius super oleum: et ipsi sunt iacula.

verses.textEn: Cast your cares upon the Lord, and he will nurture you. He will not allow the just to be tossed about forever.
verses.textLa: Iacta super Dominum curam tuam, et ipse te enutriet: non dabit in æternum fluctuationem iusto.

verses.textEn: Truly, O God, you will lead them away into the well of death. Bloody and deceitful men will not divide their days in half. But I will hope in you, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Tu vero Deus deduces eos, in puteum interitus. Viri sanguinum, et dolosi non dimidiabunt dies suos: ego autem sperabo in te Domine.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the people who have become far removed from the Sacred. Of David, with the inscription of a title, when the Philistines held him in Gath.
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro populo, qui a Sanctis longe factus est, David in tituli inscriptionem, cum tenuerunt eum Allophyli in Geth.
verses.notes: Or, ‘far from what is holy.’

verses.textEn: Have mercy on me, O God, because man has trampled over me. All day long, he has afflicted me by fighting against me.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Deus, quoniam conculcavit me homo: tota die impugnans tribulavit me.

verses.textEn: My enemies have trampled over me all day long. For those who make war against me are many.
verses.textLa: Conculcaverunt me inimici mei tota die: quoniam multi bellantes adversum me.

verses.textEn: From the height of the day, I will be afraid. But truly, I will hope in you.
verses.textLa: Ab altitudine diei timebo: ego vero in te sperabo.

verses.textEn: In God, I will praise my words. In God, I have put my trust. I will not fear what flesh can do to me.
verses.textLa: In Deo laudabo sermones meos, in Deo speravi: non timebo quid faciat mihi caro.

verses.textEn: All day long, they curse my words. All their intentions are for evil against me.
verses.textLa: Tota die verba mea execrabantur: adversum me omnes cogitationes eorum, in malum.

verses.textEn: They will dwell and hide themselves. They will watch my heel, just as they waited for my soul;
verses.textLa: Inhabitabunt et abscondent: ipsi calcaneum meum observabunt. Sicut sustinuerunt animam meam,

verses.textEn: because of this, nothing will save them. In your anger, you will crush the people.
verses.textLa: pro nihilo salvos facies illos: in ira populos confringes.

verses.textEn: O God, I have announced my life to you. You have placed my tears in your sight, and even in your promise.
verses.textLa: Deus, vitam meam annunciavi tibi: posuisti lacrymas meas in conspectu tuo, Sicut et in promissione tua:

verses.textEn: Then my enemies will be turned back. On whatever day that I call upon you, behold, I know that you are my God.
verses.textLa: tunc convertentur inimici mei retrorsum: In quacumque die invocavero te: ecce cognovi quoniam Deus meus es.

verses.textEn: In God, I will praise the word. In the Lord, I will praise his speech. In God, I have hoped. I will not fear what man can do to me.
verses.textLa: In Deo laudabo verbum, in Domino laudabo sermonem: in Deo speravi, non timebo quid faciat mihi homo.

verses.textEn: My vows to you, O God, are in me. I will repay them. Praises be to you.
verses.textLa: In me sunt Deus vota tua, quæ reddam, laudationes tibi.

verses.textEn: For you have rescued my soul from death and my feet from slipping, so that I may be pleasing in the sight of God, in the light of the living.
verses.textLa: Quoniam eripuisti animam meam de morte, et pedes meos de lapsu: ut placeam coram Deo in lumine viventium.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. May you not destroy. Of David, with the inscription of a title, when he fled from Saul into a cave.
verses.textLa: In finem, Ne disperdas, David in tituli inscriptionem, cum fugeret a facie Saul in speluncam.

verses.textEn: Be merciful to me, O God, be merciful to me. For my soul trusts in you. And I will hope in the shadow of your wings, until iniquity passes away.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Deus, miserere mei: quoniam in te confidit anima mea. Et in umbra alarum tuarum sperabo, donec transeat iniquitas.

verses.textEn: I will cry out to God Most High, to God who has been kind to me.
verses.textLa: Clamabo ad Deum altissimum: Deum qui benefecit mihi.

verses.textEn: He sent from heaven and freed me. He has surrendered into disgrace those who trampled me. God has sent his mercy and his truth.
verses.textLa: Misit de cælo, et liberavit me: dedit in opprobrium conculcantes me. Misit Deus misericordiam suam, et veritatem suam,

verses.textEn: And he has rescued my soul from the midst of the young lions. I slept troubled. The sons of men: their teeth are weapons and arrows, and their tongue is a sharp sword.
verses.textLa: et eripuit animam meam de medio catulorum leonum: dormivi conturbatus. Filii hominum dentes eorum arma et sagittæ: et lingua eorum gladius acutus.

verses.textEn: Be exalted above the heavens, O God, and your glory above all the earth.
verses.textLa: Exaltare super cælos Deus: et in omnem terram gloria tua.

verses.textEn: They prepared a snare for my feet, and they bowed down my soul. They dug a pit before my face, yet they have fallen into it.
verses.textLa: Laqueum paraverunt pedibus meis: et incurvaverunt animam meam. Foderunt ante faciem meam foveam: et inciderunt in eam.

verses.textEn: My heart is prepared, O God, my heart is prepared. I will sing, and I will compose a psalm.
verses.textLa: Paratum cor meum Deus, paratum cor meum: cantabo, et psalmum dicam.
verses.notes: Again, ‘psalmum dicam’ could be translated as ‘recite a psalm.’ But, after all the great and merciful things that this and other psalms say that God has done, is the response of the Psalmist merely to recite a psalm. Is not the one who wrote this psalm a composer of psalms? So then, his response would not be merely to recite a memorized psalm, but to compose one. Psalms were composed in ancient times, not so much by sitting down and writing, but by speaking the psalm first, and writing it later.

verses.textEn: Rise up, my glory. Rise up, psaltery and harp. I will arise in early morning.
verses.textLa: Exurge gloria mea, exurge psalterium et cithara: exurgam diluculo.

verses.textEn: I will confess to you, O Lord, among the peoples. I will compose a psalm to you among the nations.
verses.textLa: Confitebor tibi in populis Domine: et psalmum dicam tibi in gentibus:

verses.textEn: For your mercy has been magnified, even to the heavens, and your truth, even to the clouds.
verses.textLa: Quoniam magnificata est usque ad cælos misericordia tua, et usque ad nubes veritas tua.

verses.textEn: Be exalted above the heavens, O God, and your glory above all the earth.
verses.textLa: Exaltare super cælos Deus: et super omnem terram gloria tua.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. May you not destroy. Of David, with the inscription of a title.
verses.textLa: In finem, Ne disperdas, David in tituli inscriptionem.

verses.textEn: If, truly and certainly, you speak justice, then judge what is right, you sons of men.
verses.textLa: Si vere utique iustitiam loquimini: recta iudicate filii hominum.

verses.textEn: For, even in your heart, you work iniquity. Your hands construct injustice on the earth.
verses.textLa: Etenim in corde iniquitates operamini: in terra iniustitias manus vestræ concinnant.

verses.textEn: Sinners have become foreigners from the womb; they have gone astray from conception. They have been speaking falsehoods.
verses.textLa: Alienati sunt peccatores a vulva, erraverunt ab utero: locuti sunt falsa.
verses.notes: The word ‘vulva’ is feminine and refers to the womb or to the female’s generative capability. The word ‘utero’ is masculine and, in this context, refers to the male generative capability. It is not a second reference to the womb. Here the Scriptures are saying that the sinful tendencies of human persons comes from being conceived of fallen men and fallen women.

verses.textEn: Their fury is similar to that of a serpent; it is like a deaf asp, who even blocks her ears,
verses.textLa: Furor illis secundum similitudinem serpentis: sicut aspidis surdæ, et obturantis aures suas,

verses.textEn: who will not listen to the voice of charmers, nor even to the enchanter who chants wisely.
verses.textLa: quæ non exaudiet vocem incantantium: et venefici incantantis sapienter.

verses.textEn: God will crush their teeth within their own mouth. The Lord will break the molars of the lions.
verses.textLa: Deus conteret dentes eorum in ore ipsorum: molas leonum confringet Dominus.

verses.textEn: They will come to nothing, like water flowing away. He has aimed his bow, while they are being weakened.
verses.textLa: Ad nihilum devenient tamquam aqua decurrens: intendit arcum suum donec infirmentur.

verses.textEn: Like wax that flows, they will be carried away. Fire has fallen upon them, and they will not see the sun.
verses.textLa: Sicut cera, quæ fluit, auferentur: supercecidit ignis, et non viderunt solem.

verses.textEn: Before your thorns could know the brier, he consumes them alive, as if in rage.
verses.textLa: Priusquam intelligerent spinæ vestræ rhamnum: sicut viventes, sic in ira absorbet eos.
verses.notes: The expression ‘absorbet eos viventes’ is figurative, as indicated by ‘sicut.’ However, it is already clear in the English translation that ‘swallowing them alive’ or ‘consuming them alive’ is a figure of speech, so a word-for-word translation of ‘sicut’ is not necessary. The meaning of ‘sicut’ is implied in the English text.

verses.textEn: The just one will rejoice when he sees vindication. He will wash his hands in the blood of the sinner.
verses.textLa: Lætabitur iustus cum viderit vindictam: manus suas lavabit in sanguine peccatoris.

verses.textEn: And man will say, “If the just one is fruitful, then, truly, there is a God judging them on earth.”
verses.textLa: Et dicet homo: Si utique est fructus iusto: utique est Deus iudicans eos in terra.
verses.notes: Here the word ‘justo’ is singular, so it could be translated as ‘the just man,’ referring, on one level, to Christ. The teachings and sacrifice of Jesus Christ bear fruit, so man concludes that there is a God who judges the earth. But, on another level, the word ‘justo’ refers to the just in general, as indicated by the plural word ‘eos.’

verses.textEn: Unto the end. May you not destroy. Of David, with the inscription of a title, when Saul sent and watched his house, in order to execute him.
verses.textLa: In finem, Ne disperdas, David in tituli inscriptionem, quando misit Saul, et custodivit domum eius, ut eum interficeret.
verses.notes: Or, ‘Lest you destroy.’

verses.textEn: Rescue me from my enemies, my God, and free me from those who rise up against me.
verses.textLa: Eripe me de inimicis meis Deus meus: et ab insurgentibus in me libera me.

verses.textEn: Rescue me from those who work iniquity, and save me from men of blood.
verses.textLa: Eripe me de operantibus iniquitatem: et de viris sanguinum salva me.

verses.textEn: For behold, they have seized my soul. The strong have rushed upon me.
verses.textLa: Quia ecce ceperunt animam meam: irruerunt in me fortes.

verses.textEn: And it is neither my iniquity, nor my sin, O Lord. I have run and gone directly, without iniquity.
verses.textLa: Neque iniquitas mea, neque peccatum meum Domine: sine iniquitate cucurri, et direxi.

verses.textEn: Rise up to meet me, and see: even you, O Lord, the God of hosts, the God of Israel. Reach out to visit all nations. Do not take pity on all those who work iniquity.
verses.textLa: Exurge in occursum meum, et vide: et tu Domine Deus virtutum, Deus Israel, Intende ad visitandas omnes gentes: non miserearis omnibus, qui operantur iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: They will return toward evening, and they will suffer hunger like dogs, and they will wander around the city.
verses.textLa: Convertentur ad vesperam: et famem patientur ut canes, et circuibunt civitatem.

verses.textEn: Behold, they will speak with their mouth, and a sword is in their lips: “For who has heard us?”
verses.textLa: Ecce loquentur in ore suo, et gladius in labiis eorum: quoniam quis audivit?

verses.textEn: And you, O Lord, will laugh at them. You will lead all the Gentiles to nothing.
verses.textLa: Et tu Domine deridebis eos: ad nihilum deduces omnes Gentes.
verses.notes: In this context, from the point of view of Catholicism, the ‘Gentes’ (Gentiles) are not the non-Jews, but rather the non-believers, those who reject God and His Way.

verses.textEn: I will guard my strength toward you, for you are God, my supporter.
verses.textLa: Fortitudinem meam ad te custodiam, quia Deus susceptor meus es:
verses.notes: The Douay-Rheims and Challoner Douay-Rheims lack the word ‘God’ in this verse, even though the Clementine Vulgate has the word God. Occasional differences between the Douay and the Clementine Vulgate lead me to conclude that Challoner et al. were working from a slightly different edition of the Sixtus V and Clement VIII Latin Vulgate than I have available to me.

verses.textEn: My God, his mercy will precede me.
verses.textLa: Deus meus misericordia eius præveniet me.
verses.notes: Or, ‘his mercy will intercept me.’ Or, ‘his mercy will go before me.’

verses.textEn: God will oversee my enemies for me. Do not slay them, lest at times my people may forget them. Scatter them by your virtue. And depose them, O Lord, my protector,
verses.textLa: Deus ostendet mihi super inimicos meos, ne occidas eos: nequando obliviscantur populi mei. Disperge illos in virtute tua: et depone eos protector meus Domine:

verses.textEn: by the offense of their mouth and by the speech of their lips. And may they be caught in their arrogance. And, for their cursing and lying, they will be made known
verses.textLa: Delictum oris eorum, sermonem labiorum ipsorum: et comprehendantur in superbia sua. Et de execratione et mendacio annuntiabuntur

verses.textEn: at the consummation, in the fury of the consummation, and so they will be no more. And they will know that God will rule over Jacob, even to the ends of the earth.
verses.textLa: in consummatione: in ira consummationis, et non erunt. Et scient quia Deus dominabitur Iacob: et finium terræ.

verses.textEn: They will return toward evening, and they will suffer hunger like dogs, and they will wander around the city.
verses.textLa: Convertentur ad vesperam, et famem patientur ut canes: et circuibunt civitatem.

verses.textEn: They will be dispersed in order to gnaw, and truly, when they will not have been satisfied, they will murmur.
verses.textLa: Ipsi dispergentur ad manducandum: si vero non fuerint saturati, et murmurabunt.

verses.textEn: But I will sing your strength, and I will extol your mercy, in the morning. For you have been my supporter and my refuge in the day of my tribulation.
verses.textLa: Ego autem cantabo fortitudinem tuam: et exultabo mane misericordiam tuam. Quia factus es susceptor meus, et refugium meum, in die tribulationis meæ.

verses.textEn: To you, my helper, I will sing psalms. For you are God, my supporter. My God is my mercy.
verses.textLa: Adiutor meus tibi psallam, quia Deus susceptor meus es: Deus meus misericordia mea.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For those who will be changed, with the inscription of a title, of David himself, for instruction:
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro his, qui immutabuntur, in tituli inscriptionem ipsi David in doctrinam,

verses.textEn: when he set fire to Mesopotamia of Syria and Sobal, and Joab turned back and struck Idumea, in the valley of the salt pits, twelve thousand men.
verses.textLa: cum succendit Mesopotamiam Syriæ, et Sobal, et convertit Ioab, et percussit Idumæam in valle Salinarum duodecim millia.

verses.textEn: O God, you have rejected us, and you have ruined us. You became angry, and yet you have been merciful to us.
verses.textLa: Deus repulisti nos, et destruxisti nos: iratus es, et misertus es nobis.

verses.textEn: You have moved the earth, and you have disturbed it. Heal its breaches, for it has been moved.
verses.textLa: Commovisti terram, et conturbasti eam: sana contritiones eius, quia commota est.

verses.textEn: You have revealed to your people difficulties. You have made us drink the wine of remorse.
verses.textLa: Ostendisti populo tuo dura: potasti nos vino compunctionis.

verses.textEn: You have given a warning sign to those who fear you, so that they may flee from before the face of the bow, so that your beloved may be delivered.
verses.textLa: Dedisti metuentibus te significationem: ut fugiant a facie arcus: Ut liberentur dilecti tui:

verses.textEn: Save me with your right hand, and hear me.
verses.textLa: salvum fac dextera tua, et exaudi me.

verses.textEn: God has spoken in his holy place: I will rejoice, and I will divide Shechem, and I will measure the steep valley of the tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Deus locutus est in sancto suo: Lætabor, et partibor Sichimam: et convallem tabernaculorum metibor.

verses.textEn: Gilead is mine, and Manasseh is mine. And Ephraim is the strength of my head. Judah is my king.
verses.textLa: Meus est Galaad, et meus est Manasses: et Ephraim fortitudo capitis mei. Iuda rex meus:

verses.textEn: Moab is the cooking pot of my hope. Into Idumea, I will extend my shoe. To me, the foreigners have been made subject.
verses.textLa: Moab olla spei meæ. In Idumæam extendam calceamentum meum: mihi alienigenæ subditi sunt.

verses.textEn: Who will lead me into the fortified city? Who will lead me all the way to Idumea?
verses.textLa: Quis deducet me in civitatem munitam? quis deducet me usque in Idumæam?

verses.textEn: Will not you, O God, who has rejected us? And will not you, O God, go out with our armies?
verses.textLa: Nonne tu Deus, qui repulisti nos: et non egredieris Deus in virtutibus nostris?

verses.textEn: Grant us help from tribulation. For salvation from man is empty.
verses.textLa: Da nobis auxilium de tribulatione: quia vana salus hominis.

verses.textEn: In God, we will act virtuously. And those who trouble us, he will lead to nothing.
verses.textLa: In Deo faciemus virtutem: et ipse ad nihilum deducet tribulantes nos.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. With hymns, of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, In hymnis David.

verses.textEn: O God, pay attention to my supplication. Be attentive to my prayer.
verses.textLa: Exaudi Deus deprecationem meam: intende orationi meæ.

verses.textEn: I cried out to you from the ends of the earth. When my heart was in anguish, you exalted me on a rock. You have led me,
verses.textLa: A finibus terræ ad te clamavi: dum anxiaretur cor meum, in petra exaltasti me. Deduxisti me,

verses.textEn: for you have been my hope, a tower of strength before the face of the enemy.
verses.textLa: quia factus es spes mea: turris fortitudinis a facie inimici.

verses.textEn: I will dwell in your tabernacle forever. I will be protected under the cover of your wings.
verses.textLa: Inhabitabo in tabernaculo tuo in sæcula: protegar in velamento alarum tuarum.

verses.textEn: For you, my God, have listened to my prayer. You have granted an inheritance to those who fear your name.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu Deus meus exaudisti orationem meam: dedisti hereditatem timentibus nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: You will add days to the days of the king, to his years, even to the time of generation after generation.
verses.textLa: Dies super dies regis adiicies: annos eius usque in diem generationis et generationis.

verses.textEn: He remains in eternity, in the sight of God. Who will long for his mercy and truth?
verses.textLa: Permanet in æternum in conspectu Dei: misericordiam et veritatem eius quis requiret?

verses.textEn: So I will compose a psalm to your name, forever and ever, so that I may repay my vows from day to day.
verses.textLa: Sic psalmum dicam nomini tuo in sæculum sæculi: ut reddam vota mea de die in diem.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For Jeduthun. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro Idithun, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: Will my soul not be subject to God? For from him is my salvation.
verses.textLa: Nonne Deo subiecta erit anima mea? ab ipso enim salutare meum.

verses.textEn: Yes, he himself is my God and my salvation. He is my supporter; I will be moved no more.
verses.textLa: Nam et ipse Deus meus, et salutaris meus: susceptor meus, non movebor amplius.

verses.textEn: How is it that you rush against a man? Every one of you puts to death, as if you were pulling down a ruined wall, leaning over and falling apart.
verses.textLa: Quousque irruitis in hominem? interficitis universi vos: tamquam parieti inclinato et maceriæ depulsæ.
verses.notes: The word ‘parieti’ refers to a ruined wall. The addition of the phrase ‘inclinato et maceriæ,’ further describes the wall as leaning over and falling apart. The word ‘maceriæ’ is often used to describe a garden wall, because garden walls have no mortar; they are simply one stone on another. Thus the word ‘maceriæ,’ in this context, refers to a wall that has lost its mortar and is therefore falling apart.

verses.textEn: So, truly, they intended to reject my price. I ran in thirst. They blessed with their mouth and cursed with their heart.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen pretium meum cogitaverunt repellere, cucurri in siti: ore suo benedicebant, et corde suo maledicebant.

verses.textEn: Yet, truly, my soul will be subject to God. For from him is my patience.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen Deo subiecta esto anima mea: quoniam ab ipso patientia mea.

verses.textEn: For he is my God and my Savior. He is my helper; I will not be expelled.
verses.textLa: Quia ipse Deus meus, et salvator meus: adiutor meus, non emigrabo.

verses.textEn: In God is my salvation and my glory. He is the God of my help, and my hope is in God.
verses.textLa: In Deo salutare meum, et gloria mea: Deus auxilii mei, et spes mea in Deo est.

verses.textEn: All peoples gathered together: trust in him. Pour out your hearts in his sight. God is our helper for eternity.
verses.textLa: Sperate in eo omnis congregatio populi, effundite coram illo corda vestra: Deus adiutor noster in æternum.

verses.textEn: So, truly, the sons of men are untrustworthy. The sons of men are liars in the scales, so that, by emptiness, they may deceive among themselves.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen vani filii hominum, mendaces filii hominum in stateris: ut decipiant ipsi de vanitate in idipsum.

verses.textEn: Do not trust in iniquity, and do not desire plunder. If riches flow toward you, do not be willing to set your heart on them.
verses.textLa: Nolite sperare in iniquitate, et rapinas nolite concupiscere: divitiæ si affluant, nolite cor apponere.

verses.textEn: God has spoken once. I have heard two things: that power belongs to God,
verses.textLa: Semel locutus est Deus, duo hæc audivi, quia potestas Dei est,

verses.textEn: and that mercy belongs to you, O Lord. For you will repay each one according to his works.
verses.textLa: et tibi Domine misericordia: quia tu reddes unicuique iuxta opera sua.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David, when he was in the desert of Idumea.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, Cum esset in deserto Idumææ.

verses.textEn: O God, my God: to you, I keep vigil until first light. For you, my soul has thirsted, to you my body, in so many ways.
verses.textLa: Deus, Deus meus, ad te de luce vigilo. Sitivit in te anima mea, quam multipliciter tibi caro mea.

verses.textEn: By a deserted land, both inaccessible and waterless, so I have appeared in the sanctuary before you, in order to behold your virtue and your glory.
verses.textLa: In terra deserta, et invia, et inaquosa: sic in sancto apparui tibi, ut viderem virtutem tuam, et gloriam tuam.

verses.textEn: For your mercy is better than life itself. It is you my lips will praise.
verses.textLa: Quoniam melior est misericordia tua super vitas: labia mea laudabunt te.

verses.textEn: So will I bless you in my life, and I will lift up my hands in your name.
verses.textLa: Sic benedicam te in vita mea: et in nomine tuo levabo manus meas.

verses.textEn: Let my soul be filled, as if with marrow and fatness; and my mouth will give praise with exultant lips.
verses.textLa: Sicut adipe et pinguedine repleatur anima mea: et labiis exultationis laudabit os meum.

verses.textEn: When I have remembered you on my bed in the morning, I will meditate on you.
verses.textLa: Si memor fui tui super stratum meum, in matutinis meditabor in te:

verses.textEn: For you have been my helper. And I will exult under the cover of your wings.
verses.textLa: quia fuisti adiutor meus. Et in velamento alarum tuarum exultabo,

verses.textEn: My soul has clung close to you. Your right hand has supported me.
verses.textLa: adhæsit anima mea post te: me suscepit dextera tua.

verses.textEn: Truly, these ones have sought my soul in vain. They will enter into the lower parts of the earth.
verses.textLa: Ipsi vero in vanum quæsierunt animam meam, introibunt in inferiora terræ:

verses.textEn: They will be delivered into the hand of the sword. They will be the portions of foxes.
verses.textLa: tradentur in manus gladii, partes vulpium erunt.

verses.textEn: Truly, the king will rejoice in God: all those who swear by him will be praised, because the mouth of those who speak iniquity has been blocked.
verses.textLa: Rex vero lætabitur in Deo, laudabuntur omnes qui iurant in eo: quia obstructum est os loquentium iniqua.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David.

verses.textEn: Hear, O God, my prayer of supplication. Rescue my soul from the fear of the enemy.
verses.textLa: Exaudi Deus orationem meam cum deprecor: a timore inimici eripe animam meam.

verses.textEn: You have protected me from the assembly of the malignant, from a multitude of workers of iniquity.
verses.textLa: Protexisti me a conventu malignantium: a multitudine operantium iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: For they have sharpened their tongues like a sword; they have formed their bow into a bitter thing,
verses.textLa: Quia exacuerunt ut gladium linguas suas: intenderunt arcum rem amaram,

verses.textEn: so that they may shoot arrows from hiding at the immaculate.
verses.textLa: ut sagittent in occultis immaculatum.

verses.textEn: They will suddenly shoot arrows at him, and they will not be afraid. They are resolute in their wicked talk. They have discussed hidden snares. They have said, “Who will see them?”
verses.textLa: Subito sagittabunt eum, et non timebunt: firmaverunt sibi sermonem nequam. Narraverunt ut absconderent laqueos: dixerunt: Quis videbit eos?

verses.textEn: They have been searching carefully for iniquities. Their exhaustive search has failed. Man will approach with a deep heart,
verses.textLa: Scrutati sunt iniquitates: defecerunt scrutantes scrutinio. Accedet homo ad cor altum:
verses.notes: The repetition in the phrase ‘defecerunt scrutantes scrutinio’ indicates intensity. It is best expressed by rephrasing the sentence so that the search is the subject: ‘their exhaustive search has failed,’ rather than ‘they have failed in their exhaustive search.’ The meaning is that the wicked have searched for iniquities so as to make an accusation against the just; but they fail to find any true accusation to make.

verses.textEn: and God will be exalted. The arrows of the little ones have become their wounds,
verses.textLa: et exaltabitur Deus. Sagittæ parvulorum factæ sunt plagæ eorum:

verses.textEn: and their tongues have been weakened against them. All those who saw them have been troubled;
