verses.textLa: et infirmatæ sunt contra eos linguæ eorum. Conturbati sunt omnes qui videbant eos:

verses.textEn: and every man was afraid. And they announced the works of God, and they understood his acts.
verses.textLa: et timuit omnis homo. Et annunciaverunt opera Dei: et facta eius intellexerunt.

verses.textEn: The just will rejoice in the Lord, and they will hope in him. And all the upright of heart will be praised.
verses.textLa: Lætabitur iustus in Domino, et sperabit in eo, et laudabuntur omnes recti corde.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David. A Canticle of Jeremiah and Ezekiel to the people of the captivity, when they began to go into exile.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David, Canticum Hieremiæ, et Ezechielis populo transmigrationis, cum inciperent exire.

verses.textEn: O God, a hymn adorns you in Zion, and a vow will be repaid to you in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Te decet hymnus Deus in Sion: et tibi reddetur votum in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: Hear my prayer: all flesh will come to you.
verses.textLa: Exaudi orationem meam: ad te omnis caro veniet.

verses.textEn: Words of iniquity have prevailed over us. And you will pardon our impieties.
verses.textLa: Verba iniquorum prævaluerunt super nos: et impietatibus nostris tu propitiaberis.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he whom you have chosen and taken up. He will dwell in your courts. We will be filled with the good things of your house. Holy is your temple:
verses.textLa: Beatus, quem elegisti, et assumpsisti: inhabitabit in atriis tuis. Replebimur in bonis domus tuæ: sanctum est templum tuum,

verses.textEn: wonderful in equity. Hear us, O God our Savior, the hope of all the ends of the earth and of a sea far away.
verses.textLa: mirabile in æquitate. Exaudi nos Deus salutaris noster, spes omnium finium terræ, et in mari longe.

verses.textEn: You prepare the mountains in your virtue, wrapped with power.
verses.textLa: Præparans montes in virtute tua, accinctus potentia:

verses.textEn: You stir up the depths of the sea, the noise of its waves. The nations will be troubled,
verses.textLa: qui conturbas profundum maris sonum fluctuum eius. Turbabuntur gentes,

verses.textEn: and those who dwell at the limits will be afraid, before your signs. You will make the passing of morning and evening enjoyable.
verses.textLa: et timebunt qui habitant terminos a signis tuis: exitus matutini et vespere delectabis.

verses.textEn: You have visited the earth, and you have saturated it. You have enriched it in so many ways. The river of God has been filled with water. You have prepared their food. For thus is its preparation.
verses.textLa: Visitasti terram et inebriasti eam: multiplicasti locupletare eam. Flumen Dei repletum est aquis, parasti cibum illorum: quoniam ita est præparatio eius.

verses.textEn: Drench its streams, multiply its fruits; it will spring up and rejoice in its showers.
verses.textLa: Rivos eius inebria, multiplica genimina eius: in stillicidiis eius lætabitur germinans.

verses.textEn: You will bless the crown of the year with your kindness, and your fields will be filled with abundance.
verses.textLa: Benedices coronæ anni benignitatis tuæ: et campi tui replebuntur ubertate.

verses.textEn: The beauty of the desert will fatten, and the hills will be wrapped with exultation.
verses.textLa: Pinguescent speciosa deserti: et exultatione colles accingentur.

verses.textEn: The rams of the sheep have been clothed, and the valleys will abound with grain. They will cry out; yes, they will even utter a hymn.
verses.textLa: Induti sunt arietes ovium, et valles abundabunt frumento: clamabunt, etenim hymnum dicent.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Canticle Psalm of the Resurrection. Shout joyfully to God, all the earth.
verses.textLa: In finem, Canticum Psalmi Resurrectionis. Iubilate Deo omnis terra,

verses.textEn: Proclaim a psalm to his name. Give glory to his praise.
verses.textLa: psalmum dicite nomini eius: date gloriam laudi eius.

verses.textEn: Exclaim to God, “How terrible are your works, O Lord!” According to the fullness of your virtue, your enemies will speak lies about you.
verses.textLa: Dicite Deo quam terribilia sunt opera tua Domine! in multitudine virtutis tuæ mentientur tibi inimici tui.

verses.textEn: Let all the earth adore you and sing psalms to you. May it sing a psalm to your name.
verses.textLa: Omnis terra adoret te, et psallat tibi: psalmum dicat nomini tuo.

verses.textEn: Draw near and see the works of God, who is terrible in his counsels over the sons of men.
verses.textLa: Venite, et videte opera Dei: terribilis in consiliis super filios hominum.

verses.textEn: He converts the sea into dry land. They will cross the river on foot. There, we will rejoice in him.
verses.textLa: Qui convertit mare in aridam, in flumine pertransibunt pede: ibi lætabimur in ipso.

verses.textEn: He rules by his virtue for eternity. His eyes gaze upon the nations. May those who exasperate him, not be exalted in themselves.
verses.textLa: Qui dominatur in virtute sua in æternum, oculi eius super gentes respiciunt: qui exasperant non exaltentur in semetipsis.

verses.textEn: Bless our God, you Gentiles, and make the voice of his praise be heard.
verses.textLa: Benedicite Gentes Deum nostrum: et auditam facite vocem laudis eius,

verses.textEn: He has set my soul toward life, and he has granted that my feet may not be shaken.
verses.textLa: Qui posuit animam meam ad vitam: et non dedit in commotionem pedes meos.

verses.textEn: For you, O God, have tested us. You have examined us by fire, just as silver is examined.
verses.textLa: Quoniam probasti nos Deus: igne nos examinasti, sicut examinatur argentum.

verses.textEn: You have led us into a snare. You have placed tribulations on our back.
verses.textLa: Induxisti nos in laqueum, posuisti tribulationes in dorso nostro:

verses.textEn: You have set men over our heads. We have crossed through fire and water. And you have led us out to refreshment.
verses.textLa: imposuisti homines super capita nostra. Transivimus per ignem et aquam: et eduxisti nos in refrigerium.

verses.textEn: I will enter your house with holocausts. I will repay my vows to you,
verses.textLa: Introibo in domum tuam in holocaustis: reddam tibi vota mea,

verses.textEn: which my lips discerned and my mouth spoke, in my tribulation.
verses.textLa: quæ distinxerunt labia mea. Et locutum est os meum, in tribulatione mea.

verses.textEn: I will offer to you holocausts full of marrow, with the burnt offerings of rams. I will offer to you bulls as well as goats.
verses.textLa: Holocausta medullata offeram tibi cum incenso arietum: offeram tibi boves cum hircis.

verses.textEn: Draw near and listen, all you who fear God, and I will describe to you how much he has done for my soul.
verses.textLa: Venite, audite, et narrabo, omnes qui timetis Deum, quanta fecit animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: I cried out to him with my mouth, and I extolled him under my breath.
verses.textLa: Ad ipsum ore meo clamavi, et exaltavi sub lingua mea.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘sub lingua mea’ is a figurative expression similar to the English expression ‘under my breath.’

verses.textEn: If I have seen iniquity in my heart, the Lord would not heed me.
verses.textLa: Iniquitatem si aspexi in corde meo, non exaudiet Dominus.

verses.textEn: And yet, God has heeded me and he has attended to the voice of my supplication.
verses.textLa: Propterea exaudivit Deus, et attendit voci deprecationis meæ.

verses.textEn: Blessed is God, who has not removed my prayer, nor his mercy, from me.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Deus, qui non amovit orationem meam, et misericordiam suam a me.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. With hymns, a Canticle Psalm of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, In hymnis, Psalmus Cantici David.

verses.textEn: May God have mercy on us and bless us. May he shine his countenance upon us, and may he have mercy on us.
verses.textLa: Deus misereatur nostri, et benedicat nobis: illuminet vultum suum super nos, et misereatur nostri.

verses.textEn: So may we know your way upon the earth, your salvation among all nations.
verses.textLa: Ut cognascamus in terra viam tuam: in omnibus gentibus salutare tuum.

verses.textEn: Let the peoples confess to you, O God. Let all the peoples confess to you.
verses.textLa: Confiteantur tibi populi Deus: confiteantur tibi populi omnes.

verses.textEn: May the nations rejoice and exult. For you judge the peoples with equity, and you direct the nations on earth.
verses.textLa: Lætentur et exultent gentes: quoniam iudicas populos in æquitate, et gentes in terra dirigis.

verses.textEn: Let the peoples confess to you, O God. Let all the peoples confess to you.
verses.textLa: Confiteantur tibi populi Deus: confiteantur tibi populi omnes.

verses.textEn: The earth has provided her fruit. May God, our God, bless us.
verses.textLa: Terra dedit fructum suum. Benedicat nos Deus, Deus noster,

verses.textEn: May God bless us, and may all the ends of the earth fear him.
verses.textLa: benedicat nos Deus: et metuant eum omnes fines terræ.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Canticle Psalm of David himself.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus Cantici ipsi David.

verses.textEn: May God rise up, and may his enemies be scattered, and may those who hate him flee from before his face.
verses.textLa: Exurgat Deus, et dissipentur inimici eius, et fugiant qui oderunt eum, a facie eius.

verses.textEn: Just as smoke vanishes, so may they vanish. Just as wax flows away before the face of fire, so may sinners pass away before the face of God.
verses.textLa: Sicut deficit fumus, deficiant: sicut fluit cera a facie ignis, sic pereant peccatores a facie Dei.

verses.textEn: And so, let the just feast, and let them exult in the sight of God and be delighted in gladness.
verses.textLa: Et iusti epulentur, et exultent in conspectu Dei: et delectentur in lætitia.

verses.textEn: Sing to God, sing a psalm to his name. Make a path for him, who ascends over the west. The Lord is his name. Exult in his sight; they will be stirred up before his face,
verses.textLa: Cantate Deo, psalmum dicite nomini eius: iter facite ei, qui ascendit super occasum: Dominus nomen illi. Exultate in conspectu eius, turbabuntur a facie eius,

verses.textEn: the father of orphans and the judge of widows. God is in his holy place.
verses.textLa: patris orphanorum, et iudicis viduarum. Deus in loco sancto suo:

verses.textEn: It is God who makes men dwell in a house under one custom. He leads out those who are strongly bound, and similarly, those who exasperate, who dwell in sepulchers.
verses.textLa: Deus qui inhabitare facit unius moris in domo: Qui educit vinctos in fortitudine, similiter eos, qui exasperant, qui habitant in sepulchris.
verses.notes: This verse refers to men who dwell together under one set of rules (as in a religious order), or under an agreed upon set of behaviors or morals. It indicates harmony, as opposed to conflict.

verses.textEn: O God, when you departed in the sight of your people, when you passed through the desert,
verses.textLa: Deus cum egredereris in conspectu populi tui, cum pertransires in deserto,

verses.textEn: the earth was moved, for the heavens rained down before the face of the God of Sinai, before the face of the God of Israel.
verses.textLa: terra mota est, etenim cæli distillaverunt a facie Dei Sinai, a facie Dei Israel.
verses.notes: This verse is not saying merely that it rained, but rather that the heaven rained down blessing upon the earth.

verses.textEn: You will set aside for your inheritance, O God, a willing rain. And though it was weak, truly, you have made it perfect.
verses.textLa: Pluviam voluntariam segregabis Deus hereditati tuæ: et infirmata est, tu vero perfecisti eam.

verses.textEn: Your animals will dwell in it. O God, in your sweetness, you have provided for the poor.
verses.textLa: Animalia tua habitabunt in ea: parasti in dulcedine tua pauperi, Deus.

verses.textEn: The Lord will give the word to evangelizers, along with great virtue.
verses.textLa: Dominus dabit verbum evangelizantibus, virtute multa.

verses.textEn: The King of virtue is beloved among the beloved. And the beauty of the house will divide spoils.
verses.textLa: Rex virtutum dilecti dilecti: et speciei domus dividere spolia.
verses.notes: Or, ‘the beloved of the beloved.’

verses.textEn: If you take your rest in the midst of the clergy, you will be like a dove whose wings are covered with fine silver and edged with pale gold.
verses.textLa: Si dormiatis inter medios cleros, pennæ columbæ deargentatæ, et posteriora dorsi eius in pallore auri.

verses.textEn: When heaven discerns kings to be over her, they will be whitened with the snows of Zalmon.
verses.textLa: Dum discernit cælestis reges super eam, nive dealbabuntur in Selmon:

verses.textEn: The mountain of God is a fat mountain, a dense mountain, a thick mountain.
verses.textLa: mons Dei, mons pinguis. Mons coagulatus, mons pinguis:

verses.textEn: So then, why are you distrustful of dense mountains? The mountain on which God is well pleased to dwell, even there, the Lord will dwell until the end.
verses.textLa: ut quid suspicamini montes coagulatos? Mons, in quo beneplacitum est Deo habitare in eo: etenim Dominus habitabit in finem.

verses.textEn: The chariot of God is ten thousand fold: thousands rejoice. The Lord is with them in Sinai, in the holy place.
verses.textLa: Currus Dei decem millibus multiplex, millia lætantium: Dominus in eis in Sina in sancto.

verses.textEn: You have ascended on high; you have taken captivity captive. You have accepted gifts among men. For even those who do not believe dwell with the Lord God.
verses.textLa: Ascendisti in altum, cepisti captivitatem: accepisti dona in hominibus: Etenim non credentes, inhabitare Dominum Deum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord, day after day. The God of our salvation will make our journey prosper for us.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus die quotidie: prosperum iter faciet nobis Deus salutarium nostrorum.

verses.textEn: Our God is the God who will bring about our salvation, and our Lord is the Lord who has brought an end to death.
verses.textLa: Deus noster, Deus salvos faciendi: et Domini, Domini exitus mortis.
verses.notes: This sentence is fairly eloquent in Latin, but a strict translation into English would be inelegant and barely comprehensible. Thus a looser translation is used for this verse than is generally used for other verses.

verses.textEn: So then, truly, God will break the heads of his enemies, the hairy skull of those who wander around in their offenses.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen Deus confringet capita inimicorum suorum: verticem capilli perambulantium in delictis suis.

verses.textEn: The Lord said: I will turn them away from Bashan, I will turn them into the depths of the sea,
verses.textLa: Dixit Dominus: Ex Basan convertam, convertam in profundum maris:

verses.textEn: so that your feet may be soaked in the blood of your enemies, so that the tongue of your dogs may be soaked with the same.
verses.textLa: Ut intingatur pes tuus in sanguine: lingua canum tuorum ex inimicis, ab ipso.
verses.notes:
Here is an example of a slight departure of the Challoner version from the Clementine Vulgate. The latter contains no reference to the color red, but the former does use the word ‘red.’
 Note that ‘pes’ in Latin is singular, but the same type of expression in English uses the plural, so the translation uses the plural: ‘feet.’

verses.textEn: O God, they have seen your arrival, the arrival of my God, of my king who is in a holy place.
verses.textLa: Viderunt ingressus tuos Deus, ingressus Dei mei: regis mei qui est in sancto.

verses.textEn: The leaders went ahead, united with the singers of psalms, in the midst of girls playing on timbrels.
verses.textLa: Prævenerunt principes coniuncti psallentibus, in medio iuvencularum tympanistriarum.

verses.textEn: In the churches, bless the Lord God from the fountains of Israel.
verses.textLa: In ecclesiis, benedicite Deo Domino, de fontibus Israel.

verses.textEn: In that place, Benjamin is a youth in ecstasy of mind. The leaders of Judah are their governors: the leaders of Zebulun, the leaders of Naphtali.
verses.textLa: Ibi Beniamin adolescentulus, in mentis excessu. Principes Iuda, duces eorum: principes Zabulon, principes Nephthali.

verses.textEn: Command by your virtue, O God. Confirm in this place, O God, what you have wrought in us.
verses.textLa: Manda Deus virtuti tuæ: confirma hoc Deus, quod operatus es in nobis.

verses.textEn: Before your temple in Jerusalem, kings will offer gifts to you.
verses.textLa: A templo tuo in Ierusalem, tibi offerent reges munera.

verses.textEn: Rebuke the wild beasts of the reeds, a congregation of bulls with the cows of the people, for they seek to exclude those who have been tested like silver. Scatter the nations that are pleased by wars.
verses.textLa: Increpa feras arundinis, congregatio taurorum in vaccis populorum: ut excludant eos, qui probati sunt argento. Dissipa gentes, quæ bella volunt:

verses.textEn: Ambassadors will come out of Egypt. Ethiopia will offer in advance her hands to God.
verses.textLa: venient legati ex Ægypto: Æthiopia præveniet manus eius Deo.

verses.textEn: Sing to God, O kingdoms of the earth. Sing psalms to the Lord. Sing psalms to God.
verses.textLa: Regna terræ, cantate Deo: psallite Domino: psallite Deo.

verses.textEn: He ascends, up to the heaven of the heavens, toward the east. Behold, he will utter his voice, the voice of virtue.
verses.textLa: qui ascendit super cælum cæli, ad Orientem. Ecce dabit voci suæ vocem virtutis,

verses.textEn: Give glory to God beyond Israel. His magnificence and his virtue is in the clouds.
verses.textLa: date gloriam Deo super Israel, magnificentia eius, et virtus eius in nubibus.

verses.textEn: God is wonderful in his saints. The God of Israel himself will give virtue and strength to his people. Blessed is God.
verses.textLa: Mirabilis Deus in sanctis suis, Deus Israel ipse dabit virtutem, et fortitudinem plebi suæ, benedictus Deus.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For those who will be changed: of David.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro iis, qui commutabuntur, David.

verses.textEn: Save me, O God, for the waters have entered, even to my soul.
verses.textLa: Salvum me fac Deus: quoniam intraverunt aquæ usque ad animam meam.

verses.textEn: I have become stuck in a deep quagmire, and there is no firm footing. I have arrived at the height of the sea, and a tempest has overwhelmed me.
verses.textLa: Infixus sum in limo profundi: et non est substantia. Veni in altitudinem maris: et tempestas demersit me.

verses.textEn: I have endured hardships, while crying out. My jaws have become hoarse; my eyes have failed. Meanwhile, I hope in my God.
verses.textLa: Laboravi clamans, raucæ factæ sunt fauces meæ: defecerunt oculi mei, dum spero in Deum meum.

verses.textEn: Those who hate me without cause have been multiplied beyond the hairs of my head. My enemies, who persecuted me unjustly, have been strengthened. Then I was required to pay for what I did not take.
verses.textLa: Multiplicati sunt super capillos capitis mei, qui oderunt me gratis. Confortati sunt qui persecuti sunt me inimici mei iniuste: quæ non rapui, tunc exolvebam.

verses.textEn: O God, you know my foolishness, and my offenses have not been hidden from you.
verses.textLa: Deus tu scis insipientiam meam: et delicta mea a te non sunt abscondita.

verses.textEn: Let those who wait for you, O Lord, the Lord of hosts, not be shamed in me. Let those who seek you, O God of Israel, not be confounded over me.
verses.textLa: Non erubescant in me qui expectant te Domine, Domine virtutum. Non confundantur super me qui quærunt te, Deus Israel.

verses.textEn: For because of you, I have endured reproach; confusion has covered my face.
verses.textLa: Quoniam propter te sustinui opprobrium: operuit confusio faciem meam.

verses.textEn: I have become a stranger to my brothers and a sojourner to the sons of my mother.
verses.textLa: Extraneus factus sum fratribus meis, et peregrinus filiis matris meæ.

verses.textEn: For zeal for your house has consumed me, and the reproaches of those who reproached you have fallen upon me.
verses.textLa: Quoniam zelus domus tuæ comedit me: et opprobria exprobrantium tibi, ceciderunt super me.

verses.textEn: And I covered my soul with fasting, and it has become a reproach to me.
verses.textLa: Et operui in ieiunio animam meam: et factum est in opprobrium mihi.

verses.textEn: And I put on a haircloth as my garment, and I became a parable to them.
verses.textLa: Et posui vestimentum meum cilicium: et factus sum illis in parabolam.

verses.textEn: Those who sat at the gate spoke against me, and those who drank wine made me their song.
verses.textLa: Adversum me loquebantur qui sedebant in porta: et in me psallebant qui bibebant vinum.

verses.textEn: But as for me, truly, my prayer is to you, O Lord. This time has pleased you well, O God. In the multitude of your mercy, in the truth of your salvation, hear me.
verses.textLa: Ego vero orationem meam ad te Domine: tempus beneplaciti Deus. In multitudine misericordiæ tuæ exaudi me, in veritate salutis tuæ:

verses.textEn: Rescue me from the quagmire, so that I may not become trapped. Free me from those who hate me and from deep waters.
verses.textLa: Eripe me de luto, ut non infigar: libera me ab iis, qui oderunt me, et de profundis aquarum.

verses.textEn: Do not allow the tempest of water to submerge me, nor the deep to absorb me. And do not allow the well to close in on me.
verses.textLa: Non me demergat tempestas aquæ, neque absorbeat me profundum: neque urgeat super me puteus os suum.

verses.textEn: Hear me, O Lord, for your mercy is kind. Look upon me, according to the fullness of your compassion.
verses.textLa: Exaudi me Domine, quoniam benigna est misericordia tua: secundum multitudinem miserationum tuarum respice in me.

verses.textEn: And do not turn your face away from your servant, for I am in trouble: heed me quickly.
verses.textLa: Et ne avertas faciem tuam a puero tuo: quoniam tribulor, velociter exaudi me.

verses.textEn: Attend to my soul, and free it. Rescue me, because of my enemies.
verses.textLa: Intende animæ meæ, et libera eam: propter inimicos meos eripe me.

verses.textEn: You know my reproach, and my confusion, and my reverence.
verses.textLa: Tu scis improperium meum, et confusionem meam, et reverentiam meam.

verses.textEn: All those who trouble me are in your sight; my heart has anticipated reproach and misery. And I sought for one who might grieve together with me, but there was no one, and for one who might console me, and I found no one.
verses.textLa: In conspectu tuo sunt omnes qui tribulant me, improperium expectavit cor meum et miseriam. Et sustinui qui simul contristaretur, et non fuit: et qui consolaretur, et non inveni.

verses.textEn: And they gave me gall for my food. And in my thirst, they gave me vinegar to drink.
verses.textLa: Et dederunt in escam meam fel: et in siti mea potaverunt me aceto.

verses.textEn: Let their table be a snare before them, and a retribution, and a scandal.
verses.textLa: Fiat mensa eorum coram ipsis in laqueum, et in retributiones, et in scandalum.

verses.textEn: Let their eyes be darkened, so that they may not see, and may their back always be crooked.
verses.textLa: Obscurentur oculi eorum ne videant: et dorsum eorum semper incurva.

verses.textEn: Pour out your indignation upon them, and may the fury of your anger take hold of them.
verses.textLa: Effunde super eos iram tuam: et furor iræ tuæ comprehendat eos.

verses.textEn: May their dwelling place be deserted, and may there be no one who dwells in their tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Fiat habitatio eorum deserta: et in tabernaculis eorum non sit qui inhabitet.

verses.textEn: For they persecuted whomever you struck. And they have added to the grief of my wounds.
verses.textLa: Quoniam quem tu percussisti, persecuti sunt: et super dolorem vulnerum meorum addiderunt.

verses.textEn: Assign an iniquity upon their iniquity, and may they not enter into your justice.
verses.textLa: Appone iniquitatem super iniquitatem eorum: et non intrent in iustitiam tuam.

verses.textEn: Delete them from the Book of the Living, and let them not be written down with the just.
verses.textLa: Deleantur de Libro viventium: et cum iustis non scribantur.

verses.textEn: I am poor and sorrowful, but your salvation, O God, has taken me up.
verses.textLa: Ego sum pauper et dolens: salus tua Deus suscepit me.

verses.textEn: I will praise the name of God with a canticle, and I will magnify him with praise.
verses.textLa: Laudabo nomen Dei cum cantico: et magnificabo eum in laude:

verses.textEn: And it will please God more than a new calf producing horns and hoofs.
verses.textLa: Et placebit Deo super vitulum novellum: cornua producentem et ungulas.

verses.textEn: Let the poor see and rejoice. Seek God, and your soul will live.
verses.textLa: Videant pauperes et lætentur: quærite Deum, et vivet anima vestra:

verses.textEn: For the Lord has heard the poor, and he has not despised his prisoners.
verses.textLa: Quoniam exaudivit pauperes Dominus: et vinctos suos non despexit.

verses.textEn: Let the heavens and the earth praise him: the sea, and everything that crawls in it.
verses.textLa: Laudent illum cæli et terra, mare, et omnia reptilia in eis.

verses.textEn: For God will save Zion, and the cities of Judah will be built up. And they will dwell there, and they will acquire it by inheritance.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Deus salvam faciet Sion: et ædificabuntur civitates Iuda. Et inhabitabunt ibi, et hereditate acquirent eam.

verses.textEn: And the offspring of his servants will possess it; and those who love his name will dwell in it.
verses.textLa: Et semen servorum eius possidebit eam, et qui diligunt nomen eius, habitabunt in ea.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm of David, in remembrance that the Lord had saved him.
verses.textLa: In finem, Psalmus David, In rememorationem, quod salvum fecerit eum Dominus.

verses.textEn: O God, reach out to help me. O Lord, hasten to assist me.
verses.textLa: Deus in adiutorium meum intende: Domine ad adiuvandum me festina.

verses.textEn: May those who seek my soul be confounded and awed.
verses.textLa: Confundantur, et revereantur, qui quærunt animam meam:

verses.textEn: May those who wish evils upon me be turned back and blush with shame. May they be turned away immediately, blushing with shame, who say to me: “Well, well.”
verses.textLa: Avertantur retrorsum, et erubescant, qui volunt mihi mala: Avertantur statim erubescentes, qui dicunt mihi: Euge, euge.

verses.textEn: Let all who seek you exult and rejoice in you, and let those who love your salvation forever say: “The Lord be magnified.”
verses.textLa: Exultent et lætentur in te omnes qui quærunt te, et dicant semper: Magnificetur Dominus: qui diligunt salutare tuum.

verses.textEn: I am truly destitute and poor. O God, assist me. You are my helper and my deliverer. O Lord, do not delay.
verses.textLa: Ego vero egenus, et pauper sum: Deus adiuva me. Adiutor meus, et liberator meus es tu: Domine ne moreris.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David. Of the sons of Jonadab and the former captives. In you, O Lord, I have hoped; do not let me be brought to ruin forever.
verses.textLa: Psalmus David, Filiorum Ionadab, et priorum captivorum. In te Domine speravi, non confundar in æternum:

verses.textEn: Free me by your justice, and rescue me. Incline your ear to me, and save me.
verses.textLa: in iustitia tua libera me, et eripe me. Inclina ad me aurem tuam, et salva me.

verses.textEn: Be a God of protection and a place of strength for me, so that you may accomplish my salvation. For you are my firmament and my refuge.
verses.textLa: Esto mihi in Deum protectorem, et in locum munitum: ut salvum me facias. Quoniam firmamentum meum, et refugium meum es tu.

verses.textEn: Rescue me, O my God, from the hand of the sinner, and from the hand of the unjust and those who act against the law.
verses.textLa: Deus meus eripe me de manu peccatoris, et de manu contra legem agentis et iniqui:

verses.textEn: For you, O Lord, are my patience: my hope from my youth, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu es patientia mea Domine: Domine spes mea a iuventute mea.

verses.textEn: In you, I have been confirmed from conception. From my mother’s womb, you are my protector. In you, I will sing forever.
verses.textLa: In te confirmatus sum ex utero: de ventre matris meæ tu es protector meus: In te cantatio mea semper:

verses.textEn: I have become to many as if I were a portent, but you are a strong helper.
verses.textLa: tamquam prodigium factus sum multis: et tu adiutor fortis.

verses.textEn: Let my mouth be filled with praise, so that I may sing your glory, your greatness all day long.
verses.textLa: Repleatur os meum laude, ut cantem gloriam tuam: tota die magnitudinem tuam.

verses.textEn: Do not cast me off in the time of old age. Do not abandon me when my strength will fail.
verses.textLa: Ne proiicias me in tempore senectutis: cum defecerit virtus mea, ne derelinquas me.

verses.textEn: For my enemies have spoken against me. And those who watched for my soul have taken counsel as one,
verses.textLa: Quia dixerunt inimici mei mihi: et qui custodiebant animam meam, consilium fecerunt in unum,

verses.textEn: saying: “God has abandoned him. Pursue and overtake him. For there is no one to rescue him.”
verses.textLa: Dicentes: Deus dereliquit eum, persequimini, et comprehendite eum: quia non est qui eripiat.

verses.textEn: O God, do not be far from me. O my God, provide for my assistance.
verses.textLa: Deus ne elongeris a me: Deus meus in auxilium meum respice.

verses.textEn: May they be confounded, and may they fail, who drag down my soul. Let them be covered with confusion and shame, who seek evils for me.
verses.textLa: Confundantur, et deficiant detrahentes animæ meæ: operiantur confusione, et pudore qui quærunt mala mihi.

verses.textEn: But I will always have hope. And I will add more to all your praise.
verses.textLa: Ego autem semper sperabo: et adiiciam super omnem laudem tuam.

verses.textEn: My mouth will announce your justice, your salvation all day long. For I have not known letters.
verses.textLa: Os meum annuntiabit iustitiam tuam: tota die salutare tuum. Quoniam non cognovi litteraturam,

verses.textEn: I will enter into the powers of the Lord. I will be mindful of your justice alone, O Lord.
verses.textLa: introibo in potentias Domini: Domine, memorabor iustitiæ tuæ solius.

verses.textEn: You have taught me from my youth, O God. And so I will declare your wonders continuously,
verses.textLa: Deus docuisti me a iuventute mea: et usque nunc pronuntiabo mirabilia tua.

verses.textEn: even in old age and with grey hairs. Do not abandon me, O God, while I announce your arm to every future generation: your power
verses.textLa: Et usque in senectam et senium: Deus ne derelinquas me, Donec annunciem brachium tuum generationi omni, quæ ventura est: Potentiam tuam,

verses.textEn: and your justice, O God, even to the highest great things that you have done. O God, who is like you?
verses.textLa: et iustitiam tuam Deus usque in altissima, quæ fecisti magnalia: Deus quis similis tibi?

verses.textEn: How great is the tribulation that you have revealed to me: very great and evil. And so, turning back, you have brought me to life, and you have led me back again from the abyss of the earth.
verses.textLa: Quantas ostendisti mihi tribulationes multas, et malas: et conversus vivificasti me: et de abyssis terræ iterum reduxisti me:

verses.textEn: You have multiplied your magnificence. And so, turning back to me, you have consoled me.
verses.textLa: Multiplicasti magnificentiam tuam: et conversus consolatus es me.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I will confess your truth to you, with the instruments of the Psalter. O God, I will sing psalms to you with stringed instruments, O Holy One of Israel.
verses.textLa: Nam et ego confitebor tibi in vasis psalmi veritatem tuam: Deus psallam tibi in cithara, Sanctus Israel.

verses.textEn: My lips will exult, when I sing to you, and also my soul, which you have redeemed.
verses.textLa: Exultabunt labia mea cum cantavero tibi: et anima mea, quam redemisti.

verses.textEn: And even my tongue will meditate on your justice all day long, when those who seek evils for me have been confounded and set in awe.
verses.textLa: Sed et lingua mea tota die meditabitur iustitiam tuam: cum confusi et reveriti fuerint qui quærunt mala mihi.

verses.textEn: A Psalm according to Solomon.
verses.textLa: Psalmus, In Salomonem.
verses.notes: In other words, this is a psalm according to the wisdom and understanding of Solomon.

verses.textEn: Give your judgment, O God, to the king, and your justice to the king’s son, to judge your people with justice and your poor with judgment.
verses.textLa: Deus iudicium tuum regi da: et iustitiam tuam filio regis: Iudicare populum tuum in iustitia, et pauperes tuos in iudicio.

verses.textEn: Let the mountains take up peace for the people, and the hills, justice.
verses.textLa: Suscipiant montes pacem populo: et colles iustitiam.

verses.textEn: He will judge the poor of the people, and he will bring salvation to the sons of the poor. And he will humble the false accuser.
verses.textLa: Iudicabit pauperes populi, et salvos faciet filios pauperum: et humiliabit calumniatorem.

verses.textEn: And he will remain, with the sun and before the moon, from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Et permanebit cum Sole, et ante Lunam, in generatione et generationem.

verses.textEn: He will descend like rain upon fleece, and like showers showering upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Descendet sicut pluvia in vellus: et sicut stillicidia stillantia super terram.

verses.textEn: In his days, justice will rise like the sun, with abundance of peace, until the moon is taken away.
verses.textLa: Orietur in diebus eius iustitia, et abundantia pacis: donec auferatur luna.
verses.notes: The first part does not literally say ‘rise like the sun.’ However, the word ‘orietur’ is often used to refer to the rising of the sun, so the meaning ‘rise like the sun’ is clearly implied.

verses.textEn: And he will rule from sea to sea and from the river to the limits of the whole world.
verses.textLa: Et dominabitur a mari usque ad mare: et a flumine usque ad terminos orbis terrarum.

verses.textEn: In his sight, the Ethiopians will fall prostrate, and his enemies will lick the ground.
verses.textLa: Coram illo procident Æthiopes: et inimici eius terram lingent.

verses.textEn: The kings of Tarshish and the islands will offer gifts. The kings of Arabia and of Seba will bring gifts.
verses.textLa: Reges Tharsis, et insulæ munera offerent: reges Arabum, et Saba dona adducent:

verses.textEn: And all the kings of the earth shall adore him. All nations will serve him.
verses.textLa: Et adorabunt eum omnes reges terræ: omnes gentes servient ei:

verses.textEn: For he will free the poor from the powerful, and the poor one who has no helper.
verses.textLa: Quia liberabit pauperem a potente: et pauperem, cui non erat adiutor.

verses.textEn: He will spare the poor and the indigent, and he will bring salvation to the souls of the poor.
verses.textLa: Parcet pauperi et inopi: et animas pauperum salvas faciet.

verses.textEn: He will redeem their souls from usuries and from iniquity, and their names shall be honorable in his sight.
verses.textLa: Ex usuris et iniquitate redimet animas eorum: et honorabile nomen eorum coram illo.

verses.textEn: And he will live, and to him will be given from the gold of Arabia, and by him they will always adore. They will bless him all day long.
verses.textLa: Et vivet, et dabitur ei de auro Arabiæ, et adorabunt de ipso semper: tota die benedicent ei.

verses.textEn: And there will be a firmament on earth, at the summits of mountains: its fruits will be extolled above Lebanon, and those of the city will flourish like the grass of the earth.
verses.textLa: Et erit firmamentum in terra in summis montium, superextolletur super Libanum fructus eius: et florebunt de civitate sicut fœnum terræ.

verses.textEn: May his name be blessed forever; may his name remain before the sun. And all the tribes of the earth will be blessed in him. All nations will magnify him.
verses.textLa: Sit nomen eius benedictum in sæcula: ante Solem permanet nomen eius. Et benedicentur in ipso omnes tribus terræ: omnes gentes magnificabunt eum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord, God of Israel, who alone does wondrous things.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus Deus Israel, qui facit mirabilia solus:

verses.textEn: And blessed is the name of his majesty in eternity. And all the earth will be filled with his majesty. Amen. Amen.
verses.textLa: Et benedictum nomen maiestatis eius in æternum: et replebitur maiestate eius omnis terra: fiat, fiat.

verses.textEn: The praises of David, the son of Jesse, have reached an end.
verses.textLa: Defecerunt laudes David filii Iesse.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of Asaph. How good is God to Israel, to those who are upright in heart.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Asaph. Quam bonus Israel Deus his, qui recto sunt corde!

verses.textEn: But my feet were nearly moved; my steps had nearly slipped.
verses.textLa: Mei autem pene moti sunt pedes: pene effusi sunt gressus mei.

verses.textEn: For I was zealous over the iniquitous, seeing the peacefulness of sinners.
verses.textLa: Quia zelavi super iniquos, pacem peccatorum videns.

verses.textEn: For they have no respect for their death, nor do they have support in their wounds.
verses.textLa: Quia non est respectus morti eorum: et firmamentum in plaga eorum.

verses.textEn: They are not with the hardships of men, nor will they be scourged with men.
verses.textLa: In labore hominum non sunt, et cum hominibus non flagellabuntur:

verses.textEn: Therefore, arrogance has held on to them. They have been covered with their iniquity and impiety.
verses.textLa: Ideo tenuit eos superbia, operti sunt iniquitate et impietate sua.

verses.textEn: Their iniquity has proceeded, as if from fat. They have parted from the affection of the heart.
verses.textLa: Prodiit quasi ex adipe iniquitas eorum: transierunt in affectum cordis.

verses.textEn: They have thought and spoken wickedness. They have spoken iniquity in high places.
verses.textLa: Cogitaverunt, et locuti sunt nequitiam: iniquitatem in excelso locuti sunt.
verses.notes: In modern terms, speaking iniquity in high places could be equated to speaking iniquity in the media.

verses.textEn: They have set their mouth against heaven, and their tongue has traversed the earth.
verses.textLa: Posuerunt in cælum os suum: et lingua eorum transivit in terra.
verses.notes: Again, through the media, many persons speak against heaven and their words traverse the earth.

verses.textEn: Therefore, my people will be converted here, and fullness of days will be found in them.
verses.textLa: Ideo convertetur populus meus hic: et dies pleni invenientur in eis.

verses.textEn: And they said, “How would God know?” and, “Isn’t there knowledge in high places?”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt: Quomodo scit Deus, et si est scientia in excelso?
verses.notes: The word ‘excelso’ here does not refer to God Most High. Rather, it refers to the ‘excelso’ of the above verse, i.e. the high places of the world, such as governments and corporations and news media organizations, etc. The word ‘si’ is not simply translated as ‘if’ or ‘whether.’

verses.textEn: Behold, these are sinners, and, abounding in this age, they have obtained riches.
verses.textLa: Ecce ipsi peccatores, et abundantes in sæculo, obtinuerunt divitias.

verses.textEn: And I said: So then, it is without purpose that I have justified my heart and washed my hands among the innocent.
verses.textLa: Et dixi: Ergo sine causa iustificavi cor meum, et lavi inter innocentes manus meas:

verses.textEn: And I have been scourged all day long, and I have received my chastisement in the mornings.
verses.textLa: Et fui flagellatus tota die, et castigatio mea in matutinis.

verses.textEn: If I were to say that I would explain this: Behold, I would condemn this nation of your sons.
verses.textLa: Si dicebam: Narrabo sic: ecce nationem filiorum tuorum reprobavi.

verses.textEn: I considered, so that I might know this. It is a hardship before me,
verses.textLa: Existimabam ut cognoscerem hoc, labor est ante me:

verses.textEn: until I may enter into the Sanctuary of God, and understand it to its last part.
verses.textLa: Donec intrem in Sanctuarium Dei: et intelligam in novissimis eorum.

verses.textEn: So, because of deceitfulness, truly, you have placed it before them. While they were being lifted up, you were casting them down.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen propter dolos posuisti eis: deiecisti eos dum allevarentur.

verses.textEn: How have they been brought to desolation? They have suddenly failed. They have perished because of their iniquity.
verses.textLa: Quomodo facti sunt in desolationem, subito defecerunt: perierunt propter iniquitatem suam.

verses.textEn: As a dream is to those who awaken, O Lord, so will you reduce their image to nothing in your city.
verses.textLa: Velut somnium surgentium Domine, in civitate tua imaginem ipsorum ad nihilum rediges.

verses.textEn: For my heart has been inflamed, and my temperament has been changed.
verses.textLa: Quia inflammatum est cor meum, et renes mei commutati sunt:

verses.textEn: And so, I have been reduced to nothing, and I did not know it.
verses.textLa: et ego ad nihilum redactus sum, et nescivi.

verses.textEn: I have become like a beast of burden to you, and I am always with you.
verses.textLa: Ut iumentum factus sum apud te: et ego semper tecum.

verses.textEn: You have held my right hand. And in your will, you have conducted me, and with your glory, you have taken me up.
verses.textLa: Tenuisti manum dexteram meam: et in voluntate tua deduxisti me, et cum gloria suscepisti me.

verses.textEn: For what is there for me in heaven? And what do I wish for on earth before you?
verses.textLa: Quid enim mihi est in cælo? et a te quid volui super terram?

verses.textEn: My body has failed, and my heart: O God of my heart, and God my portion, into eternity.
verses.textLa: Defecit caro mea et cor meum: Deus cordis mei, et pars mea Deus in æternum.

verses.textEn: For behold, those who put themselves far from you will perish. You have perished all those who fornicate away from you.
verses.textLa: Quia ecce, qui elongant se a te, peribunt: perdidisti omnes, qui fornicantur abs te.

verses.textEn: But it is good for me to adhere to God, to put my hope in the Lord God, so that I may announce all your prophecies, at the gates of the daughter of Zion.
verses.textLa: Mihi autem adhærere Deo bonum est: ponere in Domino Deo spem meam: ut annunciem omnes prædicationes tuas, in portis filiæ Sion.
verses.notes: Or, ‘all your predictions, at the gates of daughter Zion.’

verses.textEn: The understanding of Asaph. O God, why have you rejected us to the end. Why has your fury become enraged over the sheep of your pasture?
verses.textLa: Intellectus Asaph. Ut quid Deus repulisti in finem: iratus est furor tuus super oves pascuæ tuæ?

verses.textEn: Be mindful of your congregation, which you have possessed from the beginning. You redeemed the scepter of your inheritance, mount Zion, in which you have dwelt.
verses.textLa: Memor esto congregationis tuæ, quam possedisti ab initio. Redemisti virgam hereditatis tuæ: mons Sion, in quo habitasti in eo.

verses.textEn: Lift up your hands against their arrogance in the end. How great the malice of the enemy has been in the sanctuary!
verses.textLa: Leva manus tuas in superbias eorum in finem: quanta malignatus est inimicus in sancto!
verses.notes: This last part is literally: “How much the enemy has been malicious in the sanctuary!”

verses.textEn: And those who hate you have been glorified, in the midst of your solemnity. They have set up their own signs as a proof,
verses.textLa: Et gloriati sunt qui oderunt te: in medio solemnitatis tuæ. Posuerunt signa sua, signa:

verses.textEn: as if it had been issued from on high; yet they did not understand. As in a forest of chopped wood,
verses.textLa: et non cognoverunt sicut in exitu super summum. Quasi in silva lignorum securibus
verses.notes: They set up their own signs and then they use those signs as their proof. And they do not even understand that such signs are not valid because they come from themselves, but they consider such signs as if they had the validity of signs issued from on high (from God).

verses.textEn: they have cut down the entrances themselves. With axe and hatchet, they have brought it down.
verses.textLa: exciderunt ianuas eius in idipsum: in securi, et ascia deiecerunt eam.

verses.textEn: They have set fire to your Sanctuary. They have polluted the tabernacle of your name on earth.
verses.textLa: Incenderunt igni Sanctuarium tuum: in terra polluerunt tabernaculum nominis tui.

verses.textEn: They have said in their heart, the whole group of them together: “Let us cause all the feast days of God to cease from the land.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt in corde suo cognatio eorum simul: quiescere faciamus omnes dies festos Dei a terra.

verses.textEn: We have not seen our proof; there is now no prophet. And he will no longer know us.”
verses.textLa: Signa nostra non vidimus, iam non est propheta: et nos non cognoscet amplius.

verses.textEn: How long, O God, will the enemy place blame? Is the adversary to provoke your name until the end?
verses.textLa: Usquequo Deus improperabit inimicus: irritat adversarius nomen tuum in finem?

verses.textEn: Why do you turn your hand away, even your right hand, from the midst of your sinews, until the end?
verses.textLa: Ut quid avertis manum tuam, et dexteram tuam, de medio sinu tuo in finem?

verses.textEn: But God is our king before all ages. He has wrought salvation in the midst of the earth.
verses.textLa: Deus autem rex noster ante sæcula: operatus est salutem in medio terræ.

verses.textEn: In your virtue, you confirmed the sea. You crushed the heads of the serpents in the waters.
verses.textLa: Tu confirmasti in virtute tua mare: contribulasti capita draconum in aquis.

verses.textEn: You have broken the heads of the serpent. You have given him as food for the people of the Ethiopians.
verses.textLa: Tu confregisti capita draconis: dedisti eum escam populis Æthiopum.

verses.textEn: You have disrupted the fountains and the torrents. You have dried up the rivers of Ethan.
verses.textLa: Tu dirupisti fontes, et torrentes: tu siccasti fluvios Ethan.

verses.textEn: Yours is the day, and yours is the night. You have made the morning light and the sun.
verses.textLa: Tuus est dies, et tua est nox: tu fabricatus es auroram et solem.

verses.textEn: You have made all the limits of the earth. The summer and the spring were formed by you.
verses.textLa: Tu fecisti omnes terminos terræ: æstatem et ver tu plasmasti ea.

verses.textEn: Be mindful of this: the enemy placed blame against the Lord, and a foolish people has incited against your name.
verses.textLa: Memor esto huius, inimicus improperavit Domino: et populus insipiens incitavit nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: Do not hand over to beasts the souls that confess to you; and do not forget the souls of your poor until the end.
verses.textLa: Ne tradas bestiis animas confitentes tibi, et animas pauperum tuorum ne obliviscaris in finem.

verses.textEn: Consider your covenant. For those who have been darkened upon the earth have been filled by the iniquity of the houses.
verses.textLa: Respice in testamentum tuum: quia repleti sunt, qui obscurati sunt terræ domibus iniquitatum.

verses.textEn: Do not allow the humble to be turned away in confusion. The poor and the needy will praise your name.
verses.textLa: Ne avertatur humilis factus confusus: pauper et inops laudabunt nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: Rise up, O God, judge your own case. Call to mind the accusations against you, which are made by the foolish all day long.
verses.textLa: Exurge Deus, iudica causam tuam: memor esto improperiorum tuorum, eorum quæ ab insipiente sunt tota die.

verses.textEn: Do not forget the voices of your adversaries. The arrogance of those who hate you rises up continually.
verses.textLa: Ne obliviscaris voces inimicorum tuorum: superbia eorum, qui te oderunt, ascendit semper.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. May you not be corrupted. A Canticle Psalm of Asaph.
verses.textLa: In finem, Ne corrumpas, Psalmus Cantici Asaph.

verses.textEn: We will confess to you, O God. We will confess, and we will call upon your name. We will describe your wonders.
verses.textLa: Confitebimur tibi Deus: confitebimur, et invocabimus nomen tuum. Narrabimus mirabilia tua:

verses.textEn: While I have time, I will judge justices.
verses.textLa: cum accepero tempus, ego iustitias iudicabo.

verses.textEn: The earth has been dissolved, with all who dwell in it. I have confirmed its pillars.
verses.textLa: Liquefacta est terra, et omnes qui habitant in ea: ego confirmavi columnas eius.

verses.textEn: I said to the iniquitous: “Do not act unjustly,” and to the offenders: “Do not exalt the horn.”
verses.textLa: Dixi iniquis: Nolite inique agere: et delinquentibus: Nolite exaltare cornu:

verses.textEn: Do not exalt your horn on high. Do not speak iniquity against God.
verses.textLa: Nolite extollere in altum cornu vestrum: nolite loqui adversus Deum iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: For it is neither from the east, nor from the west, nor before the desert mountains.
verses.textLa: Quia neque ab Oriente, neque ab Occidente, neque a desertis montibus:

verses.textEn: For God is judge. This one he humbles and that one he exalts.
verses.textLa: quoniam Deus iudex est. Hunc humiliat, et hunc exaltat:

verses.textEn: For, in the hand of the Lord, there is a cup of undiluted wine, full of consternation. And he has tipped it from here to there. So, truly, its dregs have not been emptied. All the sinners of the earth will drink.
verses.textLa: quia calix in manu Domini vini meri plenus misto. Et inclinavit ex hoc in hoc: verumtamen fæx eius non est exinanita: bibent omnes peccatores terræ.
verses.notes: The expression ‘meri vini’ refers to undiluted wine. In ancient times, people often diluted their wine with water; this made the water more sanitary, while preventing drunkenness. This metaphorical wine is undiluted. God tips the cup of wine from one side to another (not pouring it out yet), so as to mix the sediments into the wine, making is full strength. The earth will drink from the cup of God’s wrath, undiluted and with even the sediments mixed in.

verses.textEn: But I will announce it in every age. I will sing to the God of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Ego autem annunciabo in sæculum: cantabo Deo Iacob.

verses.textEn: And I will break all the horns of sinners. And the horns of the just will be exalted.
verses.textLa: Et omnia cornua peccatorum confringam: et exaltabuntur cornua iusti.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. With Praises. A Psalm of Asaph. A Canticle to the Assyrians.
verses.textLa: In finem, in Laudibus, Psalmus Asaph, Canticum ad Assyrios.

verses.textEn: In Judea, God is known. In Israel, his name is great.
verses.textLa: Notus in Iudæa Deus: in Israel magnum nomen eius.

verses.textEn: And his place has been formed with peace. And his dwelling place is in Zion.
verses.textLa: Et factus est in pace locus eius: et habitatio eius in Sion.

verses.textEn: In that place, he has broken the powers of the bows, the shield, the sword, and the battle.
verses.textLa: Ibi confregit potentias arcuum, scutum, gladium, et bellum.

verses.textEn: You illuminate wondrously from the mountains of eternity.
verses.textLa: Illuminans tu mirabiliter a montibus æternis:

verses.textEn: All the foolish of heart have been disturbed. They have slept their sleep, and all the men of riches have found nothing in their hands.
verses.textLa: turbati sunt omnes insipientes corde. Dormierunt somnum suum: et nihil invenerunt omnes viri divitiarum in manibus suis.

verses.textEn: At your rebuke, O God of Jacob, those who were mounted on horseback have fallen asleep.
verses.textLa: Ab increpatione tua Deus Iacob dormitaverunt qui ascenderunt equos.

verses.textEn: You are terrible, and so, who can withstand you? From thence is your wrath.
verses.textLa: Tu terribilis es, et quis resistet tibi? ex tunc ira tua.

verses.textEn: You have caused judgment to be heard from heaven. The earth trembled and was quieted,
verses.textLa: De cælo auditum fecisti iudicium: terra tremuit et quievit,

verses.textEn: when God rose up in judgment in order to bring salvation to all the meek of the earth.
verses.textLa: cum exurgeret in iudicium Deus, ut salvos faceret omnes mansuetos terræ.

verses.textEn: For the thinking of man will confess to you, and the legacy of his thinking will keep a feast day to you.
verses.textLa: Quoniam cogitatio hominis confitebitur tibi: et reliquiæ cogitationis diem festum agent tibi.

verses.textEn: Make vows and pay them to the Lord, your God. All you who surround him bring gifts: to him who is terrible,
verses.textLa: Vovete, et reddite Domino Deo vestro: omnes qui in circuitu eius affertis munera. Terribili

verses.textEn: even to him who takes away the spirit of leaders, to him who is terrible with the kings of the earth.
verses.textLa: et ei qui aufert spiritum principum, terribili apud reges terræ.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For Jeduthun. A Psalm of Asaph.
verses.textLa: In finem, pro Idithun, Psalmus Asaph.

verses.textEn: I cried out to the Lord with my voice, to God with my voice, and he attended to me.
verses.textLa: Voce mea ad Dominum clamavi: voce mea ad Deum, et intendit mihi.

verses.textEn: In the days of my tribulation, I sought God, with my hands opposite him in the night, and I was not deceived. My soul refused to be consoled.
verses.textLa: In die tribulationis meæ Deum exquisivi, manibus meis nocte contra eum: et non sum deceptus. Renuit consolari anima mea,

verses.textEn: I was mindful of God, and I was delighted, and I was distressed, and my spirit fell away.
verses.textLa: memor fui Dei, et delectatus sum, et exercitatus sum: et defecit spiritus meus.
verses.notes: This verse sums up the contemplative way. First, you consider God with your mind. Second, you find delight in God and receive light and consolation. Third, you encounter hardships, walking, as it were, a dark and rocky road to Calvary. This third step is called the dark night of the soul. Fourth, you arrive at a contemplation of God whereby your sense of self and all traces of self-interest fall away, leaving only God.

verses.textEn: My eyes anticipated the vigils. I was disturbed, and I did not speak.
verses.textLa: Anticipaverunt vigilias oculi mei: turbatus sum, et non sum locutus.

verses.textEn: I considered the days of antiquity, and I held the years of eternity in my mind.
verses.textLa: Cogitavi dies antiquos: et annos æternos in mente habui.

verses.textEn: And I meditated in the night with my heart, and I was distressed, and I examined my spirit.
verses.textLa: Et meditatus sum nocte cum corde meo, et exercitabar, et scopebam spiritum meum.

verses.textEn: So then, will God reject for eternity? Will he not continue to allow himself to show favor?
verses.textLa: Numquid in æternum proiiciet Deus: aut non apponet ut complacitior sit adhuc?
verses.notes: The word ‘numquid’ indicates that the answer to the question is ‘no.’ Therefore, the phrasing of the question must also indicate that fact. The latter part of this verse is translated loosely, otherwise the meaning would be obscured.

verses.textEn: Or, will he cut off his mercy in the end, from generation to generation?
verses.textLa: Aut in finem misericordiam suam abscindet, a generatione in generationem?

verses.textEn: And would God ever forget to be merciful? Or, would he, in his wrath, restrict his mercies?
verses.textLa: Aut obliviscetur misereri Deus? aut continebit in ira sua misericordias suas?

verses.textEn: And I said, “Now I have begun. This change is from the right hand of the Most High.”
verses.textLa: Et dixi nunc cœpi: hæc mutatio dexteræ Excelsi.

verses.textEn: I was mindful of the works of the Lord. For I will be mindful from the beginning of your wonders,
verses.textLa: Memor fui operum Domini: quia memor ero ab initio mirabilium tuorum,

verses.textEn: and I will meditate on all your works. And I will take part in your intentions.
verses.textLa: et meditabor in omnibus operibus tuis: et in adinventionibus tuis exercebor.

verses.textEn: Your way, O God, is in what is holy. Which God is great like our God?
verses.textLa: Deus in sancto via tua: quis Deus magnus sicut Deus noster?

verses.textEn: You are the God who performs miracles. You have made your virtue known among the peoples.
verses.textLa: Tu es Deus qui facis mirabilia. Notam fecisti in populis virtutem tuam:

verses.textEn: With your arm, you have redeemed your people, the sons of Jacob and of Joseph.
verses.textLa: redemisti in brachio tuo populum tuum, filios Iacob, et Ioseph.

verses.textEn: The waters saw you, O God, the waters saw you, and they were afraid, and the depths were stirred up.
verses.textLa: Viderunt te aquæ Deus, viderunt te aquæ: et timuerunt, et turbatæ sunt abyssi.

verses.textEn: Great was the sound of the waters. The clouds uttered a voice. For your arrows also pass by.
verses.textLa: Multitudo sonitus aquarum: vocem dederunt nubes. Etenim sagittæ tuæ transeunt:

verses.textEn: The voice of your thunder is like a wheel. Your flashes have illuminated the whole world. The earth has quaked and trembled.
verses.textLa: vox tonitrui tui in rota. Illuxerunt coruscationes tuæ orbi terræ: commota est et contremuit terra.

verses.textEn: Your way is through the sea, and your paths are through many waters. And your traces will not be known.
verses.textLa: In mari via tua, et semitæ tuæ in aquis multis: et vestigia tua non cognoscentur.

verses.textEn: You have conducted your people like sheep, by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
verses.textLa: Deduxisti sicut oves populum tuum, in manu Moysi et Aaron.

verses.textEn: The understanding of Asaph. O my people, attend to my law. Incline your ears to the words of my mouth.
verses.textLa: Intellectus Asaph. Attendite popule meus legem meam: inclinate aurem vestram in verba oris mei.

verses.textEn: I will open my mouth in parables. I will speak about concepts that are from the beginning.
verses.textLa: Aperiam in parabolis os meum: loquar propositiones ab initio.

verses.textEn: We have heard and known such great things, as our fathers have described to us.
verses.textLa: Quanta audivimus et cognovimus ea: et patres nostri narraverunt nobis.

verses.textEn: These things have not been hidden from their sons in any generation: declaring the praises of the Lord, and his virtues, and the wonders that he has done.
verses.textLa: Non sunt occultata a filiis eorum, in generatione altera. Narrantes laudes Domini, et virtutes eius, et mirabilia eius quæ fecit.

verses.textEn: And he has received testimony with Jacob, and he has set a law within Israel. Such great things, he has commanded our fathers, so as to make these things known to their sons,
verses.textLa: Et suscitavit testimonium in Iacob: et legem posuit in Israel. Quanta mandavit patribus nostris nota facere ea filiis suis:

verses.textEn: so that another generation might know them, and so that the sons, who will be born and who will grow up, shall describe them to their sons.
verses.textLa: ut cognoscat generatio altera. Filii qui nascentur, et exurgent, et narrabunt filiis suis,

verses.textEn: So then, may they put their hope in God, and may they not forget the works of God, and may they seek his commandments.
verses.textLa: Ut ponant in Deo spem suam, et non obliviscantur operum Dei: et mandata eius exquirant.

verses.textEn: May they not become like their fathers, a perverse and exasperating generation: a generation that does not straighten their heart and whose spirit is not trustworthy with God.
verses.textLa: Ne fiant sicut patres eorum: generatio prava et exasperans. Generatio, quæ non direxit cor suum: et non est creditus cum Deo spiritus eius.

verses.textEn: The sons of Ephraim, who bend and shoot the bow, have been turned back in the day of battle.
verses.textLa: Filii Ephrem intendentes et mittentes arcum: conversi sunt in die belli.

verses.textEn: They have not kept the covenant of God. And they were not willing to walk in his law.
verses.textLa: Non custodierunt testamentum Dei, et in lege eius noluerunt ambulare.

verses.textEn: And they have been forgetful of his benefits, and of his miracle, which he revealed to them.
verses.textLa: Et obliti sunt benefactorum eius, et mirabilium eius quæ ostendit eis.

verses.textEn: He performed miracles in the sight of their fathers, in the land of Egypt, in the field of Tanis.
verses.textLa: Coram patribus eorum fecit mirabilia in terra Ægypti, in campo Taneos.

verses.textEn: He broke the sea and he led them through. And he stationed the waters, as if in a vessel.
verses.textLa: Interrupit mare, et perduxit eos: et statuit aquas quasi in utre.

verses.textEn: And he led them with a cloud by day, and with illumination by fire throughout the night.
verses.textLa: Et deduxit eos in nube diei: et tota nocte in illuminatione ignis.

verses.textEn: He broke through the rock in the wasteland, and he gave them to drink, as if from the great abyss.
verses.textLa: Interrupit petram in eremo: et adaquavit eos velut in abysso multa.

verses.textEn: He brought forth water from the rock, and he conducted the waters, as if they were rivers.
verses.textLa: Et eduxit aquam de petra: et deduxit tamquam flumina aquas.

verses.textEn: And yet, they continued to sin against him. In a waterless place, they provoked the Most High with resentment.
verses.textLa: Et apposuerunt adhuc peccare ei: in iram excitaverunt Excelsum in inaquoso.
verses.notes: They were angry and resentful that they were led to a waterless place by God.

verses.textEn: And they tempted God in their hearts, by asking for food according to their desires.
verses.textLa: Et tentaverunt Deum in cordibus suis: ut peterent escas animabus suis.

verses.textEn: And they spoke badly about God. They said, “Would God be able to prepare a table in the desert?
verses.textLa: Et male locuti sunt de Deo: dixerunt: Numquid poterit Deus parare mensam in deserto?

verses.textEn: He struck the rock, and so waters flowed and the torrents flooded, but would even he be able to provide bread, or provide a table, for his people?”
verses.textLa: Quoniam percussit petram, et fluxerunt aquæ, et torrentes inundaverunt. Numquid et panem poterit dare, aut parare mensam populo suo?

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Lord heard, and he was dismayed, and a fire was kindled within Jacob, and an anger ascended into Israel.
verses.textLa: Ideo audivit Dominus, et distulit: et ignis accensus est in Iacob, et ira ascendit in Israel:

verses.textEn: For they neither put their trust in God, nor did they hope in his salvation.
verses.textLa: Quia non crediderunt in Deo, nec speraverunt in salutari eius:

verses.textEn: And he commanded the clouds from above, and he opened the doors of heaven.
verses.textLa: Et mandavit nubibus desuper, et ianuas cæli aperuit.

verses.textEn: And he rained down manna upon them to eat, and he gave them the bread of heaven.
verses.textLa: Et pluit illis manna ad manducandum, et panem cæli dedit eis.

verses.textEn: Man ate the bread of Angels. He sent them provisions in abundance.
verses.textLa: Panem angelorum manducavit homo: cibaria misit eis in abundantia.

verses.textEn: He transferred the south wind from heaven, and, in his virtue, he brought in the Southwest wind.
verses.textLa: Transtulit Austrum de cælo: et induxit in virtute sua Africum.

verses.textEn: And he rained down flesh upon them, as if it were dust, and feathered birds, as if they were the sand of the sea.
verses.textLa: Et pluit super eos sicut pulverem carnes, et sicut arenam maris volatilia pennata.

verses.textEn: And they fell down in the midst of their camp, encircling their tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Et ceciderunt in medio castrorum eorum: circa tabernacula eorum.

verses.textEn: And they ate until they were greatly satisfied, and he brought to them according to their desires.
verses.textLa: Et manducaverunt et saturati sunt nimis, et desiderium eorum attulit eis:

verses.textEn: They were not cheated out of what they wanted. Their food was still in their mouth,
verses.textLa: non sunt fraudati a desiderio suo. Adhuc escæ eorum erant in ore ipsorum,

verses.textEn: and then the wrath of God came upon them. And he slew the fat ones among them, and he impeded the elect of Israel.
verses.textLa: et ira Dei ascendit super eos. Et occidit pingues eorum, et electos Israel impedivit.

verses.textEn: In all these things, they continued to sin, and they were not trustworthy with his miracles.
verses.textLa: In omnibus his peccaverunt adhuc: et non crediderunt in mirabilibus eius.

verses.textEn: And their days faded away into vanity, and their years with haste.
verses.textLa: Et defecerunt in vanitate dies eorum: et anni eorum cum festinatione.

verses.textEn: When he slew them, then they sought him. And they returned, and they drew near to him in the early morning.
verses.textLa: Cum occideret eos, quærebant eum: et revertebantur, et diluculo veniebant ad eum.

verses.textEn: And they were mindful that God is their helper and that the Most High God is their redeemer.
verses.textLa: Et rememorati sunt quia Deus adiutor est eorum: et Deus excelsus redemptor eorum est.

verses.textEn: And they chose him with their mouth, and then they lied to him with their tongue.
verses.textLa: Et dilexerunt eum in ore suo, et lingua sua mentiti sunt ei:

verses.textEn: For their heart was not upright with him, nor have they been living faithfully in his covenant.
verses.textLa: Cor autem eorum non erat rectum cum eo: nec fideles habiti sunt in testamento eius.

verses.textEn: Yet he is merciful, and he will pardon their sins. And he will not destroy them. And he has abundantly turned aside his own wrath. And he did not enflame his wrath entirely.
verses.textLa: Ipse autem est misericors, et propitius fiet peccatis eorum: et non disperdet eos. Et abundavit ut averteret iram suam: et non accendit omnem iram suam:

verses.textEn: And he remembered that they are flesh: with a spirit that goes forth and does not return.
verses.textLa: Et recordatus est quia caro sunt: spiritus vadens, et non rediens.
verses.notes: In the ancient view, man is body, spirit, and soul. The spirit of man is not a third part, but merely the quality of being alive, when body and soul are united. At death, body and soul are separated, and spirit (the breath of life) seems to cease to exist, but only because it is a quality, not a thing.

verses.textEn: How often did they provoke him in the desert and stir him to wrath in a waterless place?
verses.textLa: Quoties exacerbaverunt eum in deserto, in iram concitaverunt eum in inaquoso?

verses.textEn: And they turned back and tempted God, and they exasperated the Holy One of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et conversi sunt, et tentaverunt Deum: et Sanctum Israel exacerbaverunt.

verses.textEn: They did not remember his hand, in the day that he redeemed them from the hand of the one troubling them.
verses.textLa: Non sunt recordati manus eius, die qua redemit eos de manu tribulantis,

verses.textEn: Thus, he positioned his signs in Egypt and his wonders in the field of Tanis.
verses.textLa: Sicut posuit in Ægypto signa sua, et prodigia sua in campo Taneos.

verses.textEn: And he turned their rivers into blood, along with their rain showers, so that they could not drink.
verses.textLa: Et convertit in sanguinem flumina eorum, et imbres eorum, ne biberent.

verses.textEn: He sent among them the common fly, and it devoured them, and the frog, and it scattered them.
verses.textLa: Misit in eos cœnomyiam, et comedit eos: et ranam, et disperdidit eos.

verses.textEn: And he gave up their fruits to mold and their labors to the locust.
verses.textLa: Et dedit ærugini fructus eorum: et labores eorum locustæ.

verses.textEn: And he slew their vineyards with hail and their mulberry trees with severe frost.
verses.textLa: Et occidit in grandine vineas eorum: et moros eorum in pruina.

verses.textEn: And he delivered their cattle to the hail and their possessions to fire.
verses.textLa: Et tradidit grandini iumenta eorum: et possessionem eorum igni.

verses.textEn: And he sent the wrath of his indignation among them: indignation and wrath and tribulation, sent forth by evil angels.
verses.textLa: Misit in eos iram indignationis suæ: indignationem, et iram, et tribulationem: immissiones per angelos malos.

verses.textEn: He made way for the path of his anger. He did not spare their souls from death. And he enclosed their beasts of burden in death.
verses.textLa: Viam fecit semitæ iræ suæ, non pepercit a morte animabus eorum: et iumenta eorum in morte conclusit.

verses.textEn: And he struck all the first-born in the land of Egypt: the first-fruits of all their labor in the tabernacles of Ham.
verses.textLa: Et percussit omne primogenitum in terra Ægypti: primitias omnis laboris eorum in tabernaculis Cham.

verses.textEn: And he took away his own people like sheep, and he led them through the wilderness like a flock.
verses.textLa: Et abstulit sicut oves populum suum: et perduxit eos tamquam gregem in deserto.

verses.textEn: And he led them out in hope, and they did not fear. And the sea covered their enemies.
verses.textLa: Et deduxit eos in spe, et non timuerunt: et inimicos eorum operuit mare.

verses.textEn: And he led them to the mountain of his sanctification: the mountain that his right hand had acquired. And he cast out the Gentiles before their face. And he divided their land by lot to them, with a line of distribution.
verses.textLa: Et induxit eos in montem sanctificationis suæ, montem, quem acquisivit dextera eius. Et eiecit a facie eorum Gentes: et sorte divisit eis terram in funiculo distributionis.

verses.textEn: And he caused the tribes of Israel to dwell in their tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Et habitare fecit in tabernaculis eorum tribus Israel.

verses.textEn: Yet they tempted and aggravated God Most High, and they did not keep his testaments.
verses.textLa: Et tentaverunt, et exacerbaverunt Deum excelsum: et testimonia eius non custodierunt.

verses.textEn: And they turned themselves aside, and they did not serve the covenant. In the same manner as their fathers, they were turned backwards, like a crooked bow.
verses.textLa: Et averterunt se, et non servaverunt pactum: quemadmodum patres eorum, conversi sunt in arcum pravum.

verses.textEn: They impelled him to anger on their hills, and they provoked him to rivalry with their graven images.
verses.textLa: In iram concitaverunt eum in collibus suis: et in sculptilibus suis ad æmulationem eum provocaverunt.

verses.textEn: God listened, and he spurned them, and he reduced Israel greatly, almost to nothing.
verses.textLa: Audivit Deus, et sprevit: et ad nihilum redegit valde Israel.

verses.textEn: And he rejected the tabernacle of Shiloh, his tabernacle where he had dwelt among men.
verses.textLa: Et repulit tabernaculum Silo, tabernaculum suum, ubi habitavit in hominibus.

verses.textEn: And he delivered their virtue into captivity, and their beauty into the hands of the enemy.
verses.textLa: Et tradidit in captivitatem virtutem eorum: et pulchritudinem eorum in manus inimici.

verses.textEn: And he enclosed his people with the sword, and he spurned his inheritance.
verses.textLa: Et conclusit in gladio populum suum: et hereditatem suam sprevit.

verses.textEn: Fire consumed their young men, and their virgins were not lamented.
verses.textLa: Iuvenes eorum comedit ignis: et virgines eorum non sunt lamentatæ.

verses.textEn: Their priests fell by the sword, and their widows did not weep.
verses.textLa: Sacerdotes eorum in gladio ceciderunt: et viduæ eorum non plorabantur.

verses.textEn: And the Lord was awakened, as if out of sleep, and like a powerful man impaired by wine.
verses.textLa: Et excitatus est tamquam dormiens Dominus, tamquam potens crapulatus a vino.

verses.textEn: And he struck his enemies on the back. He gave them over to everlasting disgrace.
verses.textLa: Et percussit inimicos suos in posteriora: opprobrium sempiternum dedit illis.

verses.textEn: And he rejected the tabernacle of Joseph, and he did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
verses.textLa: Et repulit tabernaculum Ioseph: et tribum Ephraim non elegit:

verses.textEn: But he chose the tribe of Judah: mount Zion, which he loved.
verses.textLa: Sed elegit tribum Iuda, montem Sion quem dilexit.

verses.textEn: And he built up his sanctuary, like a single-horned beast, in the land that he founded for all ages.
verses.textLa: Et ædificavit sicut unicornium sanctificium suum in terra, quam fundavit in sæcula.
verses.notes: The word ‘horn’ in the Old Testament often is used metaphorically to refer to power or a source of power, or leadership or a particular leader.

verses.textEn: And he chose his servant David, and he took him from the flocks of the sheep: he received him from following the ewes with their young,
verses.textLa: Et elegit David servum suum, et sustulit eum de gregibus ovium: de post fœtantes accepit eum.

verses.textEn: in order to pasture Jacob his servant and Israel his inheritance.
verses.textLa: Pascere Iacob servum suum, et Israel hereditatem suam:

verses.textEn: And he fed them with the innocence of his heart. And he led them with the understanding of his hands.
verses.textLa: Et pavit eos in innocentia cordis sui: et in intellectibus manuum suarum deduxit eos.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of Asaph. O God, the Gentiles have entered into your inheritance; they have polluted your holy temple. They have set Jerusalem as a place to tend fruit trees.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Asaph. Deus venerunt Gentes in hereditatem tuam, polluerunt templum sanctum tuum: posuerunt Ierusalem in pomorum custodiam.

verses.textEn: They have placed the dead bodies of your servants as food for the birds of the sky, the flesh of your saints for the beasts of the earth.
verses.textLa: Posuerunt morticina servorum tuorum, escas volatilibus cæli: carnes sanctorum tuorum bestiis terræ.

verses.textEn: They have poured out their blood like water all around Jerusalem, and there was no one who would bury them.
verses.textLa: Effuderunt sanguinem eorum tamquam aquam in circuitu Ierusalem: et non erat qui sepeliret.

verses.textEn: We have become a disgrace to our neighbors, an object of ridicule and mockery to those who are around us.
verses.textLa: Facti sumus opprobrium vicinis nostris: subsannatio et illusio his, qui in circuitu nostro sunt.

verses.textEn: How long, O Lord? Will you be angry until the end? Will your zeal be kindled like a fire?
verses.textLa: Usquequo Domine, irasceris in finem: accendetur velut ignis zelus tuus?

verses.textEn: Pour out your wrath among the Gentiles, who have not known you, and upon the kingdoms that have not invoked your name.
verses.textLa: Effunde iram tuam in Gentes, quæ te non noverunt: et in regna, quæ nomen tuum non invocaverunt:

verses.textEn: For they have devoured Jacob, and they have desolated his place.
verses.textLa: Quia comederunt Iacob: et locum eius desolaverunt.

verses.textEn: Do not remember our iniquities of the past. May your mercies quickly intercept us, for we have become exceedingly poor.
verses.textLa: Ne memineris iniquitatum nostrarum antiquarum, cito anticipent nos misericordiæ tuæ: quia pauperes facti sumus nimis.

verses.textEn: Help us, O God, our Savior. And free us, Lord, for the glory of your name. And forgive us our sins for the sake of your name.
verses.textLa: Adiuva nos Deus salutaris noster: et propter gloriam nominis tui Domine libera nos: et propitius esto peccatis nostris, propter nomen tuum:

verses.textEn: Let them not say among the Gentiles, “Where is their God?” And may your name become known among the nations before our eyes. For the retribution of your servants’ blood, which has been poured out:
verses.textLa: Ne forte dicant in Gentibus: Ubi est Deus eorum? et innotescat in nationibus coram oculis nostris. Ultio sanguinis servorum tuorum, qui effusus est:
verses.notes: The verb ‘innotescat,’ in this context, refers to the name of the Lord, as mentioned in the previous verse. The term ‘Gentiles,’ in the Catholic Christian understanding of the text, refers to unbelievers, not to non-Jews. It refers to sinful secular society, to those groups and nations that do not believe.

verses.textEn: may the groans of the shackled enter before you. According to the greatness of your arm, take possession of the sons of those who have been killed.
verses.textLa: introeat in conspectu tuo gemitus compeditorum. Secundum magnitudinem brachii tui, posside filios mortificatorum.

verses.textEn: And repay our neighbors sevenfold within their sinews. It is the reproach of the same ones who brought reproach against you, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Et redde vicinis nostris septuplum in sinu eorum: improperium ipsorum, quod exprobraverunt tibi Domine.

verses.textEn: But we are your people and the sheep of your pasture: we will give thanks to you in all ages. From generation to generation, we will announce your praise.
verses.textLa: Nos autem populus tuus, et oves pascuæ tuæ, confitebimur tibi in sæculum: In generationem et generationem annunciabimus laudem tuam.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For those who will be changed. The testimony of Asaph. A Psalm.
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro iis, qui commutabuntur, testimonium Asaph, Psalmus.

verses.textEn: The One who reigns over Israel: Be attentive. For you lead Joseph like a sheep. The One who sits upon the cherubim: Shine forth
verses.textLa: Qui regis Israel, intende: qui deducis velut ovem Ioseph. Qui sedes super cherubim, manifestare

verses.textEn: in the presence of Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh. Awaken your power and draw near, so as to accomplish our salvation.
verses.textLa: coram Ephraim, Beniamin, et Manasse. Excita potentiam tuam, et veni, ut salvos facias nos.

verses.textEn: Convert us, O God. And reveal your face, and we will be saved.
verses.textLa: Deus converte nos: et ostende faciem tuam, et salvi erimus.

verses.textEn: O Lord, God of hosts, how long will you be angry over the prayer of your servant?
verses.textLa: Domine Deus virtutum, quousque irasceris super orationem servi tui?
verses.notes: There are two possible meanings here (at least). One meaning is that God is angry despite (over and above) the prayer of His servant. The other meaning is that He is angry at the inappropriate or sinful prayer of someone who is otherwise a servant of God. Some make the mistake of the Pharisee, praying with some degree of selfishness or self-exaltation. Prayer is not necessarily pleasing to God.

verses.textEn: How long will you feed us the bread of tears, and give us to drink a full measure of tears?
verses.textLa: Cibabis nos pane lacrymarum: et potum dabis nobis in lacrymis in mensura?

verses.textEn: You have set us as a contradiction to our neighbors. And our enemies have ridiculed us.
verses.textLa: Posuisti nos in contradictionem vicinis nostris: et inimici nostri subsannaverunt nos.

verses.textEn: O God of hosts, convert us. And reveal your face, and we will be saved.
