verses.textLa: Deus virtutum converte nos: et ostende faciem tuam: et salvi erimus.

verses.textEn: You have transferred a vineyard from Egypt. You have cast out the Gentiles, and planted it.
verses.textLa: Vineam de Ægypto transtulisti: eiecisti Gentes, et plantasti eam.

verses.textEn: You were the leader of the journey in its sight. You planted its roots, and it filled the earth.
verses.textLa: Dux itineris fuisti in conspectu eius: plantasti radices eius, et implevit terram.

verses.textEn: Its shadow covered the hills, and its branches covered the cedars of God.
verses.textLa: Operuit montes umbra eius: et arbusta eius cedros Dei.

verses.textEn: It extended its new branches even to the sea, and its new seedlings even to the river.
verses.textLa: Extendit palmites suos usque ad mare: et usque ad flumen propagines eius.

verses.textEn: So then, why have you destroyed its walls, so that all those who pass by the way gather its grapes?
verses.textLa: Ut quid destruxisti maceriam eius: et vindemiant eam omnes, qui prætergrediuntur viam?

verses.textEn: The wild boar of the forest has trampled it, and a single wild beast has laid waste to it.
verses.textLa: Exterminavit eam aper de silva: et singularis ferus depastus est eam.
verses.notes: The word ‘exterminavit’ does not translate as ‘exterminate.’ Rather, it has the sense of crossing a limit or border, or breaking out of a limit or border. In this context, the sense is that the borders and fences of the vineyard have been broken down and trampled over. Also, the ‘singularis ferus’ could be a ‘single wild beast,’ or even a ‘singular wild beast.’

verses.textEn: Turn back, O God of hosts. Look down from heaven, and see, and visit this vineyard;
verses.textLa: Deus virtutum convertere: respice de cælo, et vide, et visita vineam istam.

verses.textEn: and complete what your right hand has planted, and look upon the son of man, whom you have confirmed for yourself.
verses.textLa: Et perfice eam, quam plantavit dextera tua: et super filium hominis, quem confirmasti tibi.

verses.textEn: Whatever has been set on fire and dug under will perish at the rebuke of your countenance.
verses.textLa: Incensa igni, et suffossa ab increpatione vultus tui peribunt.

verses.textEn: Let your hand be over the man on your right, and over the son of man, whom you have confirmed for yourself.
verses.textLa: Fiat manus tua super virum dexteræ tuæ: et super filium hominis, quem confirmasti tibi.

verses.textEn: For we do not depart from you, and you will revive us. And we will invoke your name.
verses.textLa: Et non discedimus a te, vivificabis nos: et nomen tuum invocabimus.

verses.textEn: O Lord, God of hosts, convert us. And reveal your face, and we will be saved.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus virtutum converte nos: et ostende faciem tuam, et salvi erimus.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the wine and oil presses. A Psalm of Asaph himself.
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro torcularibus, Psalmus ipsi Asaph.

verses.textEn: Exult before God our helper. Sing joyfully to the God of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Exultate Deo adiutori nostro: iubilate Deo Iacob.

verses.textEn: Take up a psalm, and bring forth the timbrel: a pleasing Psalter with stringed instruments.
verses.textLa: Sumite psalmum, et date tympanum: psalterium iucundum cum cithara.
verses.notes: Even though the word ‘psalterium’ literally refers to an ancient type of musical instrument, it was used to accompany psalms and hymns. Therefore, the word also indirectly refers to the Psalter, that is, to the psalms and particularly to the psalms when they are sung or chanted or accompanied by music. The less literal translation is more meaningful.

verses.textEn: Sound the trumpet at the new moon, on the noteworthy day of your solemnity,
verses.textLa: Buccinate in Neomenia tuba, in insigni die solemnitatis vestræ:

verses.textEn: for it is a precept in Israel and a judgment for the God of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Quia præceptum in Israel est: et iudicium Deo Iacob.

verses.textEn: He set it as a testimony with Joseph, when he went out of the land of Egypt. He heard a tongue that he did not know.
verses.textLa: Testimonium in Ioseph posuit illud, cum exiret de Terra Ægypti: linguam, quam non noverat, audivit.

verses.textEn: He turned the burdens away from his back. His hands had been a slave to baskets.
verses.textLa: Divertit ab oneribus dorsum eius: manus eius in cophino servierunt.

verses.textEn: You called upon me in tribulation, and I freed you. I heard you within the hidden tempest. I tested you with waters of contradiction.
verses.textLa: In tribulatione invocasti me, et liberavi te: exaudivi te in abscondito tempestatis: probavi te apud aquam contradictionis.

verses.textEn: My people, listen and I will call you to testify. If, O Israel, you will pay heed to me,
verses.textLa: Audi populus meus, et contestabor te: Israel si audieris me,

verses.textEn: then there will be no new god among you, nor will you adore a foreign god.
verses.textLa: non erit in te deus recens, neque adorabis deum alienum.

verses.textEn: For I am the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt. Widen your mouth, and I will fill it.
verses.textLa: Ego enim sum Dominus Deus tuus, qui eduxi te de terra Ægypti: dilata os tuum, et implebo illud.

verses.textEn: But my people did not hear my voice, and Israel was not attentive to me.
verses.textLa: Et non audivit populus meus vocem meam: et Israel non intendit mihi.

verses.textEn: And so, I sent them away, according to the desires of their heart. They will go forth according to their own inventions.
verses.textLa: Et dimisi eos secundum desideria cordis eorum, ibunt in adinventionibus suis.

verses.textEn: If my people had heard me, if Israel had walked in my ways,
verses.textLa: Si populus meus audisset me: Israel si in viis meis ambulasset:

verses.textEn: I would have humbled their enemies, as if it were nothing, and I would have sent my hand upon those who troubled them.
verses.textLa: Pro nihilo forsitan inimicos eorum humiliassem: et super tribulantes eos misissem manum meam.
verses.notes: Or, ‘perhaps for nothing, I would have humbled their enemies.’

verses.textEn: The enemies of the Lord have lied to him, and their time will come, in every age.
verses.textLa: Inimici Domini mentiti sunt ei: et erit tempus eorum in sæcula.
verses.notes: Or, ‘and time will be theirs forever.’ The wicked never experience the timelessness of eternity. They will be trapped in the cycle of time, within the fires of Hell, without ceasing.

verses.textEn: And he fed them from the fat of the grain, and he saturated them with honey from the rock.
verses.textLa: Et cibavit eos ex adipe frumenti: et de petra, melle saturavit eos.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of Asaph. God has stood in the synagogue of gods, but, in their midst, he decides between gods.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Asaph. Deus stetit in synagoga deorum: in medio autem deos diiudicat.

verses.textEn: How long will you judge unjustly and favor the faces of sinners?
verses.textLa: Usquequo iudicatis iniquitatem: et facies peccatorum sumitis?

verses.textEn: Judge for the indigent and the orphan. Do justice to the humble and the poor.
verses.textLa: Iudicate egeno, et pupillo: humilem, et pauperem iustificate.

verses.textEn: Rescue the poor, and free the needy from the hand of the sinner.
verses.textLa: Eripite pauperem: et egenum de manu peccatoris liberate.

verses.textEn: They did not know and did not understand. They wander in darkness. All the foundations of the earth will be moved.
verses.textLa: Nescierunt, neque intellexerunt, in tenebris ambulant: movebuntur omnia fundamenta terræ.

verses.textEn: I said: You are gods, and all of you are sons of the Most High.
verses.textLa: Ego dixi: dii estis, et filii excelsi omnes.

verses.textEn: But you will die like men, and you will fall just like one of the princes.
verses.textLa: Vos autem sicut homines moriemini: et sicut unus de principibus cadetis.

verses.textEn: Rise up, O God. Judge the earth. For you will inherit it with all the nations.
verses.textLa: Surge Deus, iudica terram: quoniam tu hereditabis in omnibus gentibus.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm of Asaph.
verses.textLa: Canticum Psalmi Asaph.

verses.textEn: O God, who will ever be like you? Do not be silent, and do not be unmoved, O God.
verses.textLa: Deus, quis similis erit tibi? ne taceas, neque compescaris Deus:

verses.textEn: For behold, your enemies have sounded off, and those who hate you have carried out a head.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ecce inimici tui sonuerunt: et qui oderunt te, extulerunt caput.
verses.notes: The verb ‘extulerunt’ can refer to carrying someone out to burial, or, more generally, to carrying out or raising up something.

verses.textEn: They have acted with malice in counsel over your people, and they have plotted against your holy ones.
verses.textLa: Super populum tuum malignaverunt consilium: et cogitaverunt adversus sanctos tuos.

verses.textEn: They have said, “Come, let us scatter them from the nations and not allow the name of Israel to be remembered any longer.”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt: Venite, et disperdamus eos de gente: et non memoretur nomen Israel ultra.

verses.textEn: For they plotted unanimously. Joined together against you, they ordained a covenant:
verses.textLa: Quoniam cogitaverunt unanimiter: simul adversum te testamentum disposuerunt,
verses.notes: This and the subsequent verses refer to the deal made by the Antichrist with those who are unfaithful to Christ (as described in Daniel 9:27). Those who are unfaithful to the Church unite with the Antichrist to try to destroy the Church from within, but setting up false worship and perverse teachings. It is the tabernacle of those who have gone astray from Christ.

verses.textEn: the tabernacle of Edomites and Ishmaelites, and Moab and the Hagarites,
verses.textLa: tabernacula Idumæorum et Ismahelitæ: Moab, et Agareni,

verses.textEn: and Gebal, and Ammon, and Amalek, the foreigners among the inhabitants of Tyre.
verses.textLa: Gebal, et Ammon, et Amalec: alienigenæ cum habitantibus Tyrum.

verses.textEn: For even Assur comes with them. They have become the helpers of the sons of Lot.
verses.textLa: Etenim Assur venit cum illis: facti sunt in adiutorium filiis Lot.
verses.notes: Assur is the name of a false god of Assyria; the name is also used to refer to the Antichrist, because he is a false god from Assyria.

verses.textEn: Do to them as you did to Midian and Sisera, just as to Jabin at the torrent of Kishon.
verses.textLa: Fac illis sicut Madian et Sisaræ: sicut Iabin in torrente Cisson.

verses.textEn: They perished at Endor, and they became like the dung of the earth.
verses.textLa: Disperierunt in Endor: facti sunt ut stercus terræ.

verses.textEn: Set their leaders to be like Oreb and Zeeb, and Zebah and Zalmunna: all their leaders
verses.textLa: Pone principes eorum sicut Oreb, et Zeb, et Zebee, et Salmana: Omnes principes eorum:

verses.textEn: who said, “Let us possess the Sanctuary of God for an inheritance.”
verses.textLa: qui dixerunt: Hereditate possideamus Sanctuarium Dei.

verses.textEn: My God, set them like a wheel, and like stubble before the face of the wind.
verses.textLa: Deus meus pone illos ut rotam: et sicut stipulam ante faciem venti.

verses.textEn: Set them like a fire burning up the forest, and like a flame burning up the mountains.
verses.textLa: Sicut ignis, qui comburit silvam: et sicut flamma comburens montes:

verses.textEn: So will you pursue them in your tempest, and disturb them in your wrath.
verses.textLa: Ita persequeris illos in tempestate tua: et in ira tua turbabis eos.

verses.textEn: Fill their faces with shame, and they will seek your name, O Lord.
verses.textLa: Imple facies eorum ignominia: et quærent nomen tuum, Domine.

verses.textEn: Let them be ashamed and troubled, from age to age, and let them be confounded and perish.
verses.textLa: Erubescant, et conturbentur in sæculum sæculi: et confundantur, et pereant.

verses.textEn: And let them know that the Lord is your name. You alone are the Most High in all the earth.
verses.textLa: Et cognoscant quia nomen tibi Dominus: tu solus Altissimus in omni terra.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. For the wine and oil presses. A Psalm to the sons of Korah.
verses.textLa: In finem, Pro torcularibus filiis Core, Psalmus.

verses.textEn: How beloved are your tabernacles, O Lord of hosts!
verses.textLa: Quam dilecta tabernacula tua Domine virtutum:

verses.textEn: My soul longs and faints for the courts of the Lord. My heart and my flesh have exulted in the living God.
verses.textLa: concupiscit, et deficit anima mea in atria Domini: Cor meum, et caro mea exultaverunt in Deum vivum.

verses.textEn: For even the sparrow has found a home for himself, and the turtle-dove a nest for herself, where she may lay her young: your altars, O Lord of hosts, my king and my God.
verses.textLa: Etenim passer invenit sibi domum: et turtur nidum sibi, ubi ponat pullos suos: altaria tua Domine virtutum: Rex meus, et Deus meus.

verses.textEn: Blessed are those who dwell in your house, O Lord. They will praise you from age to age.
verses.textLa: Beati, qui habitant in domo tua Domine: in sæcula sæculorum laudabunt te.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man whose help is from you. In his heart, he is disposed to ascend
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, cuius est auxilium abs te: ascensiones in corde suo disposuit,

verses.textEn: from the valley of tears, from the place which he has determined.
verses.textLa: in valle lacrymarum in loco, quem posuit.

verses.textEn: For even the lawgiver will provide a blessing; they will go from virtue to virtue. The God of gods will be seen in Zion.
verses.textLa: Etenim benedictionem dabit legislator, ibunt de virtute in virtutem: videbitur Deus deorum in Sion.

verses.textEn: O Lord, God of hosts, hear my prayer. Pay attention, O God of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus virtutum exaudi orationem meam: auribus percipe Deus Iacob.

verses.textEn: O God, gaze upon our protector, and look upon the face of your Christ.
verses.textLa: Protector noster aspice Deus: et respice in faciem Christi tui.

verses.textEn: For one day in your courts is better than thousands elsewhere. I have chosen to be lowly in the house of my God, rather than to dwell in the tabernacles of sinners.
verses.textLa: Quia melior est dies una in atriis tuis super millia. Elegi abiectus esse in domo Dei mei: magis quam habitare in tabernaculis peccatorum.

verses.textEn: For God loves mercy and truth. The Lord will give grace and glory.
verses.textLa: Quia misericordiam, et veritatem diligit Deus: gratiam, et gloriam dabit Dominus.

verses.textEn: He will not withhold good things from those who walk in innocence. O Lord of hosts, blessed is the man who hopes in you.
verses.textLa: Non privabit bonis eos, qui ambulant in innocentia: Domine virtutum, beatus homo, qui sperat in te.

verses.textEn: Unto the end. A Psalm to the sons of Korah.
verses.textLa: In finem, filiis Core, Psalmus.

verses.textEn: O Lord, you have blessed your land. You have turned aside the captivity of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Benedixisti Domine terram tuam: avertisti captivitatem Iacob.

verses.textEn: You have released the iniquity of your people. You have covered all their sins.
verses.textLa: Remisisti iniquitatem plebis tuæ: operuisti omnia peccata eorum.

verses.textEn: You have mitigated all your wrath. You have turned aside from the wrath of your indignation.
verses.textLa: Mitigasti omnem iram tuam: avertisti ab ira indignationis tuæ.

verses.textEn: Convert us, O God, our Savior, and turn your anger away from us.
verses.textLa: Converte nos Deus salutaris noster: et averte iram tuam a nobis.

verses.textEn: Will you be angry with us forever? And will you extend your wrath from generation to generation?
verses.textLa: Numquid in æternum irasceris nobis? aut extendes iram tuam a generatione in generationem?

verses.textEn: O God, you will turn back and revive us. And your people will rejoice in you.
verses.textLa: Deus tu conversus vivificabis nos: et plebs tua lætabitur in te.

verses.textEn: O Lord, reveal to us your mercy, and grant to us your salvation.
verses.textLa: Ostende nobis Domine misericordiam tuam: et salutare tuum da nobis.

verses.textEn: I will listen to what the Lord God may be saying to me. For he will speak peace to his people, and to his saints, and to those who are being converted to the heart.
verses.textLa: Audiam quid loquatur in me Dominus Deus: quoniam loquetur pacem in plebem suam. Et super sanctos suos: et in eos, qui convertuntur ad cor.
verses.notes: Or, ‘converted to the core.’

verses.textEn: So then, truly his salvation is near to those who fear him, so that glory may inhabit our land.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen prope timentes eum salutare ipsius: ut inhabitet gloria in terra nostra.

verses.textEn: Mercy and truth have met each other. Justice and peace have kissed.
verses.textLa: Misericordia, et veritas obviaverunt sibi: iustitia, et pax osculatæ sunt.

verses.textEn: Truth has risen from the earth, and justice has gazed down from heaven.
verses.textLa: Veritas de terra orta est: et iustitia de cælo prospexit.

verses.textEn: For so will the Lord give goodness, and our earth will give her fruit.
verses.textLa: Etenim Dominus dabit benignitatem: et terra nostra dabit fructum suum.

verses.textEn: Justice will walk before him, and he will set his steps upon the way.
verses.textLa: Iustitia ante eum ambulabit: et ponet in via gressus suos.

verses.textEn: A Prayer of David himself. Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear me. For I am needy and poor.
verses.textLa: Oratio ipsi David. Inclina Domine aurem tuam, et exaudi me: quoniam inops, et pauper sum ego.

verses.textEn: Preserve my soul, for I am holy. My God, bring salvation to your servant who hopes in you.
verses.textLa: Custodi animam meam, quoniam sanctus sum: salvum fac servum tuum, Deus meus, sperantem in te.

verses.textEn: O Lord, be merciful to me, for I have cried out to you all day long.
verses.textLa: Miserere mei Domine, quoniam ad te clamavi tota die:

verses.textEn: Give joy to the soul of your servant, for I have lifted up my soul to you, Lord.
verses.textLa: lætifica animam servi tui, quoniam ad te Domine animam meam levavi.

verses.textEn: For you are sweet and mild, Lord, and plentiful in mercy to all who call upon you.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu Domine suavis, et mitis: et multæ misericordiæ omnibus invocantibus te.

verses.textEn: Pay attention, Lord, to my prayer, and attend to the voice of my supplication.
verses.textLa: Auribus percipe Domine orationem meam: et intende voci deprecationis meæ.

verses.textEn: In the day of my tribulation, I cried out to you, because you heeded me.
verses.textLa: In die tribulationis meæ clamavi ad te: quia exaudisti me.

verses.textEn: There is no one like you among the gods, O Lord, and there is no one like you in your works.
verses.textLa: Non est similis tui in diis Domine: et non est secundum opera tua.

verses.textEn: All the nations, which you have made, will draw near and adore in your presence, O Lord. And they will glorify your name.
verses.textLa: Omnes gentes quascumque fecisti, venient, et adorabunt coram te Domine: et glorificabunt nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: For you are great, and you perform wonders. You alone are God.
verses.textLa: Quoniam magnus es tu, et faciens mirabilia: tu es Deus solus.

verses.textEn: Lead me, O Lord, in your way, and I will walk in your truth. May my heart rejoice, so that it will fear your name.
verses.textLa: Deduc me Domine in via tua, et ingrediar in veritate tua: lætetur cor meum ut timeat nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: I will confess to you, O Lord my God, with my whole heart. And I will glorify your name in eternity.
verses.textLa: Confitebor tibi Domine Deus meus in toto corde meo. Et glorificabo nomen tuum in æternum:

verses.textEn: For your mercy toward me is great, and you have rescued my soul from the lower part of Hell.
verses.textLa: Quia misericordia tua magna est super me: et eruisti animam meam ex inferno inferiori.
verses.notes: Or, ‘from the deepest depths.’ Or, ‘from the lowest part of the underworld.’ Or, ‘from the bottom of Hell.’

verses.textEn: O God, the iniquitous have risen up against me, and the synagogue of the powerful have sought my soul, and they have not placed you in their sight.
verses.textLa: Deus, iniqui insurrexerunt super me, et synagoga potentium quæsierunt animam meam: et non proposuerunt te in conspectu suo.

verses.textEn: And you, Lord God, are compassionate and merciful, being patient and full of mercy and truthful.
verses.textLa: Et tu Domine Deus miserator et misericors, patiens, et multæ misericordiæ, et verax.

verses.textEn: Look down upon me and have mercy on me. Grant your authority to your servant, and bring salvation to the son of your handmaid.
verses.textLa: Respice in me, et miserere mei, da imperium tuum puero tuo: et salvum fac filium ancillæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: Make me a sign of what is good, so that those who hate me, may look and be confounded. For you, O Lord, have helped me and consoled me.
verses.textLa: Fac mecum signum in bonum, ut videant qui oderunt me, et confundantur: quoniam tu Domine adiuvisti me, et consolatus es me.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm to the sons of Korah. Its foundations are in the holy mountains:
verses.textLa: Filiis Core, Psalmus Cantici. Fundamenta eius in montibus sanctis:

verses.textEn: the Lord loves the gates of Zion above all the tabernacles of Jacob.
verses.textLa: diligit Dominus portas Sion super omnia tabernacula Iacob.

verses.textEn: Glorious things are being said of you, O City of God.
verses.textLa: Gloriosa dicta sunt de te, civitas Dei.

verses.textEn: I will be mindful of Rahab and of Babylon knowing me. Behold, the foreigners, and Tyre, and the people of the Ethiopians: these have been there.
verses.textLa: Memor ero Rahab, et Babylonis scientium me. Ecce alienigenæ, et Tyrus, et populus Æthiopum, hi fuerunt illic.

verses.textEn: Will not Zion say that this man and that man were born in her? And the Most High himself has founded her.
verses.textLa: Numquid Sion dicet: Homo, et homo natus est in ea: et ipse fundavit eam Altissimus?

verses.textEn: The Lord will explain, in the writings of peoples and of leaders, about those who have been in her.
verses.textLa: Dominus narrabit in scripturis populorum, et principum: horum, qui fuerunt in ea.

verses.textEn: For so the dwelling place within you is with all rejoicing.
verses.textLa: Sicut lætantium omnium habitatio est in te.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm to the sons of Korah. Unto the end. For Mahalath, to answer the understanding of Heman the Ezrahite.
verses.textLa: Canticum Psalmi, Filiis Core, in finem, pro Maheleth ad respondendum, intellectus Eman Ezrahitæ.

verses.textEn: O Lord, God of my salvation: I have cried out, day and night, in your presence.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus salutis meæ: in die clamavi, et nocte coram te.

verses.textEn: Let my prayer enter in your sight. Incline your ear to my petition.
verses.textLa: Intret in conspectu tuo oratio mea: inclina aurem tuam ad precem meam:

verses.textEn: For my soul has been filled with evils, and my life has drawn near to Hell.
verses.textLa: Quia repleta est malis anima mea: et vita mea inferno appropinquavit.

verses.textEn: I am considered to be among those who will descend into the pit. I have become like a man without assistance,
verses.textLa: Æstimatus sum cum descendentibus in lacum: factus sum sicut homo sine adiutorio,

verses.textEn: idle among the dead. I am like the wounded sleeping in sepulchers, whom you no longer remember, and who have been repelled by your hand.
verses.textLa: inter mortuos liber, Sicut vulnerati dormientes in sepulchris, quorum non es memor amplius: et ipsi de manu tua repulsi sunt.

verses.textEn: They have lain me in the lower pit: in dark places and in the shadow of death.
verses.textLa: Posuerunt me in lacu inferiori: in tenebrosis, et in umbra mortis.

verses.textEn: Your fury has been confirmed over me. And you have brought all your waves upon me.
verses.textLa: Super me confirmatus est furor tuus: et omnes fluctus tuos induxisti super me.

verses.textEn: You have sent my acquaintances far from me. They have set me as an abomination to themselves. I was handed over, yet I did not depart.
verses.textLa: Longe fecisti notos meos a me: posuerunt me abominationem sibi. Traditus sum, et non egrediebar:
verses.notes: In other words: ‘I was handed over (to be harmed), even though I was not taken captive or taken away.’

verses.textEn: My eyes languished before destitution. All day long, I cried out to you, O Lord. I stretched out my hands to you.
verses.textLa: oculi mei languerunt præ inopia. Clamavi ad te Domine tota die: expandi ad te manus meas.

verses.textEn: Will you perform wonders for the dead? Or will physicians raise to life, and so confess to you?
verses.textLa: Numquid mortuis facies mirabilia: aut medici suscitabunt, et confitebuntur tibi?

verses.textEn: Could anyone declare your mercy in the sepulcher, or your truth from within perdition?
verses.textLa: Numquid narrabit aliquis in sepulchro misericordiam tuam, et veritatem tuam in perditione?

verses.textEn: Will your wonders be known in the darkness, or your justice in the land of oblivion?
verses.textLa: Numquid cognoscentur in tenebris mirabilia tua: et iustitia tua in terra oblivionis?

verses.textEn: And I have cried out to you, O Lord, and in early morning, my prayer will come before you.
verses.textLa: Et ego ad te, Domine, clamavi, et mane oratio mea præveniet te.

verses.textEn: Lord, why do you reject my prayer? Why do you turn your face away from me?
verses.textLa: Ut quid Domine repellis orationem meam: avertis faciem tuam a me?

verses.textEn: I am poor, and I have been amid hardships from my youth. And, though I have been exalted, I am humbled and disturbed.
verses.textLa: Pauper sum ego, et in laboribus a iuventute mea: exaltatus autem, humiliatus sum et conturbatus.

verses.textEn: Your wrath has crossed into me, and your terrors have disturbed me.
verses.textLa: In me transierunt iræ tuæ: et terrores tui conturbaverunt me.

verses.textEn: They have surrounded me like water, all day long. They have surrounded me, all at once.
verses.textLa: Circumdederunt me sicut aqua tota die: circumdederunt me simul.

verses.textEn: Friend and neighbor, and my acquaintances, you have sent far away from me, away from misery.
verses.textLa: Elongasti a me amicum, et proximum: et notos meos a miseria.

verses.textEn: The understanding of Ethan the Ezrahite.
verses.textLa: Intellectus Ethan Ezrahitæ.

verses.textEn: I will sing the mercies of the Lord in eternity. I will announce your truth with my mouth, from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Misericordias Domini in æternum cantabo. In generationem et generationem annunciabo veritatem tuam in ore meo.

verses.textEn: For you have said: Mercy will be built in the heavens, unto eternity. Your truth will be prepared there.
verses.textLa: Quoniam dixisti: In æternum misericordia ædificabitur in cælis: præparabitur veritas tua in eis.
verses.notes: The text literally means ‘in them,’ but ‘them’ refers to ‘the heavens.’ The translation of ‘there’ makes this reference clearer, since English does not generally refer to Heaven as ‘them.’

verses.textEn: I have set up a covenant with my elect. I have sworn to David my servant:
verses.textLa: Disposui testamentum electis meis, iuravi David servo meo:

verses.textEn: I will prepare your offspring, even in eternity. And I will build up your throne, from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: usque in æternum præparabo semen tuum. Et ædificabo in generationem, et generationem sedem tuam.

verses.textEn: The heavens will confess your miracles, Lord, and also your truth, in the Church of the saints.
verses.textLa: Confitebuntur cæli mirabilia tua Domine: etenim veritatem tuam in Ecclesia sanctorum.

verses.textEn: For who among the clouds is equal to the Lord? Who among the sons of God is like God?
verses.textLa: Quoniam quis in nubibus æquabitur Domino: similis erit Deo in filiis Dei?

verses.textEn: God is glorified by the counsel of the saints. He is great and terrible above all those who are around him.
verses.textLa: Deus, qui glorificatur in consilio sanctorum: magnus et terribilis super omnes qui in circuitu eius sunt.
verses.notes: The word ‘consilio’ in Latin can refer to either a deliberative group (council) or to a process of deliberating and giving advice (counsel). But in translating the Latin into English, one must choose within that broad range of meaning. The Latin word has a broader range of meaning than English words that could be used to translate. In this case, the translation is ‘counsel’ because God is more glorified in the deliberations, decisions, and advice of those who are holy than he is glorified by meetings of councils.

verses.textEn: O Lord, God of hosts, who is like you? You are powerful, Lord, and your truth is all around you.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus virtutum quis similis tibi? potens es Domine, et veritas tua in circuitu tuo.

verses.textEn: You rule over the power of the sea, and you even mitigate the movement of its waves.
verses.textLa: Tu dominaris potestati maris: motum autem fluctuum eius tu mitigas.

verses.textEn: You have humbled the arrogant one, like one who has been wounded. You have scattered your enemies with the arm of your strength.
verses.textLa: Tu humiliasti sicut vulneratum, superbum: in brachio virtutis tuæ dispersisti inimicos tuos.

verses.textEn: Yours are the heavens, and yours is the earth. You founded the whole world in all its fullness.
verses.textLa: Tui sunt cæli, et tua est terra, orbem terræ et plenitudinem eius tu fundasti:

verses.textEn: You created the north and the sea. Tabor and Hermon will exult in your name.
verses.textLa: Aquilonem, et mare tu creasti. Thabor et Hermon in nomine tuo exultabunt:

verses.textEn: Your arm acts with power. Let your hand be strengthened, and let your right hand be exalted.
verses.textLa: tuum brachium cum potentia. Firmetur manus tua, et exaltetur dextera tua:

verses.textEn: Justice and judgment are the preparation of your throne. Mercy and truth will precede your face.
verses.textLa: iustitia et iudicium præparatio sedis tuæ. Misericordia et veritas præcedent faciem tuam.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the people that knows jubilation. They will walk in the light of your countenance, O Lord,
verses.textLa: Beatus populus, qui scit iubilationem. Domine, in lumine vultus tui ambulabunt,

verses.textEn: and they will exult in your name all day long, and they will be exalted in your justice.
verses.textLa: et in nomine tuo exultabunt tota die: et in iustitia tua exaltabuntur.

verses.textEn: For you are the glory of their virtue, and in your goodness, our horn will be exalted.
verses.textLa: Quoniam gloria virtutis eorum tu es: et in beneplacito tuo exaltabitur cornu nostrum.

verses.textEn: For our assumption is of the Lord, and it is of our king, the holy one of Israel.
verses.textLa: Quia Domini est assumptio nostra: et sancti Israel regis nostri.
verses.notes: All of the resurrected faithful will be assumed into a new Heaven after the general Resurrection.

verses.textEn: Then you spoke in a vision to your holy ones, and you said: I have stationed help with the powerful one, and I have exalted the elect one from my people.
verses.textLa: Tunc locutus es in visione sanctis tuis, et dixisti: Posui adiutorium in potente: et exaltavi electum de plebe mea.

verses.textEn: I have found my servant David. I have anointed him with my holy oil.
verses.textLa: Inveni David servum meum: oleo sancto meo unxi eum.

verses.textEn: For my hand will assist him, and my arm will fortify him.
verses.textLa: Manus enim mea auxiliabitur ei: et brachium meum confortabit eum.

verses.textEn: The enemy will have no advantage over him, nor will the son of iniquity be positioned to harm him.
verses.textLa: Nihil proficiet inimicus in eo, et filius iniquitatis non apponet nocere ei.

verses.textEn: And I will cut down his enemies before his face. And those who hate him, I will turn to flight.
verses.textLa: Et concidam a facie ipsius inimicos eius: et odientes eum in fugam convertam.

verses.textEn: And my truth and my mercy will be with him. And his horn will be exalted in my name.
verses.textLa: Et veritas mea, et misericordia mea cum ipso: et in nomine meo exaltabitur cornu eius.

verses.textEn: And I will place his hand on the sea and his right hand on the rivers.
verses.textLa: Et ponam in mari manum eius: et in fluminibus dexteram eius.

verses.textEn: He will invoke me: “You are my father, my God, and the support of my salvation.”
verses.textLa: Ipse invocabit me: Pater meus es tu: Deus meus, et susceptor salutis meæ:

verses.textEn: And I will make him the first-born, preeminent before the kings of the earth.
verses.textLa: Et ego primogenitum ponam illum, excelsum præ regibus terræ.

verses.textEn: I will preserve my mercy for him eternally, and my covenant for him faithfully.
verses.textLa: In æternum servabo illi misericordiam meam: et testamentum meum fidele ipsi.

verses.textEn: And I will set his offspring from generation to generation, and his throne like the days of heaven.
verses.textLa: Et ponam in sæculum sæculi semen eius: et thronum eius sicut dies cæli.

verses.textEn: But if his sons abandon my law, and if they do not walk in my judgments,
verses.textLa: Si autem dereliquerint filii eius legem meam: et in iudiciis meis non ambulaverint:

verses.textEn: if they profane my justices, and if they do not keep my commandments:
verses.textLa: Si iustitias meas profanaverint: et mandata mea non custodierint:

verses.textEn: I will visit their iniquities with a rod, and their sins with a beating.
verses.textLa: Visitabo in virga iniquitates eorum: et in verberibus peccata eorum.

verses.textEn: But I will not scatter my mercy from him, and I will not do harm to my truth.
verses.textLa: Misericordiam autem meam non dispergam ab eo: neque nocebo in veritate mea:

verses.textEn: And I will not profane my covenant, and I will not make void that which proceeds from my lips.
verses.textLa: Neque profanabo testamentum meum: et quæ procedunt de labiis meis non faciam irrita.

verses.textEn: I have sworn by my holiness one time: I will not lie to David,
verses.textLa: Semel iuravi in sancto meo, si David mentiar:

verses.textEn: his offspring will remain for eternity. And his throne will be like the sun in my sight,
verses.textLa: semen eius in æternum manebit. Et thronus eius sicut Sol in conspectu meo,

verses.textEn: and, like the moon, it is perfected in eternity, and it is a faithful witness in heaven.
verses.textLa: et sicut Luna perfecta in æternum: et testis in cælo fidelis.

verses.textEn: Yet, truly, you have rejected and despised, you have pushed away, my Christ.
verses.textLa: Tu vero repulisti et despexisti: distulisti Christum tuum.

verses.textEn: You have overthrown the covenant of your servant. You have profaned his sanctuary on earth.
verses.textLa: Evertisti testamentum servi tui: profanasti in terra Sanctuarium eius.

verses.textEn: You have destroyed all his fences. You have made his territory dreadful.
verses.textLa: Destruxisti omnes sepes eius: posuisti firmamentum eius formidinem.

verses.textEn: All who pass by the way have plundered him. He has become a disgrace to his neighbors.
verses.textLa: Diripuerunt eum omnes transeuntes viam: factus est opprobrium vicinis suis.

verses.textEn: You have exalted the right hand of those who oppress him. You have brought joy to all his enemies.
verses.textLa: Exaltasti dexteram deprimentium eum: lætificasti omnes inimicos eius.

verses.textEn: You have diverted the help of his sword, and you have not assisted him in battle.
verses.textLa: Avertisti adiutorium gladii eius: et non es auxiliatus ei in bello.

verses.textEn: You have torn him away from cleansing, and you have smashed his throne down to the ground.
verses.textLa: Destruxisti eum ab emundatione: et sedem eius in terram collisisti.

verses.textEn: You have reduced the days of his time. You have flooded him with confusion.
verses.textLa: Minorasti dies temporis eius: perfudisti eum confusione.

verses.textEn: How long, O Lord? Will you turn away unto the end? Will your wrath flare up like a fire?
verses.textLa: Usquequo Domine avertis in finem: exardescet sicut ignis ira tua?

verses.textEn: Remember what my substance is. For could you really have appointed all the sons of men in vain?
verses.textLa: Memorare quæ mea substantia: numquid enim vane constituisti omnes filios hominum?

verses.textEn: Who is the man that will live, and yet not see death? Who will rescue his own soul from the hand of the underworld?
verses.textLa: Quis est homo, qui vivet, et non videbit mortem: eruet animam suam de manu inferi?

verses.textEn: O Lord, where are your mercies of antiquity, just as you swore to David in your truth?
verses.textLa: Ubi sunt misericordiæ tuæ antiquæ Domine, sicut iurasti David in veritate tua?

verses.textEn: Be mindful, O Lord, of the disgrace of your servants (which I have sustained in my sinews) among many nations.
verses.textLa: Memor esto Domine opprobrii servorum tuorum (quod continui in sinu meo) multarum gentium.

verses.textEn: With these, your enemies have reproached you, O Lord; with these, they have reproached the commutation of your Christ.
verses.textLa: Quod exprobraverunt inimici tui Domine, quod exprobraverunt commutationem Christi tui.
verses.notes: This last part of the verse refers to the trans-substantiation, that is, to the consecration of bread and wine to become the body and blood of Christ. The word ‘commutation’ refers to changing one thing into another. The commutation that gives us Christ in the Eucharist is called trans-substantiation. The doctrine of trans-substantiation is true doctrine, but the terminology itself is superfluous. Another term could be used to describe the same truth.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the Lord for all eternity. Amen. Amen.
verses.textLa: Benedictus Dominus in æternum: fiat, fiat.

verses.textEn: A prayer of Moses, the man of God. O Lord, you have been our refuge from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Oratio Moysi hominis Dei. Domine, refugium factus es nobis: a generatione in generationem.

verses.textEn: Before the mountains became, or the land was formed along with the world: from ages past, even to all ages, you are God.
verses.textLa: Priusquam montes fierent, aut formaretur terra, et orbis: a sæculo et usque in sæculum tu es Deus.

verses.textEn: And, lest man be turned aside in humiliation, you have said: Be converted, O sons of men.
verses.textLa: Ne avertas hominem in humilitatem: et dixisti: Convertimini filii hominum.

verses.textEn: For a thousand years before your eyes are like the days of yesterday, which have passed by, and they are like a watch of the night,
verses.textLa: Quoniam mille anni ante oculos tuos, tamquam dies hesterna, quæ præteriit, Et custodia in nocte,

verses.textEn: which was held for nothing: so their years shall be.
verses.textLa: quæ pro nihilo habentur, eorum anni erunt.
verses.notes: Either the watch of the night was considered to be nothing (meaningless, valueless), or it was uneventful (nothing to report on that watch), or even futile.

verses.textEn: In the morning, he may pass away like grass; in the morning, he may flower and pass away. In the evening, he will fall, and harden, and become dry.
verses.textLa: Mane sicut herba transeat, mane floreat, et transeat: vespere decidat, induret, et arescat.

verses.textEn: For, at your wrath, we have withered away, and we have been disturbed by your fury.
verses.textLa: Quia defecimus in ira tua, et in furore tuo turbati sumus.

verses.textEn: You have placed our iniquities in your sight, our age in the illumination of your countenance.
verses.textLa: Posuisti iniquitates nostras in conspectu tuo: sæculum nostrum in illuminatione vultus tui.

verses.textEn: For all our days have faded away, and at your wrath, we have fainted. Our years will be considered to be like a spider’s web.
verses.textLa: Quoniam omnes dies nostri defecerunt: et in ira tua defecimus. Anni nostri sicut aranea meditabuntur:

verses.textEn: The days of our years in them are seventy years. But in the powerful, they are eighty years, and more of these are with hardship and sorrow. For mildness has overwhelmed us, and we shall be corrected.
verses.textLa: dies annorum nostrorum in ipsis, septuaginta anni. Si autem in potentatibus octoginta anni: et amplius eorum, labor et dolor. Quoniam supervenit mansuetudo: et corripiemur.

verses.textEn: Who knows the power of your wrath? And, before fear, can your wrath
verses.textLa: Quis novit potestatem iræ tuæ: et præ timore tuo iram tuam

verses.textEn: be numbered? So make known your right hand, along with men learned in heart, in wisdom.
verses.textLa: dinumerare? Dexteram tuam sic notam fac: et eruditos corde in sapientia.

verses.textEn: Return, O Lord, how long? And may you be persuaded on behalf of your servants.
verses.textLa: Convertere Domine usquequo? et deprecabilis esto super servos tuos.

verses.textEn: We were filled in the morning with your mercy, and we exulted and delighted all our days.
verses.textLa: Repleti sumus mane misericordia tua: et exultavimus, et delectati sumus omnibus diebus nostris.

verses.textEn: We have been rejoicing, because of the days in which you humbled us, because of the years in which we saw evils.
verses.textLa: Lætati sumus pro diebus, quibus nos humiliasti: annis, quibus vidimus mala.

verses.textEn: Look down upon your servants and upon their works, and direct their sons.
verses.textLa: Respice in servos tuos, et in opera tua: et dirige filios eorum.

verses.textEn: And may the splendor of the Lord our God be upon us. And so, direct the works of our hands over us; direct even the work of our hands.
verses.textLa: Et sit splendor Domini Dei nostri super nos, et opera manuum nostrarum dirige super nos: et opus manuum nostrarum dirige.

verses.textEn: The Praise of a Canticle, of David. Whoever dwells with the assistance of the Most High will abide in the protection of the God of heaven.
verses.textLa: Laus Cantici David. Qui habitat in adiutorio Altissimi, in protectione Dei cæli commorabitur.
verses.notes: The Challoner revision has “God of Jacob,” whereas the original Douay-Rheims and the Wycliffe translations both have “God of heaven.” The Hetzenauer edition of 1914 (Latin Vulgate) has “Dei cæli.”

verses.textEn: He will say to the Lord, “You are my supporter and my refuge.” My God, I will hope in him.
verses.textLa: Dicet Domino: Susceptor meus es tu, et refugium meum: Deus meus sperabo in eum.

verses.textEn: For he has freed me from the snare of those who go hunting, and from the harsh word.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ipse liberavit me de laqueo venantium, et a verbo aspero.

verses.textEn: He will overshadow you with his shoulders, and you will hope under his wings.
verses.textLa: Scapulis suis obumbrabit tibi: et sub pennis eius sperabis:

verses.textEn: His truth will surround you with a shield. You will not be afraid: before the terror of the night,
verses.textLa: Scuto circumdabit te veritas eius: non timebis a timore nocturno,

verses.textEn: before the arrow flying in the day, before the troubles that wander in the darkness, nor of invasion and the midday demon.
verses.textLa: A sagitta volante in die, a negotio perambulante in tenebris: ab incursu, et dæmonio meridiano.

verses.textEn: A thousand will fall before your side and ten thousand before your right hand. Yet it will not draw near you.
verses.textLa: Cadent a latere tuo mille, et decem millia a dextris tuis: ad te autem non appropinquabit.

verses.textEn: So then, truly, you will consider with your eyes, and you will see the retribution of sinners.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen oculis tuis considerabis: et retributionem peccatorum videbis.

verses.textEn: For you, O Lord, are my hope. You have set the Most High as your refuge.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu es Domine spes mea: Altissimum posuisti refugium tuum.

verses.textEn: Disaster will not draw near to you, and the scourge will not approach your tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Non accedet ad te malum: et flagellum non appropinquabit tabernaculo tuo.

verses.textEn: For he has given his Angels charge over you, so as to preserve you in all your ways.
verses.textLa: Quoniam angelis suis mandavit de te: ut custodiant te in omnibus viis tuis.

verses.textEn: With their hands, they will carry you, lest you hurt your foot against a stone.
verses.textLa: In manibus portabunt te: ne forte offendas ad lapidem pedem tuum.

verses.textEn: You will walk over the asp and the king serpent, and you will trample the lion and the dragon.
verses.textLa: Super aspidem, et basiliscum ambulabis: et conculcabis leonem et draconem.
verses.notes: The word ‘basiliscum’ is derived from a Greek word meaning ‘king,’ and it is used in Latin to refer to a dangerous snake.

verses.textEn: Because he has hoped in me, I will free him. I will protect him because he has known my name.
verses.textLa: Quoniam in me speravit, liberabo eum: protegam eum, quoniam cognovit nomen meum.

verses.textEn: He will cry out to me, and I will heed him. I am with him in tribulation. I will rescue him, and I will glorify him.
verses.textLa: Clamabit ad me, et ego exaudiam eum: cum ipso sum in tribulatione: eripiam eum et glorificabo eum.

verses.textEn: I will fill him with length of days. And I will reveal to him my salvation.
verses.textLa: Longitudine dierum replebo eum: et ostendam illi salutare meum.

verses.textEn: A Canticle Psalm. On the day of the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Psalmus Cantici, In die Sabbati.

verses.textEn: It is good to confess to the Lord and to sing psalms to your name, O Most High:
verses.textLa: Bonum est confiteri Domino: et psallere nomini tuo Altissime.

verses.textEn: to announce your mercy in the morning, and your truth throughout the night,
verses.textLa: Ad annunciandum mane misericordiam tuam: et veritatem tuam per noctem.

verses.textEn: upon the ten strings, upon the psaltery, with a canticle, upon stringed instruments.
verses.textLa: In decachordo, psalterio: cum cantico, in cithara.

verses.textEn: For you, O Lord, have delighted me with your doings, and I will exult in the works of your hands.
verses.textLa: Quia delectasti me Domine in factura tua: et in operibus manuum tuarum exultabo.

verses.textEn: How great are your works, O Lord! Your thoughts have been made exceedingly deep.
verses.textLa: Quam magnificata sunt opera tua Domine! nimis profundæ factæ sunt cogitationes tuæ:

verses.textEn: A foolish man will not know these things, and a senseless one will not understand:
verses.textLa: Vir insipiens non cognoscet: et stultus non intelliget hæc.

verses.textEn: when sinners will have risen up like grass, and when all those who work iniquity will have appeared, that they shall pass away, age after age.
verses.textLa: Cum exorti fuerint peccatores sicut fœnum: et apparuerint omnes, qui operantur iniquitatem: Ut intereant in sæculum sæculi:

verses.textEn: But you, O Lord, are the Most High for all eternity.
verses.textLa: tu autem Altissimus in æternum Domine.

verses.textEn: For behold your enemies, O Lord, for behold your enemies will perish, and all those who work iniquity will be dispersed.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ecce inimici tui Domine, quoniam ecce inimici tui peribunt: et dispergentur omnes, qui operantur iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: And my horn will be exalted like that of the single-horned beast, and my old age will be exalted in fruitful mercy.
verses.textLa: Et exaltabitur sicut unicornis cornu meum: et senectus mea in misericordia uberi.
verses.notes: Here the adjective ‘uberi’ (fertile, fruitful, productive; related to the word for breast) is used to describe the mercy of one’s old age (old age is not generally thought of as fertile or productive).

verses.textEn: And my eye has looked down upon my enemies, and my ear will hear of the malignant rising up against me.
verses.textLa: Et despexit oculus meus inimicos meos: et in insurgentibus in me malignantibus audiet auris mea.

verses.textEn: The just one will flourish like the palm tree. He will be multiplied like the cedar of Lebanon.
verses.textLa: Iustus ut palma florebit: sicut cedrus Libani multiplicabitur.

verses.textEn: Those planted in the house of the Lord will flourish in the courts of the house of our God.
verses.textLa: Plantati in domo Domini, in atriis domus Dei nostri florebunt.

verses.textEn: They will still be multiplied in a fruitful old age, and they will endure well,
verses.textLa: Adhuc multiplicabuntur in senecta uberi: et bene patientes erunt,

verses.textEn: so that they may announce that the Lord our God is righteous and that there is no iniquity in him.
verses.textLa: ut annuncient: Quoniam rectus Dominus Deus noster: et non est iniquitas in eo.

verses.textEn: The Praise of a Canticle, of David himself. In the time before the Sabbath, when the earth was founded.
verses.textLa: Laus Cantici ipsi David, in die ante Sabbatum, quando fundata est terra.
verses.notes:
The numbering of the Ninety-Second Psalm has been altered in the CPDV and the corresponding edit of the Vulgate. The prologue is now verse one, and what was formerly one long first verse has been broken into verses two and three. The other verses are numbered consecutively, totaling seven verses instead of five.
 The word ‘die’ is translated as ‘time’ instead of ‘day’ because that is the meaning and because the use of day would be confusing since the creation of the world is metaphorically divided into 6 days. The 7th day was the first Sabbath, a day of rest.

verses.textEn: The Lord has reigned. He has been clothed with beauty.
verses.textLa: Dominus regnavit, decorem indutus est:

verses.textEn: The Lord has been clothed with strength, and he has girded himself. Yet he has also confirmed the world, which will not be moved.
verses.textLa: indutus est Dominus fortitudinem, et præcinxit se. Etenim firmavit orbem terræ, qui non commovebitur.

verses.textEn: My throne is prepared from of old. You are from everlasting.
verses.textLa: Parata sedes tua ex tunc: a sæculo tu es.

verses.textEn: The floods have lifted up, O Lord, the floods have lifted up their voice. The floods have lifted up their waves,
verses.textLa: Elevaverunt flumina Domine: elevaverunt flumina vocem suam. Elevaverunt flumina fluctus suos,

verses.textEn: before the noise of many waters. Wondrous are the surges of the sea; wondrous is the Lord on high.
verses.textLa: a vocibus aquarum multarum. Mirabiles elationes maris, mirabilis in altis Dominus.

verses.textEn: Your testimonies have been made exceedingly trustworthy. Sanctity befits your house, O Lord, with length of days.
verses.textLa: Testimonia tua credibilia facta sunt nimis: domum tuam decet sanctitudo Domine in longitudinem dierum.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. The Fourth Sabbath. The Lord is the God of retribution. The God of retribution acts in order to deliver.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David, Quarta Sabbati. Deus ultionum Dominus: Deus ultionum libere egit.

verses.textEn: Lift yourself up, for you judge the earth. Repay the arrogant with retribution.
verses.textLa: Exaltare qui iudicas terram: redde retributionem superbis.

verses.textEn: How long will sinners, O Lord, how long will sinners glory?
verses.textLa: Usquequo peccatores Domine: usquequo peccatores gloriabuntur:

verses.textEn: How long will they utter and speak iniquity? How long will all who work injustice speak out?
verses.textLa: Effabuntur, et loquentur iniquitatem: loquentur omnes, qui operantur iniustitiam?
verses.notes: The translation words ‘how long...’ are implied from the previous verse.

verses.textEn: They have humiliated your people, O Lord, and they have harassed your inheritance.
verses.textLa: Populum tuum Domine humiliaverunt: et hereditatem tuam vexaverunt.

verses.textEn: They have executed the widow and the new arrival, and they have slaughtered the orphan.
verses.textLa: Viduam, et advenam interfecerunt: et pupillos occiderunt.

verses.textEn: And they have said, “The Lord will not see, nor will the God of Jacob understand.”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt: Non videbit Dominus, nec intelliget Deus Iacob.

verses.textEn: Understand, you senseless ones among the people. And be wise at last, you foolish ones.
verses.textLa: Intelligite insipientes in populo: et stulti aliquando sapite.

verses.textEn: He who formed the ear, will he not hear? And he who forged the eye, does he not look closely?
verses.textLa: Qui plantavit aurem, non audiet? aut qui finxit oculum, non considerat?

verses.textEn: He who chastises nations, he who teaches man knowledge, will he not rebuke?
verses.textLa: Qui corripit gentes, non arguet: qui docet hominem scientiam?
verses.notes: Or, ‘He who chastises nations, will he not rebuke? for it is he who teaches man knowledge.’

verses.textEn: The Lord knows the thoughts of men: that these are in vain.
verses.textLa: Dominus scit cogitationes hominum, quoniam vanæ sunt.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man whom you will instruct, O Lord. And you will teach him from your law.
verses.textLa: Beatus homo, quem tu erudieris Domine: et de lege tua docueris eum.

verses.textEn: So may you soothe him from the evil days, until a pit may be dug for sinners.
verses.textLa: Ut mitiges ei a diebus malis: donec fodiatur peccatori fovea.

verses.textEn: For the Lord will not drive away his people, and he will not abandon his inheritance,
verses.textLa: Quia non repellet Dominus plebem suam: et hereditatem suam non derelinquet.

verses.textEn: even until the time when justice is being converted into judgment, and when those who are close to justice are all those who are upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Quoadusque iustitia convertatur in iudicium: et qui iuxta illam omnes qui recto sunt corde.
verses.notes: The pronoun ‘illam’ is singular feminine, so it refers to ‘justitia’ not ‘judicium.’ The translation is somewhat loose in order to preserve the meaning of the Latin.

verses.textEn: Who will rise up with me against the malignant? Or who will stand with me against the workers of iniquity?
verses.textLa: Quis consurget mihi adversus malignantes? aut quis stabit mecum adversus operantes iniquitatem?

verses.textEn: Except that the Lord assisted me, my soul almost would have dwelt in Hell.
verses.textLa: Nisi quia Dominus adiuvit me: paulominus habitasset in inferno anima mea.

verses.textEn: If ever I said, “My foot is slipping,” then your mercy, O Lord, assisted me.
verses.textLa: Si dicebam: Motus est pes meus: misericordia tua Domine adiuvabat me.

verses.textEn: According to the multitude of my sorrows in my heart, your consolations have given joy to my soul.
verses.textLa: Secundum multitudinem dolorum meorum in corde meo: consolationes tuæ lætificaverunt animam meam.

verses.textEn: Does the seat of iniquity adhere to you, you who contrive hardship within a commandment?
verses.textLa: Numquid adhæret tibi sedes iniquitatis: qui fingis laborem in præcepto?

verses.textEn: They will hunt down the soul of the just, and they will condemn innocent blood.
verses.textLa: Captabunt in animam iusti: et sanguinem innocentem condemnabunt.

verses.textEn: And the Lord has been made into a refuge for me, and my God into the assistance of my hope.
verses.textLa: Et factus est mihi Dominus in refugium: et Deus meus in adiutorium spei meæ.

verses.textEn: And he will repay them their iniquity, and he will destroy them in their malice. The Lord our God will utterly destroy them.
verses.textLa: Et reddet illis iniquitatem ipsorum: et in malitia eorum disperdet eos: disperdet illos Dominus Deus noster.

verses.textEn: The Praise of a Canticle, of David himself. Come, let us exult in the Lord. Let us shout joyfully to God, our Savior.
verses.textLa: Laus Cantici ipsi David. Venite, exultemus Domino: iubilemus Deo salutari nostro:
verses.notes: Or, ‘A Canticle Praise....’

verses.textEn: Let us anticipate his presence with confession, and let us sing joyfully to him with psalms.
verses.textLa: Præoccupemus faciem eius in confessione: et in psalmis iubilemus ei.

verses.textEn: For the Lord is a great God and a great King over all gods.
verses.textLa: Quoniam Deus magnus Dominus: et Rex magnus super omnes deos.

verses.textEn: For in his hand are all the limits of the earth, and the heights of the mountains are his.
verses.textLa: Quia in manu eius sunt omnes fines terræ: et altitudines montium ipsius sunt.

verses.textEn: For the sea is his, and he made it, and his hands formed the dry land.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ipsius est mare, et ipse fecit illud: et siccam manus eius formaverunt.

verses.textEn: Come, let us adore and fall prostrate, and let us weep before the Lord who made us.
verses.textLa: Venite adoremus, et procidamus: et ploremus ante Dominum, qui fecit nos.

verses.textEn: For he is the Lord our God, and we are the people of his pasture and the sheep of his hand.
verses.textLa: Quia ipse est Dominus Deus noster: et nos populus pascuæ eius, et oves manus eius.

verses.textEn: If today you hear his voice, harden not your hearts:
verses.textLa: Hodie si vocem eius audieritis, nolite obdurare corda vestra;

verses.textEn: as in the provocation, according to the day of temptation in the wilderness, where your fathers tempted me; they tested me, though they had seen my works.
verses.textLa: Sicut in irritatione secundum diem tentationis in deserto: ubi tentaverunt me patres vestri, probaverunt me, et viderunt opera mea.

verses.textEn: For forty years, I was offended by that generation, and I said: These have always strayed in heart.
verses.textLa: Quadraginta annis offensus fui generationi illi, et dixi: Semper hi errant corde.

verses.textEn: And these have not known my ways. So I swore in my wrath: They shall not enter into my rest.
verses.textLa: Et isti non cognoverunt vias meas: ut iuravi in ira mea: Si introibunt in requiem meam.

verses.textEn: A Canticle of David himself, when the house was built after the captivity. Sing to the Lord a new song. Sing to the Lord, all the earth.
verses.textLa: Canticum ipsi David, Quando domus ædificabatur post captivitatem. Cantate Domino canticum novum: cantate Domino omnis terra.

verses.textEn: Sing to the Lord and bless his name. Announce his salvation from day to day.
verses.textLa: Cantate Domino, et benedicite nomini eius: annunciate de die in diem salutare eius.

verses.textEn: Announce his glory among the Gentiles, his miracles among all peoples.
verses.textLa: Annunciate inter Gentes gloriam eius, in omnibus populis mirabilia eius.

verses.textEn: For the Lord is great and greatly to be praised. He is terrible, beyond all gods.
verses.textLa: Quoniam magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis: terribilis est super omnes deos.

verses.textEn: For all the gods of the Gentiles are demons, but the Lord made the heavens.
verses.textLa: Quoniam omnes dii Gentium dæmonia: Dominus autem cælos fecit.

verses.textEn: Confession and beauty are in his sight. Sanctity and magnificence are in his sanctuary.
verses.textLa: Confessio, et pulchritudo in conspectu eius: sanctimonia, et magnificentia in sanctificatione eius.
verses.notes: Or, ‘Purity and magnificence are in his sanctuary.’

verses.textEn: Bring to the Lord, you natives of the nations, bring to the Lord glory and honor.
verses.textLa: Afferte Domino patriæ gentium, afferte Domino gloriam et honorem:

verses.textEn: Bring to the Lord glory for his name. Lift up sacrifices, and enter into his courts.
verses.textLa: afferte Domino gloriam nomini eius. Tollite hostias, et introite in atria eius:

verses.textEn: Adore the Lord in his holy court. Let the entire earth be shaken before his face.
verses.textLa: adorate Dominum in atrio sancto eius. Commoveatur a facie eius universa terra:

verses.textEn: Say among the Gentiles: The Lord has reigned. For he has even corrected the whole world, which will not be shaken. He will judge the peoples with fairness.
verses.textLa: dicite in Gentibus quia Dominus regnavit. Etenim correxit orbem terræ qui non commovebitur: iudicabit populos in æquitate.
verses.notes: Even though the previous verse said that the entire earth could be shaken before the face of God, this verse says that the whole world will not be shaken (or moved). Presently, the earth can and will be shaken, but eventually God will establish His kingdom on earth and it shall never be shaken (or moved or destroyed) again.

verses.textEn: Let the heavens rejoice, and let the earth exult; let the sea and all its fullness be moved.
verses.textLa: Lætentur cæli, et exultet terra, commoveatur mare, et plenitudo eius:

verses.textEn: The fields and all the things that are in them will be glad. Then all the trees of the forest will rejoice
verses.textLa: gaudebunt campi, et omnia quæ in eis sunt. Tunc exultabunt omnia ligna silvarum

verses.textEn: before the face of the Lord: for he arrives. For he arrives to judge the earth. He will judge the whole world with fairness and the peoples with his truth.
verses.textLa: a facie Domini, quia venit: quoniam venit iudicare terram. Iudicabit orbem terræ in æquitate, et populos in veritate sua.

verses.textEn: This is to David, when his land was restored to him. The Lord has reigned, let the earth exult. Let the many islands rejoice.
verses.textLa: Huic David, Quando terra eius restituta est. Dominus regnavit, exultet terra: lætentur insulæ multæ.
verses.notes:
The first two words are usually translated as ‘to this David,’ or ‘to the same David.’ The word ‘huic’ is dative, indicating an indirect object, which is often translated using the English ‘to’ or ‘for.’ Essentially, the first word, ‘huic’ translates as ‘for this,’ or ‘to this.’ The word ‘David’ (as with many non-Latin names) is not usually altered in its ending to indicate case. The translation could be ‘To this David,’ but then the word ‘this’ would not be of much use, except to indicate the case of the word ‘David,’ i.e. ‘To David,’ rather than ‘To this David.’ Another possible translation (a somewhat loose translation), would be to view ‘David’ as the subject: ‘David is for this,’ which can be rephrased in English as ‘This is for David.’
 So the translation should be either: ‘To David,’ or, ‘This is for David.’ Both of which have approximately the same meaning.

verses.textEn: Clouds and mist are all around him. Justice and judgment are corrections from his throne.
verses.textLa: Nubes, et caligo in circuitu eius: iustitia, et iudicium correctio sedis eius.

verses.textEn: A fire will precede him, and it will enflame his enemies all around.
verses.textLa: Ignis ante ipsum præcedet, et inflammabit in circuitu inimicos eius.

verses.textEn: His lightnings have enlightened the whole world. The earth saw, and it was shaken.
verses.textLa: Illuxerunt fulgura eius orbi terræ: vidit, et commota est terra.

verses.textEn: The mountains flowed like wax before the face of the Lord, before the face of the Lord of all the earth.
verses.textLa: Montes, sicut cera fluxerunt a facie Domini: a facie Domini omnis terra.

verses.textEn: The heavens announced his justice, and all peoples saw his glory.
verses.textLa: Annunciaverunt cæli iustitiam eius: et viderunt omnes populi gloriam eius.

verses.textEn: May all those who adore graven images be confounded, along with those who glory in their false images. All you his Angels: Adore him.
verses.textLa: Confundantur omnes, qui adorant sculptilia: et qui gloriantur in simulacris suis. Adorate eum omnes angeli eius:

verses.textEn: Zion heard, and was glad. And the daughters of Judah exulted because of your judgments, O Lord.
verses.textLa: audivit, et lætata est Sion. Et exultaverunt filiæ Iudæ, propter iudicia tua Domine:

verses.textEn: For you are the Most High Lord over all the earth. You are greatly exalted above all gods.
verses.textLa: Quoniam tu Dominus altissimus super omnem terram: nimis exaltatus es super omnes deos.

verses.textEn: You who love the Lord: hate evil. The Lord watches over the souls of his holy ones. He will free them from the hand of the sinner.
verses.textLa: Qui diligitis Dominum, odite malum: custodit Dominus animas sanctorum suorum, de manu peccatoris liberabit eos.

verses.textEn: The light has risen for the just, and joy for the upright of heart.
verses.textLa: Lux orta est iusto, et rectis corde lætitia.

verses.textEn: Rejoice in the Lord, you just ones, and confess to the memory of his sanctuary.
verses.textLa: Lætamini iusti in Domino: et confitemini memoriæ sanctificationis eius.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. Sing to the Lord a new song, for he has performed wonders. His right hand has accomplished salvation for him, with his holy arm.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David. Cantate Domino canticum novum: quia mirabilia fecit. Salvavit sibi dextera eius: et brachium sanctum eius.

verses.textEn: The Lord has made known his salvation. He has revealed his justice in the sight of the nations.
verses.textLa: Notum fecit Dominus salutare suum: in conspectu gentium revelavit iustitiam suam.

verses.textEn: He has remembered his mercy and his truth toward the house of Israel. All the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God.
verses.textLa: Recordatus est misericordiæ suæ, et veritatis suæ domui Israel. Viderunt omnes termini terræ salutare Dei nostri.

verses.textEn: Sing joyfully to God, all the earth. Sing and exult, and sing psalms.
verses.textLa: Iubilate Deo omnis terra: cantate, et exultate, et psallite.

verses.textEn: Sing psalms to the Lord with stringed instruments, with strings and the voice of a psalmist,
verses.textLa: Psallite Domino in cithara, in cithara et voce psalmi:
verses.notes: The translation here is less strict, in order to take into account a wide range of musical instruments, rather than trying to convey the type of instruments used in ancient times.

verses.textEn: with subtle wind instruments and the voice of woodwinds. Make a joyful noise before the Lord our king.
verses.textLa: in tubis ductilibus, et voce tubæ corneæ. Iubilate in conspectu regis Domini:
verses.notes: The ‘ductile’ tuba or trumpet, is not so much made of ductile metal, as it is metaphorically ductile, i.e. subtle and easily flowing in musical quality. The ‘tubæ corneæ’ refers to woodwinds because ‘tubae’ refers to any type of wind instrument, and ‘corneae’ refers to anything made from the wood of the cornel tree.

verses.textEn: Let the sea be moved and all its fullness, the whole world and all who dwell in it.
verses.textLa: moveatur mare, et plenitudo eius: orbis terrarum, et qui habitant in eo.

verses.textEn: The rivers will clap their hands, the mountains will exult together,
verses.textLa: Flumina plaudent manu, simul montes exultabunt

verses.textEn: before the presence of the Lord. For he comes to judge the earth. He will judge the whole world with justice, and the peoples with fairness.
verses.textLa: a conspectu Domini: quoniam venit iudicare terram. Iudicabit orbem terrarum in iustitia, et populos in æquitate.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. The Lord has reigned: let the peoples be angry. He sits upon the cherubim: let the earth be moved.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David. Dominus regnavit, irascantur populi: qui sedet super cherubim, moveatur terra.

verses.textEn: The Lord is great in Zion, and he is high above all peoples.
verses.textLa: Dominus in Sion magnus: et excelsus super omnes populos.

verses.textEn: May they confess to your great name, for it is terrible and holy.
verses.textLa: Confiteantur nomini tuo magno: quoniam terribile, et sanctum est:

verses.textEn: And the honor of the king loves judgment. You have prepared guidance. You have accomplished judgment and justice in Jacob.
verses.textLa: et honor regis iudicium diligit. Tu parasti directiones: iudicium et iustitiam in Iacob tu fecisti.

verses.textEn: Exalt the Lord our God, and adore the footstool of his feet, for it is holy.
verses.textLa: Exaltate Dominum Deum nostrum, et adorate scabellum pedum eius: quoniam sanctum est.

verses.textEn: Moses and Aaron are among his priests, and Samuel is among those who call upon his name. They called upon the Lord, and he heeded them.
verses.textLa: Moyses et Aaron in sacerdotibus eius: et Samuel inter eos, qui invocant nomen eius: Invocabant Dominum, et ipse exaudiebat eos:

verses.textEn: He spoke to them in the pillar of the cloud. They kept his testimonies and the precept that he gave them.
verses.textLa: in columna nubis loquebatur ad eos. Custodiebant testimonia eius, et præceptum quod dedit illis.

verses.textEn: You heeded them, O Lord our God. You were a forgiving God to them, though taking vengeance on all their inventions.
verses.textLa: Domine Deus noster tu exaudiebas eos: Deus tu propitius fuisti eis, et ulciscens in omnes adinventiones eorum.

verses.textEn: Exalt the Lord our God, and adore on his holy mountain. For the Lord our God is holy.
verses.textLa: Exaltate Dominum Deum nostrum, et adorate in monte sancto eius: quoniam sanctus Dominus Deus noster.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of Confession.
verses.textLa: Psalmus in confessione.

verses.textEn: Shout joyfully to God, all the earth. Serve the Lord with rejoicing. Enter into his sight in exultation.
verses.textLa: Iubilate Deo omnis terra: servite Domino in lætitia. Introite in conspectu eius, in exultatione.

verses.textEn: Know that the Lord himself is God. He made us, and we ourselves did not. We are his people and the sheep of his pasture.
verses.textLa: Scitote quoniam Dominus ipse est Deus: ipse fecit nos, et non ipsi nos: Populus eius, et oves pascuæ eius:

verses.textEn: Enter his gates with confession, his courts with hymns, and acknowledge him. Praise his name.
verses.textLa: introite portas eius in confessione, atria eius in hymnis: confitemini illi. Laudate nomen eius:

verses.textEn: For the Lord is sweet, his mercy is in eternity, and his truth is from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: quoniam suavis est Dominus, in æternum misericordia eius, et usque in generationem et generationem veritas eius.

verses.textEn: A Psalm of David himself. I will sing mercy and judgment to you, O Lord. I will sing psalms.
verses.textLa: Psalmus ipsi David. Misericordiam, et iudicium cantabo tibi Domine: Psallam,

verses.textEn: And I will have understanding within the immaculate way, when you will draw near to me. I wandered about in the innocence of my heart, in the midst of my house.
verses.textLa: et intelligam in via immaculata, quando venies ad me. Perambulabam in innocentia cordis mei, in medio domus meæ.

verses.textEn: I will not display any unjust thing before my eyes. I have hated those carrying out betrayals.
verses.textLa: Non proponebam ante oculos meos rem iniustam: facientes prævaricationes odivi.

verses.textEn: The perverse heart did not adhere to me. And the malignant, who turned away before me, I would not recognize.
verses.textLa: Non adhæsit mihi cor pravum: declinantem a me malignum non cognoscebam.

verses.textEn: The one who secretly detracted his neighbor, this one I pursued. The one with an arrogant eye and an insatiable heart, with that one I would not eat.
verses.textLa: Detrahentem secreto proximo suo, hunc persequebar. Superbo oculo, et insatiabili corde, cum hoc non edebam.

verses.textEn: My eyes looked toward the faithful of the earth, to sit with me. The one walking in the immaculate way, this one ministered to me.
verses.textLa: Oculi mei ad fideles terræ ut sedeant mecum: ambulans in via immaculata, hic mihi ministrabat.

verses.textEn: He who has acted arrogantly will not dwell in the midst of my house. He who has spoken iniquity was not guided with the sight of my eyes.
verses.textLa: Non habitabit in medio domus meæ qui facit superbiam: qui loquitur iniqua, non direxit in conspectu oculorum meorum.

verses.textEn: In the morning, I executed all the sinners of the earth, so that I might scatter all the workers of iniquity from the city of the Lord.
verses.textLa: In matutino interficiebam omnes peccatores terræ: ut disperderem de civitate Domini omnes operantes iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: The prayer of the pauper, when he was anxious, and so he poured out his petition in the sight of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Oratio pauperis, cum anxius fuerit, et in conspectu Domini effuderit precem suam.

verses.textEn: O Lord, hear my prayer, and let my outcry reach you.
verses.textLa: Domine exaudi orationem meam: et clamor meus ad te veniat.

verses.textEn: Do not turn your face away from me. In whatever day that I am in trouble, incline your ear to me. In whatever day that I will call upon you, heed me quickly.
verses.textLa: Non avertas faciem tuam a me: in quacumque die tribulor, inclina ad me aurem tuam. In quacumque die invocavero te, velociter exaudi me.

verses.textEn: For my days have faded away like smoke, and my bones have dried out like firewood.
verses.textLa: Quia defecerunt sicut fumus dies mei: et ossa mea sicut cremium aruerunt.

verses.textEn: I have been cut down like hay, and my heart has withered, for I had forgotten to eat my bread.
verses.textLa: Percussus sum ut fœnum, et aruit cor meum: quia oblitus sum comedere panem meum.
verses.notes: This last part refers to those who separate themselves from the Eucharist: they dry out like hay and are cut down, and their hearts wither.

verses.textEn: Before the voice of my groaning, my bone has adhered to my flesh.
verses.textLa: A voce gemitus mei adhæsit os meum carni meæ.

verses.textEn: I have become like a pelican in solitude. I have become like a night raven in a house.
verses.textLa: Similis factus sum pellicano solitudinis: factus sum sicut nycticorax in domicilio.

verses.textEn: I have kept vigil, and I have become like a solitary sparrow on a roof.
verses.textLa: Vigilavi, et factus sum sicut passer solitarius in tecto.

verses.textEn: All day long my enemies reproached me, and those who praised me swore oaths against me.
verses.textLa: Tota die exprobrabant mihi inimici mei: et qui laudabant me adversum me iurabant.

verses.textEn: For I chewed on ashes like bread, and I mixed weeping into my drink.
verses.textLa: Quia cinerem tamquam panem manducabam, et potum meum cum fletu miscebam.

verses.textEn: By the face of your anger and indignation, you lifted me up and threw me down.
verses.textLa: A facie iræ et indignationis tuæ: quia elevans allisisti me.

verses.textEn: My days have declined like a shadow, and I have dried out like hay.
verses.textLa: Dies mei sicut umbra declinaverunt: et ego sicut fœnum arui.

verses.textEn: But you, O Lord, endure for eternity, and your memorial is from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Tu autem Domine in æternum permanes: et memoriale tuum in generationem et generationem.

verses.textEn: You will rise up and take pity on Zion, for it is time for its mercy, for the time has come.
verses.textLa: Tu exurgens misereberis Sion: quia tempus miserendi eius, quia venit tempus.

verses.textEn: For its stones have pleased your servants, and they will take pity on its land.
verses.textLa: Quoniam placuerunt servis tuis lapides eius: et terræ eius miserebuntur.

verses.textEn: And the Gentiles will fear your name, O Lord, and all the kings of the earth your glory.
verses.textLa: Et timebunt Gentes nomen tuum Domine, et omnes reges terræ gloriam tuam.

verses.textEn: For the Lord has built up Zion, and he will be seen in his glory.
verses.textLa: Quia ædificavit Dominus Sion: et videbitur in gloria sua.

verses.textEn: He has noticed the prayer of the humble, and he has not despised their petition.
verses.textLa: Respexit in orationem humilium: et non sprevit precem eorum.

verses.textEn: Let these things be written in another generation, and the people who will be created will praise the Lord.
verses.textLa: Scribantur hæc in generatione altera: et populus, qui creabitur, laudabit Dominum:

verses.textEn: For he has gazed from his high sanctuary. From heaven, the Lord has beheld the earth.
verses.textLa: Quia prospexit de excelso sancto suo: Dominus de cælo in terram aspexit:

verses.textEn: So may he hear the groans of those in shackles, in order that he may release the sons of the slain.
verses.textLa: Ut audiret gemitus compeditorum: ut solveret filios interemptorum:

verses.textEn: So may they announce the name of the Lord in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem:
verses.textLa: Ut annuncient in Sion nomen Domini: et laudem eius in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: while the people convene, along with kings, in order that they may serve the Lord.
verses.textLa: In conveniendo populos in unum, et reges ut serviant Domino.

verses.textEn: He responded to him in the way of his virtue: Declare to me the brevity of my days.
verses.textLa: Respondit ei in via virtutis suæ: Paucitatem dierum meorum nuncia mihi.

verses.textEn: Do not call me back in the middle of my days: your years are from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Ne revoces me in dimidio dierum meorum: in generationem et generationem anni tui.

verses.textEn: In the beginning, O Lord, you founded the earth. And the heavens are the work of your hands.
verses.textLa: Initio tu Domine terram fundasti: et opera manuum tuarum sunt cæli.

verses.textEn: They will perish, but you remain. And all will grow old like a garment. And, like a blanket, you will change them, and they will be changed.
verses.textLa: Ipsi peribunt, tu autem permanes: et omnes sicut vestimentum veterascent. Et sicut opertorium mutabis eos, et mutabuntur:

verses.textEn: Yet you are ever yourself, and your years will not decline.
verses.textLa: tu autem idem ipse es, et anni tui non deficient.

verses.textEn: The sons of your servants will live, and their offspring will be guided aright in every age.
verses.textLa: Filii servorum tuorum habitabunt: et semen eorum in sæculum dirigetur.

verses.textEn: To David himself. Bless the Lord, O my soul, and bless his holy name, all that is within me.
verses.textLa: Ipsi David. Benedic anima mea Domino et omnia, quæ intra me sunt, nomini sancto eius.

verses.textEn: Bless the Lord, O my soul, and do not forget all his recompenses.
verses.textLa: Benedic anima mea Domino: et noli oblivisci omnes retributiones eius:

verses.textEn: He forgives all your iniquities. He heals all your infirmities.
verses.textLa: Qui propitiatur omnibus iniquitatibus tuis: qui sanat omnes infirmitates tuas.

verses.textEn: He redeems your life from destruction. He crowns you with mercy and compassion.
verses.textLa: Qui redimit de interitu vitam tuam: qui coronat te in misericordia et miserationibus.

verses.textEn: He satisfies your desire with good things. Your youth will be renewed like that of the eagle.
verses.textLa: Qui replet in bonis desiderium tuum: renovabitur ut aquilæ iuventus tua:

verses.textEn: The Lord accomplishes mercies, and his judgment is for all who patiently endure injuries.
verses.textLa: Faciens misericordias Dominus: et iudicium omnibus iniuriam patientibus.

verses.textEn: He has made his ways known to Moses, his will to the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Notas fecit vias suas Moysi, filiis Israel voluntates suas.

verses.textEn: The Lord is compassionate and merciful, patient and full of mercy.
verses.textLa: Miserator, et misericors Dominus: longanimis, et multum misericors.

verses.textEn: He will not be angry forever, and he will not threaten for eternity.
verses.textLa: Non in perpetuum irascetur: neque in æternum comminabitur.
